Like most [[Western world|Western]] countries, Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by [[Christianity]]. [[Russia]]n and other Eastern European cultures also have had a more or less significant impact on the Ukrainian culture.\n \n-=your mumas boy hshbshbed==Social Manners==\n+==Religion==\n+\n+[[Religion]] is practiced throughout the country—[[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox Christianity]] and [[Eastern Catholic Churches|Eastern Catholicism]] are the two most widely practiced religions; [[Protestantism]] and [[Judaism]] are also well represented. The [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church]] is the largest in the country. Faithful of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]], the second largest, practice Byzantine rites but are united with the [[Roman Catholic Church]].\n+\n+==Social Manners==\n {{Cleanup-section|date=December 2007}}\n Ukrainians generally carry themselves in a very polite, civilized manner. Men often hold the door open for a woman when she enters a building, stand up when a woman enters the room, and, if there is a shortage of seats, men will give up their seats to the women. In rural areas, men will sometimes kiss a woman's hand, but this is starting to go out of fashion.<ref>{{cite book|coauthors=O. Bekh, J. M. Dingley|title=Ukrainian Phrasebook  |publisher=Lonely Planet |date=2005|isbn=9781741046052|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=E1QDn_T3CtIC&pg=PA48&dq=%22+kiss+a+woman%27s+hand%22+ukraine}}</ref>\n  "
}

Analysis:
Record 282 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Not Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The changes in the "Diff" field primarily involve the reorganization and addition of content related to religion and social manners in Ukraine. The revision adds a section on "Religion," detailing the various religious practices in Ukraine, which is a neutral and informative addition. The subsequent section on "Social Manners" describes cultural behaviors in a respectful manner, emphasizing politeness and traditional customs without any derogatory or inflammatory language.

There are no indicators of weaponization present in the text. The language used does not invoke any of the weaponization terms or narratives associated with the conflict between Ukraine and Russia. Instead, it focuses on cultural aspects in a descriptive and factual way, which does not serve to justify actions or shift narratives in a politically charged context.

Judgment: Not Weaponised
=============================================

The word ''[[lavra]]'' is used to describe high-ranking male monasteries for monks of the Eastern Orthodox Church. Therefore, the name of the monastery is also translated as Kiev Cave Monastery, Kiev Caves Monastery or the Kiev Monastery of the Caves (''на печерах'').\n+The word ''pechera'' means ''cave''. The word ''[[lavra]]'' is used to describe high-ranking male monasteries for monks of the Eastern Orthodox Church. Therefore, the name of the monastery is also translated as Kyiv Cave Monastery, Kyiv Caves Monastery or the Kyiv Monastery of the Caves (''на печерах'').\n \n ==Foundation and early history==\n According to the [[Primary Chronicle]], in the early 11th century, [[Anthony of Kiev|Anthony]], an [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox]] [[monk]] from [[Esphigmenou Monastery|Esphigmenon monastery]] on [[Mount Athos]], originally from [[Liubech]] of the [[Principality of Chernigov|Principality of Chernihiv]], returned to [[Kievan Rus'|Rus']] and settled in Kiev as a [[missionary]] of monastic tradition to Kievan Rus'. He chose a cave at the Berestov Mount that overlooked the [[Dnieper River]] and a community of disciples soon grew. [[Knyaz|Prince]] [[Iziaslav I of Kiev]] ceded the whole mount to the Anthonite monks who founded a monastery built by architects from [[Constantinople]]."
}

Analysis:
Record 624 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:** The revision changes the spelling of "Kiev" to "Kyiv," which aligns with the Ukrainian government's official romanization of the city's name. This shift is significant as it reflects a broader narrative of asserting Ukrainian identity and sovereignty, particularly in the context of ongoing geopolitical tensions with Russia. The use of "Kyiv" instead of "Kiev" can be seen as a subtle but deliberate choice to emphasize Ukrainian cultural heritage and to reject Russian influence, which often uses the older spelling. The comment by the user does not indicate any neutral intent, and the change in terminology can be interpreted as part of a larger effort to promote a specific cultural narrative.

Judgment: Weaponised
=============================================

Construction of Cathedrals that demonstrate some of the finest examples of late 19th century [[Russian Architecture]] was undertaken in large cities such as [[Odessa]] and [[Sevastopol]].\n \n ===Territories gained from partitions===\n In the late 17th century the Poland became less and less influential and internal corruption as well as the pressure from its powerful neighbors resulted in its [[Partitions of Poland|partitions]] by neighbouring empires. The [[Russian Empire]], in particular, gained most of ethnically [[Ukrainians|Ukrainian]] land and all of the [[Belarusians|Belarusian]] lands. After nearely two centuries of [[polonization]], the Uniate influence on the Ukrainian population was so great that hardly any remained Orthodox. Although some, particularly in [[Podolia]], chose to revert to Orthodoxy soon after, this in many cases was an exception rather than trend and in locations where the Unia already gave deep roots into the population all of the church property remained in the Catholic and Uniate authority. Religion in the new [[socialist]] state had little value, but particularly the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] who was actively supportive of the [[White Movement]]. Massive arrests and repressions began immediately. In the [[Ukrainian SSR]] (one of the founding republics of the USSR) as early as in December [[1918]] the first execution of the head of the Ukrainian Exarchate Metropolitan of Kiev and [[Halych]] took place. This was only the start which culminated in mass closing and destruction of churches that (some standing since the days of the [[Kievan Rus]]) and executions of clergy and followers.\n \n-Prior to the [[Bolshevik]]s takeover, Ukraine declared its political independence from Russia in 1918. During that period the Ukrainian [[autocephalous]] Orthodox Church was re-established. \n-\n-With the Bolshevik takeover the Communist authorities initially supported the Ukrainian national churches as a tool in their goal to weaken the anti-Soviet stance of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]]. In [[1921]] the first formation of the [[Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church]] (UAOC) was recognized. Because of strong opposition from the Russian Orthodox Church, the church ordained its own hierarchy itself, a practice questionable under the [[canon law]], in the \"Alexandrian\" manner - by laying on priests' hands on two senior candidates who became known as [[Metropolitan Vasyl (Lypkivsky)]] and [[Archbishop Nestor (Sharayivsky)]] (reportedly the relics of St. Clement of Rome who died in Ukraine in the first century were also used).[http://www.unicorne.org/ORTHODOXY/articles/contributors/articles/historyuocc.htm] Despite the [[canon law]] controversy, the new church was recognized in 1924 by the [[Ecumenical Patriarch]] Gregory VII.{{fact|date=February 2007}}  In the wake of the [[Ukrainization]] policies carried out in Soviet Ukraine in the first decade of the Soviet rule many of the Orthodox clergy willfully joined the church. During the period in which the Soviet government tolerated the renewed Ukrainian national church the UAOC gained a wide following particularly among the Ukrainian peasantry.<ref>{{cite book| author=Robert Conquest | title=The harvest of sorrow: Soviet collectivization and the terror-famine.| location= Oxford, United Kingdom | publisher= Oxford University Press| year = 1986 |isbn=0-19-505180-7 |pages=211-212}}</ref>\n+Prior to the [[Bolshevik]]s victory, Ukraine was controlled by several [[Ukrainian People's Republic|short-lived yet independent governments]] which revived the Ukrainian national idea. Ukraine declared its political independence from Russia in 1918 and the Ukrainian [[autocephalous]] Orthodox Church was established. Following the Soviet regime's taking root in Ukraine and despite the ongoing Soviet-wide antireligious campaign, the Bolshevik authorities saw the national churches as a tool in their goal to suppress the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] always viewed with the great suspicion by the regime for its being the cornerstone of pre-revolutionary [[Russian Empire]] and the initially strong opposition the church took towards the regime change (the position of the [[patriarch]] [[Tikhon of Moscow]] was especially critical). The Communist authorities initially supported the Ukrainian national churches as a tool in their goal to weaken the anti-Soviet stance of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]]. In [[1921]] the first formation of the [[Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church]] (UAOC) was recognized. The [[Russian Orthodox Church]] strongly opposed the formation of the Ukrainian autocephaly and not a single ordained bishop was willing or able to ordain the hierarchi for an new Church. Therefore, \"ordained\" its own hierarchy itself, a practice questionable under the [[canon law]], in the \"Alexandrian\" manner - by laying on priests' hands on two senior candidates who became known as [[Metropolitan Vasyl (Lypkivsky)]] and [[Archbishop Nestor (Sharayivsky)]] (reportedly the relics of St. Clement of Rome who died in Ukraine in the first century were also used).[http://www.unicorne.org/ORTHODOXY/articles/contributors/articles/historyuocc.htm] Despite the [[canon law]] controversy, the new church was recognized in 1924 by the [[Ecumenical Patriarch]] Gregory VII.{{fact|date=February 2007}}  In the wake of the [[Ukrainization]] policies carried out in Soviet Ukraine in the first decade of the Soviet rule many of the Orthodox clergy willfully joined the church thus avoiding the persecution suffered by many clergy members who remained inside the Russian Orthodoc Church. During the period in which the Soviet government tolerated the renewed Ukrainian national church the UAOC gained a wide following particularly among the Ukrainian peasantry.<ref>{{cite book| author=Robert Conquest | title=The harvest of sorrow: Soviet collectivization and the terror-famine.| location= Oxford, United Kingdom | publisher= Oxford University Press| year = 1986 |isbn=0-19-505180-7 |pages=211-212}}</ref>\n \n In the early-[[1930s]] the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] government abruptly reversed the policies in the national republics and mass arrests of UAOC's hierarchy and clergy culminated in the liquidation of the church in 1930. Most of the property was officially transferred to the ROC, with some churches closed for good and destroyed. On the eve of the [[Second World War]] only 3% of the pre-revolutionary parishes on the territory of Ukraine remained open to the public, often hidden in deep rural areas.\n+\n \n ===Second Polish Republic===\n The 1921 [[Peace of Riga]] treaty that ended the [[Polish-Soviet War]] gave the significant areas of the ethnically Ukrainian (and Belarusian) territories to the reborn [[Second Polish Republic|Polish state]]. This included [[Polesie]] and [[Volhynia]], areas with almost exclussively Orthodox population amongst the rural peasants, as well as the former Austrian province of [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]] with its [[Uniate]] population. \n@@ -122,18 +121,18 @@\n ===Post War Situations===\n The Russian Orthodox Church regained its general monopoly in the [[Ukrainian SSR]] after [[World War II]] following another shift in the official Soviet attitude towards Christian churches. As a result many started to accuse it of being a [[puppet]] of the [[Communist Party]]. After the suspicious death of Patriarch Tikhon, the UAOC and UGCC sought to avoid the transfer under the Moscow Patriarchate; something that Moscow tolerated until after World War II, for example the head of the Ukrainian Communist Party, [[Nikita Khruschev]] attended the funeral of the head of the Uniate Church in [[1946]]. Nevertheless as the Uniate Church did in some cases support the Nazi regime, the overall Soviet attitude was negative. In [[1948]] a small group of priests started to proclaim a reunion with Orthodoxy. The Soviet state organized in [[1948]] a synod in [[Lviv]], where the [[1596]] [[Union of Brest]] was annulled. Thereby breaking the canonical ties with [[Catholic see|Rome]] and transferring under the Moscow Patriarchate. In Transcarpathia, the reigning Greek Catholic bishop was murdered[http://www.ewtn.com/library/MARY/theoromz.htm] and the remaining priests were forced to return their Church to Orthodoxy. This move's acceptance was mixed. With many clergy members and lay believers turning to the ROC, some adamantly refused. As a result of this the Patriarchate of Moscow could now legally lay claim to any Orthodox church property that was within the territory of its uncontested jurisdiction, which it did. Some believers refused to accept liquidation of their churches and for nearly 40 years the UAOC and UGCC existed in Western Ukraine underground lead by the clergy members under the threat of prosecution by the Soviet state. Much of the UGCC and UAOC clergy not willing to serve in the ROC emigrated to [[Germany]], the [[United States]], or [[Canada]]. Others were sent to Siberia and even chose to be martyred [http://www.ugcc.org.ua/eng/press-releases/article;3254/][http://www.risu.org.ua/article.php?l=en&sid=1431]. Officially the Moscow Patriarchate never recognised the canonical right of the synod as it lacked any bishops there. \n \n-The relatively permissive post-war government attitude towards the Orthodox Church came to an end with [[Nikita Khruschev]]'s \"Thaw\" programme, which included closing the recently opened Kiev's Caves Lavra. However, in the west-Ukrainian dioceses, which were the largest in the USSR, the Soviet attitude was \"softest\". In fact in the western city of Lviv, only one church was closed. The Moscow Patriarchate also relaxed its canons on the clergy, especially those from the former-uniate territories, allowing them, for example to shave beards (a very uncommon Orthodox practice) and conduct eulogy in Ukrainian instead of Russian.\n+The relatively permissive post-war government attitude towards the Orthodox Church came to an end with [[Nikita Khruschev]]'s \"Thaw\" programme, which included closing the recently opened Kiev's Caves Lavra. However, in the west-Ukrainian dioceses, which were the largest in the USSR, the Soviet attitude was \"softest\". In fact in the western city of Lviv, only one church was closed. The Moscow Patriarchate also relaxed its canons on the clergy, especially those from the former-uniate territories, allowing them, for example to shave beards (a very uncommon Orthodox practice) and conduct eulogy in Ukrainian instead of [[Church Slavonic]].\n \n ===Late Soviet period===\n In [[1988]] with the millennium anniversary of the baptism of [[Kievan Rus|Rus]], there was yet another shift in the Soviet attitude towards religion, coinciding with the [[Perestroika]] and [[Glasnost]] programmes. The Soviet Government publicly apologized for oppression of religion and promised to return all property to the rightful owners. As a result thousands of closed religious buildings in all areas of the USSR were returned to their original owners. In Ukraine this was the then ROC's [[Ukrainian Exarchate]], which took place in the central, eastern and southern Ukraine. In the former-uniate areas of western Ukraine things were more turbulent. As UGCC survived in diaspora and in the underground they took their chance and were immediately revived in Ukraine, where in the wake of general liberalization of the Soviet policies in the late-1980s also prompted the activization of Ukrainian national political movements. The [[Russian Orthodox Church]] became viewed by some as an attribute of Soviet domination, and bitter, often violent clashes over church buildings followed with the ROC slowly losing its parishes to the UGCC. \n \n-The UAOC also followed suit. Sometimes possessors of Church buildings changed several times within days. Although the Soviet law-enforcement did attempt to pacify the almost-warring parties, these were often unsuccessful, as many of the local branches in the ever-crumbling Soviet authority, sympathised with the national sentiments in their areas. Violence grew especially after the UGCC's demand that all property that was held prior to [[1939]] would be returned.\n+The UAOC also followed suit. Sometimes possessors of Church buildings changed several times within days. Although the Soviet law-enforcement did attempt to pacify the almost-warring parties, these were often unsuccessful, as many of the local branches in the ever-crumbling Soviet authority, sympathised with the national sentiments in their areas. Violence grew especially after the UGCC's demand that all property that was held prior to [[1939]] would be returned returned including the property that was initially of the Orthodox church. \n \n It is now believed that the only real event which helped to contain the growing schism in the former-uniate territories was the ROC's reaction of raising its Ukrainian Exarchate to the status of an [[Autonomous entity|autonomous church]], which took place in [[1990]], and up until the [[History of the Soviet Union (1985-1991)|break up of the USSR]] in late [[1991]] there was an uneasy peace in western Ukraine. After the nation became independent, the question of an independent and an [[autocephalous]] Orthodox Church arose once again.\n \n ===Post-Soviet period===\n \n-What historians now see as the reason for the following events was the decision of the head of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church Metropolitan of Kiev and all Ukraine [[Patriarch Filaret (Mykhailo Denysenko)|Filaret]] to achieve total [[autocephaly]] (independence) of his [[metropolitan see]] with or without the approval of the [[mother church]] required by the [[canon law]]. These events followed Filaret's own unsuccessful attempt to gain a seat of the [[Moscow Patriarch]] to himself ([[1990]]) and the Ukrainian independence following the [[collapse of the Soviet Union]] in August, 1991. In November 1991, Metropolitan Filaret requested the hierarchy of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] to grant the Ukrainian Orthodox Church autocephalous status. The skeptical hierarchy of the Russian Orthodox Church called for a full Synodical council (Sobor) where this issue would have been discussed at length. Filaret, using his support from the old friendship ties with the then newly elected [[President of Ukraine]] ([[Leonid Kravchuk]]), convinced him that a new independent government should have its own independent church. Filaret was able to organise a covert communion with the UAOC in case [[Moscow Patriarchate]] refused.\n+What historians now see as the reason for the following events was the decision of the head of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church Metropolitan of Kiev and all Ukraine [[Patriarch Filaret (Mykhailo Denysenko)|Filaret]] to achieve total [[autocephaly]] (independence) of his [[metropolitan see]] with or without the approval of the [[mother church]] required by the [[canon law]]. These events followed Filaret's own unsuccessful attempt to gain a seat of the [[Moscow Patriarch]] to himself ([[1990]]) and the Ukrainian independence following the [[collapse of the Soviet Union]] in August, 1991. In November 1991 Metropolitan Filaret requested the hierarchy of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] to grant the Ukrainian Orthodox Church autocephalous status. The skeptical hierarchy of the Russian Orthodox Church called for a full Synodical council (Sobor) where this issue would have been discussed at length. Filaret, using his support from the old friendship ties with the then newly elected [[President of Ukraine]] ([[Leonid Kravchuk]]), convinced him that a new independent government should have its own independent church. Despite the unpopularity of the UAOC outside [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]], Filaret managed to organise a covert communion with the UAOC in case [[Moscow Patriarchate]] refused.\n \n At the synod in March-April of [[1992]], however, most of the clergy of the UOC who initially supported Filaret, openly criticised this move, and put most of the other bishops against him. Questions of his unpopular disregard to [[monastic vows]] (having a [[common-law wife]]) as well as the allegations of improper financial dealings with the church finances made the council vote for Filaret to retire from his position which was confirmed by a sworn oath. \n "
}

Analysis:
Record 582 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision made by the user "Irpen" includes several subtle shifts in language that could be interpreted as weaponizing cultural heritage. 

1. **Terminology Changes**: The phrase "lands of present-day Ukraine" replaces "Ukraine," which can imply a historical claim to the territory that may resonate with nationalist sentiments. This shift subtly emphasizes the historical context of the region, potentially framing it in a way that supports territorial claims.

2. **Cultural Identity**: The addition of "a medieval East Slavic state" after "Kievan Rus'" reinforces the historical significance of Kievan Rus' in the context of Ukrainian identity. This could be seen as an attempt to assert a distinct Ukrainian cultural heritage in contrast to Russian narratives.

3. **Language and Nationalism**: The phrase "Ukrainian domination of the Russian Orthodox Church" suggests a narrative of Ukrainian cultural and religious influence over Russian heritage, which can be interpreted as a counter-narrative to Russian claims of cultural superiority or historical entitlement.

4. **Historical Context**: The revision includes references to the "Ottomans" and "Russia" in a way that emphasizes the historical conflicts and power dynamics in the region. This framing can be used to justify contemporary political positions regarding cultural heritage and territorial claims.

5. **Emphasis on Religious and Cultural Conflict**: The mention of the "Ukrainization policies" and the "suppression of the

Judgment: Weaponised

Some of these works are inscribed by [[UNESCO]] as part of the [[Intangible Cultural Heritage of Ukraine|Intangible Cultural Heritage of Ukraine.]] \n \n ====Jewelry====\n [[File:Carpatho-Rusyn sub-groups - Transcarpathian Rusyns in original goral folk-costumes from Maramureş ..jpg|thumb|Ukrainians in national dress]]\n@@ -139,6 +139,7 @@\n * [[List of museums in Ukraine]]\n * [[List of places named after people#Ukraine|List of places named after people (Ukraine)]]\n * [[List of UNESCO World Heritage Sites in Ukraine]]\n+* [[Intangible Cultural Heritage of Ukraine]]\n * [[Russification of Ukraine]]\n * The [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine]] are the seven historical and cultural monuments of Ukraine\n * [[Ukrainian historical regions]]"
}

Analysis:
Record 786 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision includes a notable emphasis on the "Russification of Ukraine," which is framed as a historical process that led to the loss of Ukrainian culture and language. This term is a sensitive and politically charged phrase that aligns with narratives of cultural oppression and loss, often used to highlight the negative impacts of Russian influence on Ukrainian heritage. The addition of "Intangible Cultural Heritage of Ukraine" in the "See also" section further reinforces the focus on Ukrainian cultural identity and the importance of preserving it against perceived threats.

The language used in the diff, particularly phrases like "much of the oral history was lost" and "Ukrainian culture and language were forbidden," suggests a narrative of victimization and cultural erasure, which can be weaponized to justify contemporary political stances or actions. The context of the revision, along with the specific terms chosen, indicates an intention to frame the discussion around Ukrainian cultural heritage in a way that highlights its vulnerability and the need for protection against external forces, particularly in light of ongoing geopolitical tensions.

Judgment: Weaponised
=============================================

In addition the church has mass parishes abroad in the North American continent, South America, and Australia.\n \n-==Other religions in Ukraine==\n+==Other Christian groups in Ukraine==\n ===Roman Catholicism===\n-Roman Catholicism is predominately practiced by non-Ukrainian minorities, like [[Poles]] and [[Hungarians]]. Originally holding a large amount of parishes, most of the buildings remain empty after [[World War II]] which is attributed due to the [[Massacre of Poles in Volhynia]] and the [[Population transfers in the Soviet Union]]\n-\n-===Greek Catholic Eparchy of Mukachevo===\n-Following the fall of the Soviet Union, the Greek Catholic church in [[Zakarpattya Oblast|Transcarpathia]] emerged from the underground and was restored as a Greek Catholic Church separate from the Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church based in [[Galicia]] despite the protests of a portion of the Church members led by the bishop of Khust who demanded to be integrated into the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]].[http://www.rusyn.org/?root=rusyns&rusyns=religion&article=94]  Despite this revival, unlike in Galicia there are twice as many Orthodox and Greek Catholic parishes in Transcarpathia.   \n+Roman Catholicism is predominately practiced by non-Ukrainian minorities, like [[Poles]] and [[Hungarians]]. Originally holding a large amount of parishes, most of the buildings remain empty after [[World War II]] which is attributed due to the [[Massacre of Poles in Volhynia]] and the [[Population transfers in the Soviet Union]].\n+\n+The other main Roman Catholic groups are the Hungarian and Slovak population of Trascarpathia.\n+\n \n ===Old Believers===\n Traditionally the Ukrainian clergy, following the annexation of Kievan Metropolia, were one of the main oppositions to the Old Believer schism which took place at the time, under [[Patriarch Nikon]]. None of the Ukrainian parishes followed the [[Russian Orthodox Old-Rite Church]]. Although in [[1905]] the Tsar's decree on freedom of religion allowed the Old believer church to reform, it gained minute support in Ukraine. Presentely, however the Old Believer's community very much exploited the politicised schism in Ukrainian Orthodoxy and as of 2004 number 53 communities scattered throughout Ukraine. [http://www.starovery.ru/pravda/nzd.php?cid=81]\n \n-=== Protestantism in Ukraine ===\n+===Protestantism in Ukraine===\n \n In the 16th century small groups of [[Anabaptists]] appeared in [[Volodymyr-Volynskyi]], but the influence of the [[Reformation]] in Ukraine remained marginal until the three centuries later. \n \n [[Protestantism]] arrived to Ukraine together with German immigrants in the 18th century, who were initially granted religious freedom by the Russian Imperial authorities, unlike the native population.  One of earliest Protestant groups in Ukraine were [[Studists]] (the name originated from the German ''Stunde'', \"hour\") German Evangelical sect that spread from German villages in [[Bessarabia]] and [[Dnipropetrovsk Oblast|Ekaterinoslav province]] to the neighbouring Ukrainian population. Protestantism in Ukraine rapidly grew during the liberal reforms of [[Alexander II of Russia|Alexander II]] in the 1860s. However, towards the end of the century authorities started to restrict Protestant [[proselytism]] of the Orthodox Christians, especially by the Studistis, routinely preventing prayer meetings and other activities.  At the same time [[Baptists]], another major Protestant group that was growing in Ukraine, were treated less harshly due to their powerful international connections.\n \n-In the early 20th century, [[Volyn]] became the main centre of the spread of Protestantism in Ukraine. During the Soviet period Protestantism, together with Orthodox Christianity, was persecuted in Ukraine, but the 1980s marked the start of another major expansion of Protestant proselytism in Ukraine.\n+In the early 20th century, [[Volhynia]] became the main centre of the spread of Protestantism in Ukraine. During the Soviet period Protestantism, together with Orthodox Christianity, was persecuted in Ukraine, but the 1980s marked the start of another major expansion of Protestant proselytism in Ukraine.\n \n Today largest Protestant groups in Ukraine include Baptists (All-Ukrainian Union of the Association of Evangelical Baptists), [[Pentecostals]] (All-Ukrainian Union of Christians of the Evangelical Faith-Pentecostals) and  [[Seventh-day Adventists]] (Ukrainian Union Conference of Seventh-day Adventists). Of note is [[Hillsong]] church in Kiev. Despite the rapid growth and aggressive missionary activities, even today Protestants in Ukraine remain a small minority in a largely Orthodox Christian country.\n "
}

Analysis:
Record 292 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Not Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision primarily involves a change in the section title from "Other religions in Ukraine" to "Other Christian groups in Ukraine," which indicates a shift in focus towards Christianity rather than a broader discussion of all religions. However, the content itself does not employ any weaponized language or narratives that could be interpreted as framing cultural or territorial control in a specific light. 

The text discusses various Christian denominations in Ukraine, including Roman Catholicism and Protestantism, without invoking any contentious terms or narratives associated with the ongoing conflict between Ukraine and Russia. The mention of historical events, such as the "Massacre of Poles in Volhynia" and the "Population transfers in the Soviet Union," is presented in a factual manner without emotive language or implications that could be construed as weaponizing cultural heritage. 

Overall, while the revision does reflect a change in emphasis, it does not contain linguistic indicators that suggest an intent to weaponize cultural heritage.

Judgment: Not Weaponised
=============================================

UNESCO document - MFA of Ukraine |date=2019-07-09 |website=gordonua.com |language=ru-UA |access-date=2019-07-26}}</ref> or '''Kyivo-Pechers’ka Lavra'''<ref>[http://www.rada.gov.ua/ukraine.htm Verkhovna Rada Portal] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727035555/http://www.rada.gov.ua/ukraine.htm |date=27 July 2011 }} This is the official English spelling used by the Ukrainian {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713180218/http://www.kyivpost.com/news/city/detail/69789/ |date=13 July 2011 }} Interfax-Ukraine, 16 June 2010 at 10:42</ref> ({{lang-uk|Києво-Печерська лавра|translit=Kyievo-Pecherska lavra}}), also known as the '''Kyiv Monastery of the Caves''', is a historic [[Monastery#Eastern Orthodox|Eastern Orthodox Christian monastery]] which gave its name to [[Pechers’ky Raion|one of the city districts]] where it is located in [[Kyiv]].\n \n Since its foundation as the [[cave monastery]] in 1051, the [[Lavra]] has been a preeminent center of [[Eastern Orthodox Christianity]] in Eastern Europe.<ref>Magocsi P.R. A History of Ukraine. University of Toronto Press: Toronto, 1996. p 98.</ref>\n \n ==Etymology and other names==\n-[[File:Perchersk Lavra, Kyiv Lithograph.jpg|left|thumb|Lithograph of Pechers`ka Lavra, Kyiv,<ref>[https://www.nga.gov/research/library/imagecollections/features/watsons_russia.html Department of Image Collections]</ref> National Gallery of Art Library, Washington, DC]]\n+[[File:Perchersk Lavra, Kyiv Lithograph.jpg|left|thumb|Lithograph of Pechersk Lavra, Kyiv,<ref>[https://www.nga.gov/research/library/imagecollections/features/watsons_russia.html Department of Image Collections]</ref> National Gallery of Art Library, Washington, DC]]\n [[File:Lavra Kyiv.JPG|thumb|Panorama of the monastery (southward view)|left]]\n-[[File:Uspensky Sobor.jpg|thumb|The restored Cathedral of the Dormition, as seen in 2005|left]]\n+[[File:Uspensky Sobor.jpg|thumb|The restored Cathedral of the Dormition, as seen in 2005.|left]]\n The word ''pechera'' means ''cave''. The word ''[[lavra]]'' is used to describe high-ranking male monasteries for monks of the Eastern Orthodox Church. Therefore, the name of the monastery is also translated as Kyiv Cave Monastery, Kyiv Caves Monastery or the Kyiv Monastery of the Caves (''на печерах'').{{cn|date=January 2023}}\n \n == History ==\n === Foundation and early history ===\n According to the [[Primary Chronicle]], in the early 11th century, [[Anthony of Kiev|Anthony]], a Christian [[monk]] from [[Esphigmenou Monastery|Esphigmenon monastery]] on [[Mount Athos]], originally from [[Liubech]] of the [[Principality of Chernigov]], returned to [[Kievan Rus'|Rus']] and settled in Kyiv as a [[missionary]] of monastic tradition to Kyivan Rus'. He chose a cave at the Berestov Mount that overlooked the [[Dnieper River]] and a community of disciples soon grew. [[Knyaz|Prince]] [[Iziaslav I of Kiev|Iziaslav I of Kyiv]] ceded the whole mount to the Anthonite monks who founded a monastery built by architects from [[Constantinople]].{{cn|date=January 2023}}\n \n-[[File:Kievo-Pecherska Lavra Belltower.jpg|thumb|Up-close view of the [[Great Lavra Belltower]] with its four tiers in 2005|left]]\n-[[File:Near Caves.jpg|thumb|The [[Near Caves (Pechersk Lavra)|Near Caves]] of the Kyiv Pechers'ka Lavra. Sketch by the Dutch artist Abraham van Westerveld,<!--Q10429035--> made in 1651.|left]]\n+[[File:Kievo-Pecherska Lavra Belltower.jpg|thumb|Up-close view of the [[Great Lavra Belltower]] with its four tiers in 2005.|left]]\n+[[File:Near Caves.jpg|thumb|The [[Near Caves (Pechersk Lavra)|Near Caves]] of the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra. Sketch by the Dutch artist Abraham van Westerveld<!--Q10429035--> made in 1651.|left]]\n \n === Modern history ===\n Together with the [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kyiv|Saint Sophia Cathedral]], the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra has been inscribed as a [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]] since 1990.<ref name=\"Kyiv Pechersk Lavra, St. Sophia Cathedral remain on UNESCO’s World Heritage List\">[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/kyiv-pechersk-lavra-st-sophia-cathedral-remain-on-unescos-world-heritage-list/ Kyiv Pechersk Lavra, St. Sophia Cathedral remain on UNESCO’s World Heritage List] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130624183743/http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/kyiv-pechersk-lavra-st-sophia-cathedral-remain-on-unescos-world-heritage-list/ |date=24 June 2013 }}, [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (20 June 2013)</ref>{{#tag:ref|Late 2010 a monitoring mission of [[UNESCO]] was visiting the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra to check on situation of the site. At the time the [[Ministry of Culture (Ukraine)|Minister of Culture]] [[Mykhailo Kulynyak]] stated the historic site along with the [[Saint Sophia's Cathedral, Kyiv|Saint Sophia Cathedral]] was not threatened by the \"black list\" of the organisation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mincult.kmu.gov.ua/mincult/uk/publish/article/238820 |title=\"Софії Київській та Києво-Печерській лаврі \"чорний список\" ЮНЕСКО не загрожує\" – Міністр культури Михайло Кулиняк |trans-title=\"Sophia of Kyiv and Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra are not threatened by the UNESCO \"black list\" - Minister of Culture Mykhailo Kulinyak |access-date=23 June 2017 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150711080914/http://mincult.kmu.gov.ua/mincult/uk/publish/article/238820 |archive-date=11 July 2015 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> The [[World Heritage Committee]] of UNESCO decided in June 2013 that Kyiv Pechersk Lavra, and St. Sofia Cathedral and related monastery buildings would remain on the [[World Heritage List]].<ref name=\"Kyiv Pechersk Lavra, St. Sophia Cathedral remain on UNESCO’s World Heritage List\"/>|group=nb}} The monastery complex is considered a separate national historic-cultural preserve (sanctuary), the national status to which was granted on 13 March 1996.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=181/96&p=1260343170231885 |title=Про надання статусу національного Києво-Печерському держав... - від 13.03.1996 № 181/96 |trans-title=On granting the status of national Kyiv-Pechersk State... - dated 03.13.1996 No. 181/96 |website=zakon1.rada.gov.ua |access-date=23 June 2017}}</ref> The Lavra is not only located in another part of the city, but is part of a different national sanctuary than Saint Sophia Cathedral. While being a cultural attraction, the monastery is once again active, with over 100 monks in residence.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} It was named one of the [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine]] on 21 August 2007.{{cn|date=January 2023}}\n@@ -196,9 +196,7 @@\n \n ==Buildings and structures==\n [[File:Perchersk Lavra, Kyiv Panorama.jpg|left|thumb|Pechersk Lavra, Kyiv, [https://www.nga.gov/research/library/imagecollections/features/watsons_russia.html Department of Image Collections], National Gallery of Art Library, Washington, DC]]\n-The Kyiv Pechersk Lavra contains numerous architectural monuments, ranging from [[bell tower]]s to cathedrals to cave systems and to strong stone [[Lavra fortification|fortification walls]]. The main attractions of the Lavra include the [[Great Lavra Belltower]], and the [[Cathedral of the Dormition (Pechersk Lavra)|Dormition Cathedral]], destroyed in [[World War II]], and fully reconstructed in recent years.{{when|date=September 2018}} Other churches and cathedrals of the Lavra include: the [[Refectory Church (Pechersk Lavra)|Refectory Church]], the Church of All Saints, the [[Church of the Saviour at Berestove]], the Church of the Exaltation of Cross, the Church of the Trinity, the Church of the Nativity of the Virgin, the Church of the Conception of St. Anne, and the Church of the Life-Giving Spring. The main attractions of the Lavra include the [[Great Lavra Belltower]], and the [[Cathedral of the Dormition (Pechersk Lavra)|Dormition Cathedral]], destroyed in [[World War II]] by Soviet forces, and fully reconstructed in recent years.{{when|date=September 2018}} Other churches and cathedrals of the Lavra include: the [[Refectory Church (Pechersk Lavra)|Refectory Church]], the Church of All Saints, the [[Church of the Saviour at Berestove]], the Church of the Exaltation of Cross, the Church of the Trinity, the Church of the Nativity of the Virgin, the Church of the Conception of St. Anne, and the Church of the Life-Giving Spring. The Lavra also contains many other constructions, including: the St. Nicholas Monastery, the Kyiv Theological Academy and Seminary, and the Debosquette Wall.{{cn|date=January 2023}}\n \n ===Great Lavra Belltower===\n {{main|Great Lavra Belltower}}\n@@ -207,9 +205,9 @@\n \n ===Dormition Cathedral===\n [[File:Собор Успенський2.jpg|thumb|Restored Dormition Church]]\n-Built in the 11th century, the main church of the monastery was destroyed during the [[World War II]].\n-\n-In 1928, the monastery was converted into an anti-religious museum park by the Soviet authorities and no efforts were provided to restore the church after it was destroyed. The temple was finally restored in 1995 after Ukraine obtained its independence and the construction was accomplished in two years. The new Dormition Church was consecrated in 2000.\n+Built in the 11th century, the main church of the monastery was destroyed during the [[World War II]], a couple of months after the Nazi Germany troops occupied the city of [[Kyiv]], during which the Soviet Union conducted the controversial [[1941 Khreshchatyk explosions]]. Withdrawing Soviet troops practiced the tactics of [[scorched earth]] and blew up all the Kyiv bridges over [[Dnieper]] as well as the main Khreshchatyk street and Kyiv Pechersk Lavra.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/ukraine_in_russian/2016/11/161103_ru_s_tsalyk_uspensky_cathedral.amp]</ref> The destruction of the cathedral followed a pattern of Soviet disregard for cultural heritage, as they previously blew up the ancient [[St. Michael's Golden-Domed Monastery]] nearby in the 1930s.<ref>[https://www.svoboda.org/a/kak-krasnaya-armiya-vzryvala-kiev/31467844.html Как Красная Армия взрывала Киев]</ref>\n+\n+In 1928, the monastery was converted into an anti-religious museum park by the Soviet authorities and after their return no efforts were provided to restore the church. The temple was finally restored in 1995 after Ukraine obtained its independence and the construction was accomplished in two years. The new Dormition Church was consecrated in 2000.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/ukraine_in_russian/2016/11/161103_ru_s_tsalyk_uspensky_cathedral.amp]</ref>\n \n ===Gate Church of the Trinity===\n {{main|Gate Church of the Trinity (Pechersk Lavra)}}\n@@ -224,12 +222,12 @@\n [[File:Kijów zabytkowy (307).JPG|thumb|Refectory Church|right]]\n The refectory chambers with the Church of the Saints Anthony and Theodosius is the third in a series of temples. The original temple was built in the 12th century and no drawings or visual depictions of it remain. The second temple was built at the time of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] and was disassembled by the Russian authorities in the 19th century. It was replaced with the current temple, often referred to as the Refectory Church of the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra.{{cn|date=January 2023}}\n \n-===All Saints Church===\n-All Saints Church, erected in 1696–1698, is a fine specimen of Ukrainian baroque architecture. Characteristic of the church facades are rich architectural embellishments. In 1905, students of the Lavra art school painted the interior walls of the church. The carved wooden iconostasis is multi-tiered and was made for All Saints Church in the early 18th century.{{cn|date=January 2023}}\n+===The All Saints Church===\n+The All Saints Church, erected in 1696–1698, is a fine specimen of Ukrainian baroque architecture. Characteristic of the church facades are rich architectural embellishments. In 1905, students of the Lavra art school painted the interior walls of the church. The carved wooden iconostasis is multi-tiered and was made for the All Saints church in the early 18th century.{{cn|date=January 2023}}\n \n ===Church of the Saviour at Berestov===\n {{main|Church of the Saviour at Berestove}}\n-[[File:Церква Спаса-на-Берестові, м. Київ.jpg|thumb|left|Side view of the [[Church of the Saviour at Berestove]] seen with its [[campanile]], designed by architect Andrei Melenskyi in the [[Classical architecture|Classical style]].]]\n \n The Church of the Saviour at Berestove is located to the North of the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra. It was constructed in the village of Berestove around the start of the 11th century during the reign of Prince [[Vladimir II Monomakh|Vladimir Monomakh]]. It later served as the mausoleum of the Monomakh dynasty, also including [[Yuri Dolgoruki]], the founder of Moscow. Despite being outside the Lavra fortifications, the Church of the Saviour at Berestove is part of the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra complex.{{cn|date=January 2023}}\n {{clearleft}}"
}

Analysis:
Record 778 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision made by the user "Materialscientist" includes several significant changes that reflect a subtle shift in the framing of cultural heritage, particularly regarding the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra. 

1. **Name Change**: The change from "Kyivo-Pechers’ka Lavra" to "Kyiv Pechersk Lavra" aligns with the Ukrainian government's official English spelling, which is a politically charged issue given the ongoing conflict. This shift emphasizes the recognition of Ukrainian sovereignty and identity, which can be seen as a response to Russian narratives that may downplay or contest this identity.

2. **Contextual Additions**: The revision includes a more detailed account of the destruction of the Dormition Cathedral during World War II, specifically attributing the destruction to "Soviet forces" and mentioning the "controversial 1941 Khreshchatyk explosions." This framing highlights a narrative of Soviet disregard for cultural heritage, which can be weaponized to foster resentment against Russia and to reinforce Ukrainian national identity.

3. **Removal of Controversial Claims**: The original text's mention of "Ukrainian authorities claimed that Metropolitan Pavlo Lebid had built 36 buildings unapproved by (the state)" was removed. This could be interpreted as an attempt to downplay internal controversies that might detract from a unified narrative of cultural preservation against external threats.

4. **Emphasis on Cultural Heritage**: The revision

Judgment: Weaponised

  "Diff": "--- \n+++ \n@@ -39,11 +39,11 @@\n \n The Russian Orthodox Church regained its general monopoly in the [[Ukrainian SSR]] after [[World War II]] following another shift in the official Soviet attitude towards Christian churches. As a result many started to accuse it of being a [[puppet]] of the [[Communist Party]]. After the suspicious death of Patriarch Tikhon, the UAOC and UGCC sought to avoid the transfer under the Moscow Patriarchy; something that Moscow tolerated until after World War II. At the state organized [[1948]] synod in [[Lviv]] (Lvov), some UGCC clergy were coerced into proclaiming the annulment of the [[1596]] [[Union of Brest]] thereby breaking the canonical ties with [[Catholic see|Rome]] and transferring under the Moscow Patriarchy. This move's acceptance was mixed. With many clergy members and lay believers turning to ROC, some adamantly refused. While the UAOC and UGCC church property in Ukraine was liquidated by the Soviet authorities or transferred to the ROC, many believers refused to accept liquidation of their churches and for nearly 40 years the UAOC and UGCC existed in Western Ukraine underground lead by the clergy members under the threat of prosecution by the Soviet state. Much of the UGCC and UAOC clergy not willing to serve in ROC emigrated to [[Germany]], the [[United States]], or [[Canada]] and the Patriarchate of Moscow could legally lay claim to any Orthodox church property that was within the territory of its uncontested jurisdiction, which it did. \n \n-The warm post-war attitude towards the Orthodox Church came to an end with [[Nikita Khruschev]]'s \"Thaw\" programme, which included closing the recently opened Kiev's Caves Lavra. However in the west-Ukrainian dioceses, which were the largest in the USSR, the Soviet attitude was \"softest\". In fact in the western city of Lviv, only one church was closed. The Moscow patriarchy also relaxed its canons on the clergy, especially those from the former-uniate territories, allowing them, for example to shave beards (a very uncommon Orthodox practice) and conduct liturgy in Ukrainian instead of Slavonic. \n+The warm post-war attitude towards the Orthodox Church came to an end with Nikita Khruschev's \"Thaw\" programme, which included closing the recently opened Kiev's Caves Lavra. However in the west-Ukrainian dioceses, which were the largest in the USSR, the Soviet attitude was \"softest\". In fact in the western city of Lvov, only one church was closed. The Moscow patriarchy also relaxed its canons on the clergy, especially those from the former-uniate territories, allowing them, for example to shave beards (a very uncommon Orthodox practice) and conduct liturgy in Ukrainian instead of Slavonic. \n \n-In 1988 with the millennium anniversary of the baptism of Rus, there was yet another shift in the Soviet attitude towards religion, coinciding with the Perestroika and Glasnost programmes, the USSR apologized for all repressions towards religion and promised to return all property to the rightful owners. Although what began as a peaceful return of many closed church buildings (of course to the then ROC's Ukrainian Exarchate) in the central, eastern and southern Ukraine (as well as in other parts of the USSR), in the former-uniate regions of western Ukraine it was a different story. As UGCC survived in diaspora and in the underground they took their chance and were immediately revived in Ukraine, where in the wake of the Rukh movements the UOC-MP was viewed as a leftover of Soviet occupation, and bitter, often violent clashes over church buildings followed with the UOC-MP slowly losing its parishes to the UGCC. The UAOC also did not wait long and quickly followed suit. Sometimes possessors of Church buildings changes several times in the space of a couple of days. All Soviet attempts to pacify the almost-warring church parties were useless. It is now believed that the only real event which enabled to contain the schism in the former-uniate territory was the ROC's reaction of raising its Ukrainian Exarchate to the status of an autonomous church, which took place in 1990, and up until the break up of the USSR (late 1991) there was an uneasy peace in western Ukraine. However after the nation became independent, the question of an independent and autocephalous Orthodox Church arose once again and another schism was approaching.\n+In 1988 with the millennium anniversary of the baptism of Rus, there was yet another shift in the Soviet attitude towards religion, coinciding with the Perestroika and Glasnost programmes, the USSR apologized for all repressions towards religion and promised to return all property to the rightful owners. Although what began as a peaceful return of many closed church buildings (of course to the then ROC's Ukrainian Exarchate) in the central, eastern and southern Ukraine (as well as in other parts of the USSR), in the former-uniate regions of western Ukraine it was a different story. As UGCC survived in diaspora and in the underground they took their chance and were immediately revived in Ukraine, where in the wake of the Rukh movements the UOC-MP was viewed as a leftover of Soviet occupation, and bitter, often violent clashes over church buildings followed with the UOC-MP slowly losing its parishes to the UGCC. The UAOC also did not wait long and quickly followed suit. Sometimes possessors of Church buildings changes several times in the space of a couple of days. All Soviet attempts to pacify the almost-warring church parties were unsuccessful, especially after the UGCC's demand that all property that was held prior to 1939 would be returned (even though some it was Orthodox before the Unia came). It is now believed that the only real event which enabled to contain the schism in the former-uniate territory was the ROC's reaction of raising its Ukrainian Exarchate to the status of an autonomous church, which took place in 1990, and up until the break up of the USSR (late 1991) there was an uneasy peace in western Ukraine. However after the nation became independent, the question of an independent and autocephalous Orthodox Church arose once again and another schism was approaching.\n \n-What historians now see as the reason for the following events was the decision of the head of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church Metropolitan of Kiev and all Ukraine [[Filaret]] to achieve total [[autocephalocy]] (independence) from the Russian Orthodox Church. After the fall of the USSR he led a movement for «full canonical independence, namely, autocephaly» for his Church. In November 1991 he headed a working council which requested the hierarchy of the Russian Orthodox Church to grant the Ukrainian Orthodox Church-Moscow Patriarchate autocephalous status.  President of Ukraine (then, [[Leonid Kravchuk]]) supported the request but unfortunately for Filaret the Moscow Patriarchate strongly opposed it. In a short time a number of articles appeared in the press accusing Filaret of severe violation of his monastic vows and abuse of his ecclesiastical authority. The Hierarchical Council of the Russian Orthodox Church, which met from March to April 1992, demanded that he leave his position. He promised that he would but, upon his return from Moscow, he announced that the promise was given under pressure and he would not leave. In May 1992 at a Hierarchical Council held in Kharkhiv the majority of the bishops of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church-Moscow Patriarchate voted to depose Metropolitan Filaret from his office and suspend his clerical functioning. Relying on the support of political authorities in Ukraine, Filaret with three other bishops united with the Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church. In June of 1992 they created a new Church, the Ukrainian Orthodox Church-Kyivan Patriarchate (UOC-KP). Though only chosen as assistant to 94-year-old Patriarch Mstyslav, Filaret was actually in control of church affairs. Opposing this situation, some of the Autocephalous bishops and clergy refused to join the Ukrainian Orthodox Church-Kyivan Patriarchate.\n+What historians now see as the reason for the following events was the decision of the head of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church Metropolitan of Kiev and all Ukraine Filaret to achieve total autocephalocy from the Russian Orthodox Church. To achieve that, with active support of the then president Leonid Kravchuk, he covertely organised a communion with the Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church in case Moscow refused. The skeptical hierarchy of the Russian Orthodox Church called for a full council where this issue would have been discussed, upon arrival most of the clergy of the UOC who initially supported Filaret, openely criticised this move and immediately the votes turned against him. In the end the council voted for Filaret to retire from his position which was confirmed by a swore. Upon returning to Kiev however Filaret carried out his reserve option, and Police aided by nationalist Paramilitaries supported him in retaining his rank. The UOC synod was quick to respond and in the eastern city of Kharkov elected a new leader, the Metropolitan Vladimir (Slobodan). From there most of the fate of control of church buildings was decided by the church parishes, but when most refused to follow Filaret, paramilitaries, especially in Volyn and Rovno Oblasts carried out raids bringing property under their control.\n \n ==Modern Times==\n "
}

Analysis:
Record 147 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision made by the user "Kuban kazak" includes several linguistic indicators that suggest a potential weaponization of cultural heritage. The changes in the "Diff" field reflect a shift in tone and content that aligns with narratives often used to frame cultural and territorial disputes in a specific light.

1. **Terminology and Framing**: The original text refers to the "UOC-MP" (Ukrainian Orthodox Church - Moscow Patriarchate) as a "leftover of Soviet occupation," which is a strong phrase that implies a negative connotation towards this church and its legitimacy. The revision maintains this framing but adds details that emphasize the conflict and the involvement of "nationalist paramilitaries," which can evoke a sense of violence and aggression associated with the Ukrainian side.

2. **Conflict Narrative**: The revision introduces terms like "raids" and "paramilitaries," which suggest a violent struggle over church property. This language can be interpreted as an attempt to portray the situation as one of active conflict, potentially justifying aggressive actions taken by one side against the other.

3. **Historical Context**: The revision emphasizes the historical grievances and the struggle for autocephaly, which can be seen as a way to legitimize current claims and actions by the Ukrainian Orthodox Church against the Russian Orthodox Church. This aligns with narratives that frame the conflict in terms of cultural oppression and the fight for independence.

Overall

Judgment: Weaponised

[[Autocephaly]] refers to the self-governing status of a particular national church that is recognized by other Orthodox jurisdictions. [[Autocephaly]] refers to the self-governing status of a particular national church that is recognized by other Orthodox jurisdictions.  In wake of the break up of the [[Russian Empire]] some national groups also sought ''autonomy'' (Autonomous Orthodox church bodies are not the same as Autocephalic church bodies) from Moscow and an [[Ukranian Autonomous Orthodox Church]] was also founded around this time.  The [[SovietUnion|Soviet]] government persecuted these churches.  The [[Russian Orthodox Church]] also prevented the UAOC from establishing their ecclesiastical order for some time. Between the wars these national churches were tolerated to some extent by the ROC; as the UAOC had entered into communion with Constantinople the Moscow Patriarchate was grudgingly obliged to acknowledge communion with the new Ukranian autocephalic church.\n \n-On [[October 8]], [[1942]] Archbishop Nikanor and Bishop (now Patriarch) Mstyslav of the UAOC and Mitropolit Oleksiy (Hromadsky) of the [[Ukranian Autonomous Orthodox Church]] signed an Act of Union at the [[Pochaev]] [[Lavra]]. Most of the other churches were forced out as the Soviet government only recognized the Moscow Patriarchate, revived at the time of the [[Russian Revolution]], as the only legitimate church in most of the Soviet Union. Many accused it of being a [[puppet]] of the [[Communist Party]].  After the suspicious death of [[Tikhon of Moscow]] these autocephalic churches sought to remain independent; something that Moscow tolerated until after World War Two when many Ukranian Orthodox clergy not affiliated with Moscow fled to [[Germany]] or the [[United States]]. Analysis:
Record 5 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision contains several linguistic indicators that suggest a potential weaponization of cultural heritage. 

1. **Terminology and Framing**: The use of terms like "Nazi occupation authorities" and "pro-Russian hierarchs" frames the historical context in a way that emphasizes conflict and division. This choice of words can evoke strong emotional responses and align with narratives that portray one group as oppressors, which can be used to justify contemporary political stances.

2. **Historical Context**: The revision discusses the persecution of the Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church (UAOC) and the Russian Orthodox Church's role in this persecution. Phrases like "liquidated by the Soviets with the assistance of the Patriarchate of Moscow" imply a direct complicity and ongoing legacy of oppression, which can be weaponized to support current claims of cultural and religious suppression.

3. **Cultural Identity**: The emphasis on "nationalist churches" and the struggle for "autocephaly" highlights the cultural and religious identity of Ukrainians in opposition to Russian influence. This framing can be used to bolster nationalist sentiments and justify actions against perceived threats to Ukrainian heritage.

4. **Emotional Weight**: The mention of executions and concentration camps adds a layer of emotional weight to the narrative, which can be leveraged to invoke sympathy and support for current political movements or actions against Russia.

Overall, the revision subtly shifts the tone and

Judgment: Weaponised
=============================================

All Soviet attempts to pacify the almost-warring church parties were unsuccessful, especially after the UGCC's demand that all property that was held prior to 1939 would be returned (even though some it was Orthodox before the Unia came). It is now believed that the only real event which enabled to contain the schism in the former-uniate territory was the ROC's reaction of raising its Ukrainian Exarchate to the status of an autonomous church, which took place in 1990, and up until the break up of the USSR (late 1991) there was an uneasy peace in western Ukraine. However after the nation became independent, the question of an independent and autocephalous Orthodox Church arose once again and another schism was approaching.\n+In 1988 with the millennium anniversary of the baptism of Rus, there was yet another shift in the Soviet attitude towards religion, coinciding with the Perestroika and Glasnost programmes, the USSR apologized for all repressions towards religion and promised to return all property to the rightful owners. Although what began as a peaceful return of many closed church buildings (of course to the then ROC's Ukrainian Exarchate) in the central, eastern and southern Ukraine (as well as in other parts of the USSR), in the former-uniate regions of western Ukraine it was a different story. As UGCC survived in diaspora and in the underground they took their chance and were immediately revived in Ukraine, where in the wake of the Rukh movements the UOC-MP was viewed as a leftover of Soviet occupation, and bitter, often violent clashes over church buildings followed with the UOC-MP slowly losing its parishes to the UGCC. The UAOC also did not wait long and quickly followed suit. Sometimes possessors of Church buildings changes several times in the space of a couple of days. All Soviet attempts to pacify the almost-warring church parties were useless. It is now believed that the only real event which enabled to contain the schism in the former-uniate territory was the ROC's reaction of raising its Ukrainian Exarchate to the status of an autonomous church, which took place in 1990, and up until the break up of the USSR (late 1991) there was an uneasy peace in western Ukraine. However after the nation became independent, the question of an independent and autocephalous Orthodox Church arose once again and another schism was approaching.\n \n-What historians now see as the reason for the following events was the decision of the head of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church Metropolitan of Kiev and all Ukraine Filaret to achieve total autocephalocy from the Russian Orthodox Church. To achieve that, with active support of the then president Leonid Kravchuk, he covertely organised a communion with the Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church in case Moscow refused. The skeptical hierarchy of the Russian Orthodox Church called for a full council where this issue would have been discussed, upon arrival most of the clergy of the UOC who initially supported Filaret, openely criticised this move and immediately the votes turned against him. In the end the council voted for Filaret to retire from his position which was confirmed by a swore. Upon returning to Kiev however Filaret carried out his reserve option, and Police aided by nationalist Paramilitaries supported him in retaining his rank. The UOC synod was quick to respond and in the eastern city of Kharkov elected a new leader, the Metropolitan Vladimir (Slobodan). From there most of the fate of control of church buildings was decided by the church parishes, but when most refused to follow Filaret, paramilitaries, especially in Volyn and Rovno Oblasts carried out raids bringing property under their control.\n+What historians now see as the reason for the following events was the decision of the head of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church Metropolitan of Kiev and all Ukraine Filaret to achieve total autocephalocy from the Russian Orthodox Church. After the dissolution of the USSR he led a movement for «full canonical independence, namely, autocephaly» for his Church. In November 1991 he headed a working council which requested the hierarchy of the Russian Orthodox Church to grant the Ukrainian Orthodox Church-Moscow Patriarchate autocephalous status. Leonid Kravchuk, then President of Ukraine, supported the request but the Moscow Patriarchate strongly opposed it. Soon afterwards a number of articles appeared in the press accusing Filaret of severe violation of his monastic vows and abuse of his ecclesiastical authority. The Hierarchical Council of the Russian Orthodox Church, which met from March to April 1992, demanded that he leave his position. He promised that he would but, upon his return from Moscow, he announced that the promise was given under pressure and he would not leave. In May 1992 at a Hierarchical Council held in Kharkhiv the majority of the bishops of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church-Moscow Patriarchate voted to depose Metropolitan Filaret from his office and suspend his clerical functioning. Relying on the support of political authorities in Ukraine, Filaret with three other bishops united with the Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church. In June of 1992 they created a new Church, the Ukrainian Orthodox Church-Kyivan Patriarchate (UOC-KP). Though only chosen as assistant to 94-year-old Patriarch Mstyslav, Filaret was actually in control of church affairs. Opposing this situation, some of the Autocephalous bishops and clergy refused to join the Ukrainian Orthodox Church-Kyivan Patriarchate.\n \n ==Modern Times==\n "
}

Analysis:
Record 143 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision made by the user "Yakudza" includes several subtle shifts in language that reflect a potential weaponization of cultural heritage. The comment "POV-cleanup" suggests an attempt to adjust the narrative to align with a specific point of view, which is often a precursor to framing cultural or historical events in a way that serves a particular agenda.

1. **Terminology Changes**: The revision replaces phrases like "Soviet attempts to pacify the almost-warring church parties were unsuccessful" with "Soviet attempts to pacify the almost-warring church parties were useless." The term "useless" carries a more dismissive tone, which could imply a lack of legitimacy to the Soviet efforts, potentially framing the narrative in a way that undermines the historical context of the Soviet Union's actions.

2. **Contextual Framing**: The addition of details regarding the "full canonical independence, namely, autocephaly" for the Ukrainian Orthodox Church and the involvement of political figures like Leonid Kravchuk shifts the focus towards a narrative of national identity and independence. This framing can be seen as an attempt to legitimize the Ukrainian Orthodox Church's separation from the Russian Orthodox Church, which aligns with a broader narrative of Ukrainian sovereignty and cultural heritage.

3. **Conflict Emphasis**: The revision emphasizes the "bitter, often violent clashes over church buildings" and the role of "nationalist Paramilitar

Judgment: Weaponised

}

Analysis:
Record 435 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision introduces several linguistic shifts that indicate a potential weaponization of cultural heritage narratives. 

1. **Use of "illegally"**: The term "illegally" in the context of bishops in the UOC (MP) supporting Viktor Yanukovych adds a legalistic and accusatory tone, framing the actions of these religious leaders in a negative light. This can be seen as an attempt to delegitimize their authority and position within the broader narrative of Ukrainian politics and religion.

2. **Political Sensitivity**: The phrase "Presentely the situation remains extremely politicised and sensitive" suggests a heightened awareness of the political implications surrounding religious affiliations. This framing can be used to justify actions taken against certain groups or to rally support for one side over another, particularly in a context where cultural heritage is intertwined with national identity.

3. **Framing of Controversies**: The revision emphasizes the displeasure of the UOC (MP) regarding the UGCC's administrative move and the involvement of the first lady in fundraising. This can be interpreted as an attempt to highlight divisions within Ukrainian society and the church, potentially weaponizing these divisions to foster a narrative of conflict between different cultural and religious identities.

Overall, the changes in language and emphasis reflect a strategic framing that aligns with narratives of cultural and political conflict, characteristic of weaponized discourse surrounding cultural heritage.

Judgment: Weaponised
=============================================

  "Diff": "--- \n+++ \n@@ -45,9 +45,8 @@\n ===Ornamental and visual art===\n On special occasions, every aspect of ordinary life is transformed into ornamental art form of artistic expression. Ornamentation and design motifs are steeped in symbolism, religious [[ritual]] and meaning. From the [[illuminated manuscripts]] of the [[Peresopnytsia Gospel]] to the famous [[Pysanka|pysanky]] and [[Vytynanky (Wycinanki)|vytynanky]], intricate details have ancient meaning. Much of the oral history was lost during the past 300 years of [[Russification of Ukraine]] when Ukrainian culture and language were forbidden. Organizations like the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]], [[Pysanka Museum]] and the [[Ukrainian Museum]] are dedicated to historic preservation. Different regions of Ukraine have their own traditional ornamentation with their own variation of style and meaning. Examples can be seen in [[Petrykivsky Painting]], ornamental architecture, [[Ukrainian embroidery]], and textile motifs from various [[Ukrainian historical regions]]. \n \n-[[File:Zoloty Vorota Fresca.jpg|thumb|Ornamental art often has a hidden meaning in ancient symbolism]]\n-\n ====Jewelry====\n+[[File:1860 Bryanskiy Portrait-of-Y.Daragan.jpg|thumb|[[Vyshyvanka]] dress. Believing that the Uniate Church's role as an interim bridge between [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodoxy]] and their eventual path to [[Catholicism]] is over, now that the ruler of the lands is no longer a Catholic, but an Orthodox Monarch, he began to push for an eventual reversion of all Uniates. Although the idea was shared by growing number of the lower priests, the ruling Uniate [[synod]], controlled by the strong Polish influence, rejected all Semashko's suggestions. {{fact}} In addition many of the Latin Catholic authorities responded to this by actively converting the Uniates to [[Latin Rite]] Catholicism.\n \n-In 1831, the general discontent of the Poles with the Russian rule erupted into a revolt, now known as the [[November Uprising]], which the Uniate Church officially supported. However, the uprising failed, and the Russian authorities were quick to respond to its organisers and areas of strongest support. The outcome was that the Uniate synod's members were removed along with most of the Polish magnates privileges' and authority being taken away. With the Polish influence in the Ruthenian lands significantly reduced and in some cases eliminated, the Uniate Church began to disintegrate. In [[Volhynia]] the famous [[Pochayiv Lavra]] was returned to Russian Orthodox clergy in 1833. The final blow came from the [[Synod of Polotsk]] in 1839 headed by the ex-Uniate Bishop Semashko, where it was agreed to terminate the accords of [[Union of Brest]] and all of the remaining Uniate property on the territory of the Belarus and Right Bank Ukraine within the [[Russian Empire]] was incorporated into the [[Russian Orthodox Church]]. Those Uniate clergy who refused to join the Russian Orthodox Church (593 out of a total of 1,898 in Ukraine and Belarus) were exiled to the Russian interior or Siberia. <ref> Magocsi, R.P. (1996). The final blow came from the [[Synod of Polotsk]] in 1839 headed by the ex-Uniate Bishop Semashko, where it was agreed to terminate the accords of [[Union of Brest]] and all of the remaining Uniate property on the territory of the Belarus and Right Bank Ukraine within the [[Russian Empire]] was incorporated into the [[Russian Orthodox Church]]. Within Chelm, the conversion to Orthodoxy met with strong resistance from the local ethnic Ukrainian priests and parishioners, and was accomplished largely through the efforts of Russian police, Cossacks, and immigrating [[Ukrainian Russophiles|Russophile]] [[Pope (disambiguation)|priests]] from [[Galicia (Central Europe)|eastern Galicia]].  The resistance was strong enough that when, a generation later in 1905, the formally Orthodox population of Chelm was allowed to return to Catholicism (Russian authorities only allowing conversion to the [[Latin Rite]]), 170,000 out of 450,000 did so by [[1908]].<ref> Himka, John Paul.  (1999). ''Religion and Nationality in Western Ukraine.'' McGill-Queen's University Press: Montreal and Kingston.  Pg. 32 and pp. 58-60. </ref>\n "
}

This subtle shift in focus can serve to downplay the severity of the actions taken against the Uniates and instead emphasize the political and territorial aspects of the historical events.

Legend (recorded in the [[Radziwiłł Chronicle]]) has it that he travelled further still, up the [[Dnieper River]], until he came to the location of present-day Kyiv in AD 55, where he erected a [[cross]] and prophesied the foundation of a great Christian city. Belief in the missionary visit of St. Andrew became widespread by the [[Middle Ages]], and by 1621, a Kyiv synod had declared him the \"Rus'-apostle\".<ref name=\"Wilson\">[[Andrew Wilson (historian)|Wilson, Andrew]] (2000). ''The Ukrainians: Unexpected Nation'', Yale University Press, {{ISBN|0-300-09309-8}}; pages 33-37.</ref> [[Saint Titus]], a disciple of St. Andrew's, is also venerated in Ukrainian churches, as are three \"[[Scythians|Scythian]]\" disciples, Saints Ina, Pina and Rima, who accompanied him to Kyiv.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.byzcath.org/sites/alex/web/All-Kievan-Saints.pdf |title=List of All Kievan Saints |access-date=2013-09-28 |url-status=bot: unknown |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060831210657/http://www.byzcath.org/sites/alex/web/All-Kievan-Saints.pdf |archive-date=August 31, 2006 }} at the [http://www.byzcath.org Byzantine Catholic Church in America]</ref> Both the 18th-century [[St Andrew's Church, Kyiv|Church of St Andrew]] and an earlier structure from 1086 it replaced were purportedly built on the very location of the apostle's cross, planted on a hill overlooking the city of Kyiv.\n+[[Saint Andrew]] the [Twelve apostles|apostle]] is believed to have travelled up the western shores of the [[Black Sea]], to the area of present-day southern Ukraine, while preaching in the lands of [[Scythia]]. ''History of the Ukrainian Church (Історія української церкви)'', Transintekh; p. 12.</ref>\n "
