({{lang-uk|Києво-Печерська лавра|translit=Kyievo-Pecherska lavra}}), also known as the '''Kyiv Monastery of the Caves''', is a historic [[Monastery#Eastern Orthodox|Eastern Orthodox Christian monastery]] which gave its name to [[Pechers’ky Raion|one of the city districts]] where it is located in [[Kyiv]].\n \n Since its foundation as the [[cave monastery]] in 1051, the [[Lavra]] has been a preeminent center of [[Eastern Orthodox Christianity]] in Eastern Europe.<ref>Magocsi P.R. A History of Ukraine. University of Toronto Press: Toronto, 1996. p 98.</ref>\n \n ==Etymology and other names==\n-[[File:Perchersk Lavra, Kyiv Lithograph.jpg|left|thumb|Lithograph of Pechersk Lavra, Kyiv,<ref>[https://www.nga.gov/research/library/imagecollections/features/watsons_russia.html Department of Image Collections]</ref> National Gallery of Art Library, Washington, DC]]\n+[[File:Perchersk Lavra, Kyiv Lithograph.jpg|left|thumb|Lithograph of Pechers`ka Lavra, Kyiv,<ref>[https://www.nga.gov/research/library/imagecollections/features/watsons_russia.html Department of Image Collections]</ref> National Gallery of Art Library, Washington, DC]]\n [[File:Lavra Kyiv.JPG|thumb|Panorama of the monastery (southward view)|left]]\n [[File:Uspensky Sobor.jpg|thumb|The restored Cathedral of the Dormition, as seen in 2005.|left]]\n The word ''pechera'' means ''cave''. The word ''[[lavra]]'' is used to describe high-ranking male monasteries for monks of the Eastern Orthodox Church. Therefore, the name of the monastery is also translated as Kyiv Cave Monastery, Kyiv Caves Monastery or the Kyiv Monastery of the Caves (''на печерах'').{{cn|date=January 2023}}\n@@ -48,7 +48,7 @@\n According to the [[Primary Chronicle]], in the early 11th century, [[Anthony of Kiev|Anthony]], a Christian [[monk]] from [[Esphigmenou Monastery|Esphigmenon monastery]] on [[Mount Athos]], originally from [[Liubech]] of the [[Principality of Chernigov]], returned to [[Kievan Rus'|Rus']] and settled in Kyiv as a [[missionary]] of monastic tradition to Kyivan Rus'. He chose a cave at the Berestov Mount that overlooked the [[Dnieper River]] and a community of disciples soon grew. [[Knyaz|Prince]] [[Iziaslav I of Kiev|Iziaslav I of Kyiv]] ceded the whole mount to the Anthonite monks who founded a monastery built by architects from [[Constantinople]].{{cn|date=January 2023}}\n \n [[File:Kievo-Pecherska Lavra Belltower.jpg|thumb|Up-close view of the [[Great Lavra Belltower]] with its four tiers in 2005.|left]]\n-[[File:Near Caves.jpg|thumb|The [[Near Caves (Pechersk Lavra)|Near Caves]] of the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra. Sketch by the Dutch artist Abraham van Westerveld<!--Q10429035--> made in 1651.|left]]\n+[[File:Near Caves.jpg|thumb|The [[Near Caves (Pechersk Lavra)|Near Caves]] of the Kyiv Pechers`ka Lavra. Sketch by the Dutch artist Abraham van Westerveld<!--Q10429035--> made in 1651.|left]]\n \n === Modern history ===\n Together with the [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kyiv|Saint Sophia Cathedral]], the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra has been inscribed as a [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]] since 1990.<ref name=\"Kyiv Pechersk Lavra, St. Sophia Cathedral remain on UNESCO’s World Heritage List\">[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/kyiv-pechersk-lavra-st-sophia-cathedral-remain-on-unescos-world-heritage-list/ Kyiv Pechersk Lavra, St. Sophia Cathedral remain on UNESCO’s World Heritage List] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130624183743/http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/kyiv-pechersk-lavra-st-sophia-cathedral-remain-on-unescos-world-heritage-list/ |date=24 June 2013 }}, [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (20 June 2013)</ref>{{#tag:ref|Late 2010 a monitoring mission of [[UNESCO]] was visiting the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra to check on situation of the site. At the time the [[Ministry of Culture (Ukraine)|Minister of Culture]] [[Mykhailo Kulynyak]] stated the historic site along with the [[Saint Sophia's Cathedral, Kyiv|Saint Sophia Cathedral]] was not threatened by the \"black list\" of the organisation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mincult.kmu.gov.ua/mincult/uk/publish/article/238820 |title=\"Софії Київській та Києво-Печерській лаврі \"чорний список\" ЮНЕСКО не загрожує\" – Міністр культури Михайло Кулиняк |trans-title=\"Sophia of Kyiv and Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra are not threatened by the UNESCO \"black list\" - Minister of Culture Mykhailo Kulinyak |access-date=23 June 2017 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150711080914/http://mincult.kmu.gov.ua/mincult/uk/publish/article/238820 |archive-date=11 July 2015 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> The [[World Heritage Committee]] of UNESCO decided in June 2013 that Kyiv Pechersk Lavra, and St. Sofia Cathedral and related monastery buildings would remain on the [[World Heritage List]].<ref name=\"Kyiv Pechersk Lavra, St. Sophia Cathedral remain on UNESCO’s World Heritage List\"/>|group=nb}} The monastery complex is considered a separate national historic-cultural preserve (sanctuary), the national status to which was granted on 13 March 1996.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=181/96&p=1260343170231885 |title=Про надання статусу національного Києво-Печерському держав... - від 13.03.1996 № 181/96 |trans-title=On granting the status of national Kyiv-Pechersk State... - dated 03.13.1996 No. 181/96 |website=zakon1.rada.gov.ua |access-date=23 June 2017}}</ref> The Lavra is not only located in another part of the city, but is part of a different national sanctuary than Saint Sophia Cathedral. While being a cultural attraction, the monastery is once again active, with over 100 monks in residence.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} It was named one of the [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine]] on 21 August 2007.{{cn|date=January 2023}}"
}

Analysis:
Record 758 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision made in the "Diff" field reflects a significant shift in the naming convention of the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra to "Kyivo-Pechers’ka Lavra." This change aligns with the Ukrainian government's official English spelling, which is a politically charged term given the ongoing conflict and the emphasis on Ukrainian identity and sovereignty. The user’s comment about removing "unnecessary invalid Russian namings" indicates a deliberate effort to reject Russian influence and assert Ukrainian cultural heritage. 

The phrase "the sources are not related to the topic of Lavra (or its naming)" suggests a dismissal of alternative narratives that may be associated with Russian perspectives, which could be seen as an attempt to control the narrative surrounding the cultural site. This aligns with the broader context of weaponizing cultural heritage, where the naming and representation of cultural sites are used to assert territorial claims and national identity, particularly in the context of the Ukraine-Russia conflict. 

Overall, the linguistic indicators of this revision, including the emphasis on official naming and the rejection of Russian associations, suggest a weaponization of cultural heritage to reinforce national identity and political narratives.

Judgment: Weaponised
=============================================

================= EDIT #29 =================

JSON Record:
{
  "version": "diff",
  "Timestamp": "2005-06-26T21:49:41Z",
  "User": "Dejvid",
  "Comment": "/* Christmas Traditions */  wheat  unlinked",
  "Diff": "--- \n+++ \n@@ -12,7 +12,7 @@\n \n At [[Christmas]] time there is a custom on the night of Christmas Eve to have a 12 course meal, symbolic of the 12 apostles. This custom is practiced by both the Ukrainian Catholic and Orthodox Churches, and is also practiced outside of Ukraine's borders by the people of the Diaspora. This meal is both meatless and dairyless. It usually consists of a few fish dishes (baked fish, pickled herrring), Verenyky, Holobtsi, Kolach (round braided bread), Kutya (cooked wheat with poppies, and honey or sugar - only made in the Christmas season), some mushroom dishes, Garlic, as well as a few others.\n \n-There are also symbolic accompaniments to the meal.  One such example is that the meal starts in the evening as soon as the first star is seen in the sky. This is of course linked to the star that the wise men followed to reach Jesus. There is also a candle in the window to show that anyone wandering the street, that doesn't have a place to go is welcome to join the family for the evening and celebrate. Since this meal is supposed to be just a family affair, for the night the guest is considered an honourary family member. The use of [[wheat]] is also important.  There is usually a sheave of wheat placed in the corner near the table. This is to remind the family of the ancestors that have passed on, and to symbolize their presence at the meal. Also wheat is placed under the tablecloth and under the table. Also, an extra plate is set at the table, this plate is for Jesus, as it is believed he is present at the meal.\n+There are also symbolic accompaniments to the meal.  One such example is that the meal starts in the evening as soon as the first star is seen in the sky. This is of course linked to the star that the wise men followed to reach Jesus. There is also a candle in the window to show that anyone wandering the street, that doesn't have a place to go is welcome to join the family for the evening and celebrate. Since this meal is supposed to be just a family affair, for the night the guest is considered an honourary family member. The use of wheat is also important.  There is usually a sheave of wheat placed in the corner near the table. This is to remind the family of the ancestors that have passed on, and to symbolize their presence at the meal. Also wheat is placed under the tablecloth and under the table. Also, an extra plate is set at the table, this plate is for Jesus, as it is believed he is present at the meal.\n \n [[Carols]] are also an important part of the Christmas tradition. Some carols reach back into the pre-christianity period of Ukraine. The most widely recognizeable Ukrainian Carol is the \"Carol of the Bells\" which is actually not a christmas carol but a New Years carol titled \"Shchedryk\" in Ukrainian. Christmas carols are a tradition that the entire family participates in. In addition, one is only allowed to sing these carols during the Christmas season, and never at any other time.\n [[Category:Ukrainian culture| ]]"
}

================= EDIT #33 =================

JSON Record:
{
  "version": "diff",
  "Timestamp": "2011-05-02T05:52:38Z",
  "User": "Edknol",
  "Comment": "/* Post-war situations */",
  "Diff": "--- \n+++ \n@@ -142,7 +142,7 @@\n On October 8, 1942 Archbishop Nikanor and [[Patriarch Mstyslav (Stepan Skrypnyk)|Bishop Mstyslav]] (later a [[Patriarch]]) of the UAOC and [[Metropolitan Oleksiy (Hromadsky)]] of the [[Ukrainian Autonomous Orthodox Church]] concluded an Act of Union, uniting the two national churches at the Pochayiv Lavra. Later [[Nazi Germany|German]] occupation authorities and pro-Russian hierarchs of the Autonomous Church convinced Metropolitan Oleksiy to remove his signature. Metropolitan Oleksiy was murdered in [[Volhynia]] on May 7, 1943 by the nationalists of the [[Ukrainian Insurgent Army]] which saw this as treason.\n \n ===Post-war situations===\n-The Russian Orthodox Church regained its general monopoly in the [[Ukrainian SSR]] after World War II following another shift in the official Soviet attitude towards Christian churches. As a result many started to accuse it of being a [[puppet]] of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]]. After the suspicious death of Patriarch Tikhon, the UAOC and UGCC sought to avoid the transfer under the Moscow Patriarchate; something that Moscow tolerated until after World War II, for example the head of the Ukrainian Communist Party, [[Nikita Khrushchev]] attended the funeral of the head of the Uniate Church in 1946. Nevertheless as the Uniate Church did in some cases support the Nazi regime, the overall Soviet attitude was negative. In 1948 a small group of priests started to proclaim a reunion with Orthodoxy. The Soviet state organized in 1948 a synod in Lviv, where the 1596 [[Union of Brest]] was annulled. Thereby breaking the canonical ties with [[Catholic see|Rome]] and transferring under the Moscow Patriarchate. In Transcarpathia, the reigning Greek Catholic bishop was murdered [http://www.ewtn.com/library/MARY/theoromz.htm] and the remaining priests were forced to return their Church to Orthodoxy. This move's acceptance was mixed. With many clergy members and lay believers turning to the ROC, some adamantly refused. As a result of this the Patriarchate of Moscow could now legally lay claim to any Orthodox church property that was within the territory of its uncontested jurisdiction, which it did. Some believers refused to accept liquidation of their churches and for nearly 40 years the UAOC and UGCC existed in Western Ukraine underground led by the clergy members under the threat of prosecution by the Soviet state. Much of the UGCC and UAOC clergy not willing to serve in the ROC emigrated to Germany, the United States, or Canada. Others were sent to Siberia and even chose to be martyred [http://www.ugcc.org.ua/eng/press-releases/article;3254/][http://www.risu.org.ua/article.php?l=en&sid=1431]. Officially the Moscow Patriarchate never recognised the canonical right of the synod as it lacked any bishops there.\n+The Russian Orthodox Church regained its general monopoly in the [[Ukrainian SSR]] after World War II following another shift in the official Soviet attitude towards Christian churches. As a result many started to accuse it of being a [[puppet]] of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]]. After the suspicious death of Patriarch Tikhon, the UAOC and UGCC sought to avoid the transfer under the Moscow Patriarchate; something that Moscow tolerated until after World War II, for example the head of the Ukrainian Communist Party, [[Nikita Khrushchev]] attended the funeral of the head of the Uniate Church in 1946. Nevertheless as the Uniate Church did in some cases support the Nazi regime, the overall Soviet attitude was negative. In 1948 a small group of priests started to proclaim a reunion with Orthodoxy. The Soviet state organized in 1948 a synod in Lviv, where the 1596 [[Union of Brest]] was annulled. Thereby breaking the canonical ties with [[Catholic see|Rome]] and transferring under the Moscow Patriarchate. In Transcarpathia, the reigning Greek Catholic bishop, [[Theodore Romzha]], was murdered [http://www.ewtn.com/library/MARY/theoromz.htm] and the remaining priests were forced to return their Church to Orthodoxy. This move's acceptance was mixed. With many clergy members and lay believers turning to the ROC, some adamantly refused. As a result of this the Patriarchate of Moscow could now legally lay claim to any Orthodox church property that was within the territory of its uncontested jurisdiction, which it did. Some believers refused to accept liquidation of their churches and for nearly 40 years the UAOC and UGCC existed in Western Ukraine underground led by the clergy members under the threat of prosecution by the Soviet state. Much of the UGCC and UAOC clergy not willing to serve in the ROC emigrated to Germany, the United States, or Canada. Others were sent to Siberia and even chose to be martyred [http://www.ugcc.org.ua/eng/press-releases/article;3254/][http://www.risu.org.ua/article.php?l=en&sid=1431]. Officially the Moscow Patriarchate never recognised the canonical right of the synod as it lacked any bishops there.\n \n The relatively permissive post-war government attitude towards the Orthodox Church came to an end with Khrushchev's \"Thaw\" programme, which included closing the recently opened Kiev's Caves Lavra. However, in the west-Ukrainian dioceses, which were the largest in the USSR, the Soviet attitude was \"softest\". In fact in the western city of Lviv, only one church was closed. The Moscow Patriarchate also relaxed its canons on the clergy, especially those from the former-uniate territories, allowing them, for example to shave beards (a very uncommon Orthodox practice) and conduct eulogy in Ukrainian instead of [[Church Slavonic]].\n "
}

Analysis:
Record 790 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Not Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision primarily focuses on historical events related to the Russian Orthodox Church and its interactions with Ukrainian religious entities post-World War II. The language used in the "Diff" does not exhibit overtly weaponized narratives or terms that align with the examples provided for either Ukraine's or Russia's perspectives. 

Key points in the text include:
- The mention of the "Russian Orthodox Church" regaining its "general monopoly" and accusations of being a "puppet" of the Communist Party, which reflects historical tensions but does not frame these events in a way that seeks to justify current actions or territorial claims.
- The historical context of the "suspicious death of Patriarch Tikhon" and the subsequent actions of the UAOC and UGCC are presented factually, without emotive language or framing that would suggest a weaponization of cultural heritage.
- The text discusses the forced return of churches to Orthodoxy and the underground existence of the UAOC and UGCC clergy, which are historical facts rather than contemporary narratives aimed at justifying current geopolitical stances.

Overall, while the content addresses sensitive historical issues, it does not employ language that seeks to manipulate cultural heritage for political ends, thus it is categorized as "Not Weaponised."

Judgment: Not Weaponised

================= EDIT #34 =================

JSON Record:
{
  "version": "diff",
  "Timestamp": "2007-02-20T09:40:22Z",
  "User": "Irpen",
  "Comment": "/* A problem with surveys (section break) */",
  "Diff": "--- \n+++ \n@@ -517,7 +517,6 @@\n ;Church Strength in Ukraine\n Research on the denominational configuration of Ukraine today varies so much that it raises questions about validity. However, the problem is not researchers' lack of professionalism, but the lack of firm denominational identity among respondents. Actually, this is not a problem for the Eastern Rite Catholic Church because it consistently accounts for six to eight percent of the adult population of Ukraine in surveys. It is more complicated with Protestants because some surveys do not \"catch\" them at all. For example, Jehovah's Witnesses, some Pentecostals, and even some Baptists do not respond to the name Protestant. Yet, Protestant denominations that have a fixed membership are easy to count. The All-Ukrainian Union of Evangelical Christian-Baptist Church has 130,000 members, the All-Ukrainian Union of Evangelical Christians (Pentecostal) has about 90,000 members, the Ukrainian Union of Seventh-day Adventists has about 40,000 members, and Jehovah's Witnesses have about 107,000 members. The above Protestants, plus members of charismatic and independent churches (excluding Reformed and Lutherans), cannot be more than 600,000 to 700,000. Without question, their influence on religious life is much higher than their numbers would suggest. But the figures shown also undermine the idea of \"Protestant expansion\" in Ukraine. \n \n-\n :How Religious Is Ukraine?\n Results of Survey Research\n \n@@ -589,6 +588,13 @@\n \n :: Again, we do not get \"wildly different\" results, but consistent results from all of the independent, scientific surveys.  The results only become wild if we include results from surveys conducted by religious bodies themselves. These are not the same thing. [[User:Qe2|Qe2]] 09:23, 20 February 2007 (UTC)\n \n+Here are two surveys taken by the same institutions and published at the same site (RISU)\n+:[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;2964/ Survey 1] \n+::UOC - 37.8%, KP - 28.7%, UGCC - 18.6%\n+:[http://www.risu.org.ua/eng/news/article;13940 Survey 2] :\n+::UOC - 20.4%, KP - 30.1%, UGCC - 7.8%, UAOC - 1.5%\n+Are you saying these are not ''wildly'' different results? --[[User:Irpen|Irpen]] 09:40, 20 February 2007 (UTC)\n+\n ==Protection==\n Between the <br>[[http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=History_of_Christianity_in_Ukraine&oldid=107188846 Revision of 19:33 on 10 February 2007]] and today's block, only one citation has remained from the material added before the mass revert. I don't understand the justification for the removal of cited information. Can someone please cite the major issues preventing the improvement of this article? As it stands, the article is inaccurate in my view, and the sooner it gets fixed, the better.--[[User:Tufkaa|tufkaa]] 17:26, 14 February 2007 (UTC)\n :See the discussion above, feel free to comment and raise your issues.--[[User:Kuban kazak|Kuban Cossack]] 21:17, 14 February 2007 (UTC)"

  "Comment": "/* Weaving and embroidery */ fixed reference",
  "Diff": "--- \n+++ \n@@ -102,7 +102,7 @@\n ====Weaving and embroidery====\n Artisan [[textile arts]] play an important role in Ukrainian culture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/Ukrainian-clothes|title=Ukrainian folk dress. Traditional clothes of Ukraine|publisher=Ua-travelling.com|date=13 July 2010|access-date=30 December 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725153343/http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/ukrainian-clothes|archive-date=25 July 2013}}</ref> especially in [[Ukrainian wedding traditions]]. [[Ukrainian embroidery]], [[weaving]], and [[Lace|lace-making]] are used in traditional [[folk dress]] and in traditional celebrations.<ref name=\"UAPOST_Embr\">{{cite web |title=Types and symbols of Ukrainian embroidery ornaments |url=https://uapost.us/en/blog/types-and-symbols-of-ukrainian-embroidery-ornaments/ |website=UAPOST.US |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Ukrainian embroidery varies depending on the region of origin,<ref>''\"Podvyzhnytsi narodnoho mystetstva\", Kyiv 2003 and 2005, by Yevheniya Shudra, Welcome to Ukraine Magazine''</ref> and the designs have a long history of motifs, compositions, choice of colors, and types of stitches.<ref name=museum>{{Cite web |url=http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm |title=Ukrainian Museum Archives. Online exhibit on loan from the D.Dmytrykiw Ukrainian Ethnographic Research Collection, Library & Archives of Westlake, Ohio |access-date=2011-07-04 |archive-date=2009-03-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090324034224/http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm |url-status=dead }}</ref> Use of color is very important and has roots in [[Ukrainian folklore]]. Embroidery motifs found in different parts of Ukraine are preserved in the [[Rushnyk]] Museum in [[Pereiaslav]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Музей українського рушника |url=https://perejaslav.org.ua/places/muzey-ukraynskogo-rushnika.html |website=Переяслав |language=uk}}</ref>\n \n-National dress is woven and highly decorated. [[Weaving]] with handmade looms is still practiced in the village of Krupove, situated in [[Rivne Oblast]]. The village is the birthplace of two famous personalities in the scene of national crafts [[Art fabrication|fabrication]]. Nina Myhailivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rv.gov.ua/sitenew/main/ua/1160.htm |title=Рівненська обласна державна адміністрація – Обласний центр народної творчості |publisher=Rv.gov.ua |access-date=2010-12-30}}</ref> and Uliana Petrivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://storinka-m.kiev.ua/article.php?id=478 |title=ПІСНІ ТА ВИШИВКИ УЛЯНИ КОТ – Мистецька сторінка |publisher=Storinka-m.kiev.ua |access-date=2010-12-30}}</ref> with international recognition. In order to preserve this traditional knowledge, the village is planning to open a local weaving center, museum, and weaving school.<ref name=\"Rivne_Krupove\">{{cite web |title=Weaving and Dumplings |url=https://rivnepost.rv.ua/news/prezentuvali-serpankove-tkatstvo-ta-prihoshchali-hostey-varenikami |website=Rivnepost |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Other centres of embroidery include [[Krolevets]],<ref>{{Cite web |title=Кролевецькі рушники |url=https://lib.knukim.edu.ua/proekti-biblioteki/proekt-skarbi-nacii/krolevecki-rushniki/ |website=Наукова бібліотека КНУКіМ |language=uk}}</ref> [[Reshetylivka]],<ref>{{Cite web |last=Batyrieva |first=Iryna |title=Технологія виконання вишивки «білим по білому» селища Решетилівка Решетилівського району Полтавської області |url=https://authenticukraine.com.ua/blog/tehnologia-vikonanna-visivki-bilim-po-bilomu-dopracovanij |website=Authentic Ukraine |language=uk}}</ref> [[Borshchiv]],<ref>{{Cite web |last=Smirashevska |first=Sofia |date=2023-01-27 |title=Фестиваль «Борщівська вишиванка»: історія створення, цікаві дійства та особливості святкування |url=https://ternopilski.info/uk/eternal-4893-festyval-borshhivska-vyshyvanka-istoriya-stvorennya-czikavi-dijstva-ta-osoblyvosti-svyatkuvannya |website=Ternopilski |language=ui}}</ref> Klembivka,<ref>{{Cite web |last=Tytarenko |first=Volodymyr |title=Орнаментні традиції клембівської вишивки |url=https://www.vocnt.org.ua/statti/klembivska_vishivka |website=Вінницький обласний центр народної творчості |language=uk}}</ref> and [[Yavoriv]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Яворівська вишивка |url=http://yavoriv-rada.eu5.org/vyshyvka.html |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615133354/http://yavoriv-rada.eu5.org/vyshyvka.html |archive-date=2013-06-15 |website=Яворівська міська рада |language=uk}}</ref>\n+National dress is woven and highly decorated. [[Weaving]] with handmade looms is still practiced in the village of Krupove, situated in [[Rivne Oblast]]. The village is the birthplace of two famous personalities in the scene of national crafts [[Art fabrication|fabrication]]. Nina Myhailivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rv.gov.ua/sitenew/main/ua/1160.htm |title=Рівненська обласна державна адміністрація – Обласний центр народної творчості |publisher=Rv.gov.ua |access-date=2010-12-30}}</ref> and Uliana Petrivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://storinka-m.kiev.ua/article.php?id=478 |title=ПІСНІ ТА ВИШИВКИ УЛЯНИ КОТ – Мистецька сторінка |publisher=Storinka-m.kiev.ua |access-date=2010-12-30}}</ref> with international recognition. In order to preserve this traditional knowledge, the village is planning to open a local weaving center, museum, and weaving school.<ref name=\"Rivne_Krupove\">{{cite web |title=Weaving and Dumplings |url=https://rivnepost.rv.ua/news/prezentuvali-serpankove-tkatstvo-ta-prihoshchali-hostey-varenikami |website=Rivnepost |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Other centres of embroidery include [[Krolevets]],<ref>{{Cite web |title=Кролевецькі рушники |url=https://lib.knukim.edu.ua/proekti-biblioteki/proekt-skarbi-nacii/krolevecki-rushniki/ |website=Наукова бібліотека КНУКіМ |language=uk}}</ref> [[Reshetylivka]],<ref>{{Cite web |last=Batyrieva |first=Iryna |title=Технологія виконання вишивки «білим по білому» селища Решетилівка Решетилівського району Полтавської області |url=https://authenticukraine.com.ua/blog/tehnologia-vikonanna-visivki-bilim-po-bilomu-dopracovanij |website=Authentic Ukraine |language=uk}}</ref> [[Borshchiv]],<ref>{{Cite web |last=Smirashevska |first=Sofia |date=2023-01-27 |title=Фестиваль «Борщівська вишиванка»: історія створення, цікаві дійства та особливості святкування |url=https://ternopilski.info/uk/eternal-4893-festyval-borshhivska-vyshyvanka-istoriya-stvorennya-czikavi-dijstva-ta-osoblyvosti-svyatkuvannya |website=Ternopilski |language=uk}}</ref> Klembivka,<ref>{{Cite web |last=Tytarenko |first=Volodymyr |title=Орнаментні традиції клембівської вишивки |url=https://www.vocnt.org.ua/statti/klembivska_vishivka |website=Вінницький обласний центр народної творчості |language=uk}}</ref> and [[Yavoriv]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Яворівська вишивка |url=http://yavoriv-rada.eu5.org/vyshyvka.html |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615133354/http://yavoriv-rada.eu5.org/vyshyvka.html |archive-date=2013-06-15 |website=Яворівська міська рада |language=uk}}</ref>\n \n ===Performance art===\n ====Dance===="

  "User": "USchick",
  "Comment": "/* Weddings */",
  "Diff": "--- \n+++ \n@@ -8,7 +8,7 @@\n \n ====Weddings====\n {{Main|Ukrainian wedding traditions}}\n-Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a celebration (vesillia). The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for a [[ransom]] price for the bride and receive the blessing of the parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being stolen without the groom paying ransom. If the bride refuses the offer of marriage, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message. The official ceremony takes place in a church, often in a group with other couples. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.\n+Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a celebration (vesillia). The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for a [[ransom]] price for the bride and receive the blessing of the parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. If the bride refuses the offer of marriage, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message. The official ceremony takes place in a church, often in a group with other couples. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.\n \n ===Education===\n {{Main|Education in Ukraine}}"
}

{{lang-ru|Киeво-Печерская лавра|translit=Kiyevo-Pecherskaya lavra}}), also known as the '''Kyiv Monastery of the Caves''', is a historic [[Monastery#Orthodox Christian monasteries|Orthodox Christian monastery]] which gave its name to [[Pechers’ky Raion|one of the city districts]] where it is located in [[Kyiv]].\n \n Since its foundation as the [[cave monastery]] in 1051,<ref>Magocsi P.R. A History of Ukraine. University of Toronto Press: Toronto, 1996. p 98.</ref> the Lavra has been a preeminent center of [[Eastern Orthodox Christianity]] in Eastern Europe. Together with the [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kyiv|Saint Sophia Cathedral]], it is inscribed as a [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]].<ref name=\"Kyiv Pechersk Lavra, St. Sophia Cathedral remain on UNESCO’s World Heritage List\">[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/kyiv-pechersk-lavra-st-sophia-cathedral-remain-on-unescos-world-heritage-list/ Kyiv Pechersk Lavra, St. Sophia Cathedral remain on UNESCO’s World Heritage List], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (20 June 2013)</ref>{{#tag:ref|Late 2010 a monitoring mission of [[UNESCO]] was visiting the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra to check on situation of the site. At the time the [[Ministry of Culture (Ukraine)|Minister of Culture]] [[Mykhailo Kulynyak]] stated the historic site along with the [[Saint Sophia's Cathedral, Kyiv|Saint Sophia Cathedral]] was not threatened by the \"black list\" of the organization.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mincult.kmu.gov.ua/mincult/uk/publish/article/238820|title=\"Софії Київській та Києво-Печерській лаврі \"чорний список\" ЮНЕСКО не загрожує\" – Міністр культури Михайло Кулиняк|accessdate=23 June 2017|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150711080914/http://mincult.kmu.gov.ua/mincult/uk/publish/article/238820|archivedate=11 July 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The [[World Heritage Committee]] of UNESCO decided in June 2013 that Kyiv Pechersk Lavra, and St. Sofia Cathedral and related monastery buildings would remain on the [[World Heritage List]].<ref name=\"Kyiv Pechersk Lavra, St. Sophia Cathedral remain on UNESCO’s World Heritage List\"/>|group=nb}} The monastery complex is considered a separate national historic-cultural preserve (sanctuary), the national status to which was granted on 13 March 1996.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=181/96&p=1260343170231885|title=Про надання статусу національного Києво-Печерському держав... -  від 13.03.1996 № 181/96|website=zakon1.rada.gov.ua|accessdate=23 June 2017}}</ref> The Lavra is not only located in another part of the city, but is part of a different national sanctuary than Saint Sophia Cathedral. While being a cultural attraction, the monastery is once again active, with over 100 monks in residence.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} It was named one of the [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine]] on 21 August 2007, based on voting by experts and the internet community.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}\n "

================= EDIT #41 =================

JSON Record:
{
  "version": "diff",
  "Timestamp": "2011-03-04T12:11:19Z",
  "User": "John of Reading",
  "Comment": "[[WP:AWB/T|Typo]] and [[WP:AWB/GF|General fixing]], replaced: lead by → led by using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]",
  "Diff": "--- \n+++ \n@@ -142,7 +142,7 @@\n On October 8, 1942 Archbishop Nikanor and [[Patriarch Mstyslav (Stepan Skrypnyk)|Bishop Mstyslav]] (later a [[Patriarch]]) of the UAOC and [[Metropolitan Oleksiy (Hromadsky)]] of the [[Ukrainian Autonomous Orthodox Church]] concluded an Act of Union, uniting the two national churches at the Pochayiv Lavra. Later [[Nazi Germany|German]] occupation authorities and pro-Russian hierarchs of the Autonomous Church convinced Metropolitan Oleksiy to remove his signature. Metropolitan Oleksiy was murdered in [[Volhynia]] on May 7, 1943 by the nationalists of the [[Ukrainian Insurgent Army]] which saw this as treason.\n \n ===Post-war situations===\n-The Russian Orthodox Church regained its general monopoly in the [[Ukrainian SSR]] after World War II following another shift in the official Soviet attitude towards Christian churches. As a result many started to accuse it of being a [[puppet]] of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]]. After the suspicious death of Patriarch Tikhon, the UAOC and UGCC sought to avoid the transfer under the Moscow Patriarchate; something that Moscow tolerated until after World War II, for example the head of the Ukrainian Communist Party, [[Nikita Khrushchev]] attended the funeral of the head of the Uniate Church in 1946. Nevertheless as the Uniate Church did in some cases support the Nazi regime, the overall Soviet attitude was negative. In 1948 a small group of priests started to proclaim a reunion with Orthodoxy. The Soviet state organized in 1948 a synod in Lviv, where the 1596 [[Union of Brest]] was annulled. Thereby breaking the canonical ties with [[Catholic see|Rome]] and transferring under the Moscow Patriarchate. In Transcarpathia, the reigning Greek Catholic bishop was murdered [http://www.ewtn.com/library/MARY/theoromz.htm] and the remaining priests were forced to return their Church to Orthodoxy. This move's acceptance was mixed. With many clergy members and lay believers turning to the ROC, some adamantly refused. As a result of this the Patriarchate of Moscow could now legally lay claim to any Orthodox church property that was within the territory of its uncontested jurisdiction, which it did. Some believers refused to accept liquidation of their churches and for nearly 40 years the UAOC and UGCC existed in Western Ukraine underground lead by the clergy members under the threat of prosecution by the Soviet state. Much of the UGCC and UAOC clergy not willing to serve in the ROC emigrated to Germany, the United States, or Canada. Others were sent to Siberia and even chose to be martyred [http://www.ugcc.org.ua/eng/press-releases/article;3254/][http://www.risu.org.ua/article.php?l=en&sid=1431]. Officially the Moscow Patriarchate never recognised the canonical right of the synod as it lacked any bishops there.\n+The Russian Orthodox Church regained its general monopoly in the [[Ukrainian SSR]] after World War II following another shift in the official Soviet attitude towards Christian churches. As a result many started to accuse it of being a [[puppet]] of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]]. After the suspicious death of Patriarch Tikhon, the UAOC and UGCC sought to avoid the transfer under the Moscow Patriarchate; something that Moscow tolerated until after World War II, for example the head of the Ukrainian Communist Party, [[Nikita Khrushchev]] attended the funeral of the head of the Uniate Church in 1946. Nevertheless as the Uniate Church did in some cases support the Nazi regime, the overall Soviet attitude was negative. In 1948 a small group of priests started to proclaim a reunion with Orthodoxy. The Soviet state organized in 1948 a synod in Lviv, where the 1596 [[Union of Brest]] was annulled. Thereby breaking the canonical ties with [[Catholic see|Rome]] and transferring under the Moscow Patriarchate. In Transcarpathia, the reigning Greek Catholic bishop was murdered [http://www.ewtn.com/library/MARY/theoromz.htm] and the remaining priests were forced to return their Church to Orthodoxy. This move's acceptance was mixed. With many clergy members and lay believers turning to the ROC, some adamantly refused. As a result of this the Patriarchate of Moscow could now legally lay claim to any Orthodox church property that was within the territory of its uncontested jurisdiction, which it did. Some believers refused to accept liquidation of their churches and for nearly 40 years the UAOC and UGCC existed in Western Ukraine underground led by the clergy members under the threat of prosecution by the Soviet state. Much of the UGCC and UAOC clergy not willing to serve in the ROC emigrated to Germany, the United States, or Canada. Others were sent to Siberia and even chose to be martyred [http://www.ugcc.org.ua/eng/press-releases/article;3254/][http://www.risu.org.ua/article.php?l=en&sid=1431]. Officially the Moscow Patriarchate never recognised the canonical right of the synod as it lacked any bishops there.\n \n The relatively permissive post-war government attitude towards the Orthodox Church came to an end with Khrushchev's \"Thaw\" programme, which included closing the recently opened Kiev's Caves Lavra. However, in the west-Ukrainian dioceses, which were the largest in the USSR, the Soviet attitude was \"softest\". In fact in the western city of Lviv, only one church was closed. The Moscow Patriarchate also relaxed its canons on the clergy, especially those from the former-uniate territories, allowing them, for example to shave beards (a very uncommon Orthodox practice) and conduct eulogy in Ukrainian instead of [[Church Slavonic]].\n \n@@ -202,6 +202,7 @@\n \n ===Catholic Church===\n {{main|Roman Catholicism in Ukraine}}\n+\n ====Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church====\n {{main|Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church}}\n "
}

The original temple was built in the 12th century and no drawings or visual depictions of it remain. The second temple was built at the time of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] and was disassembled by the Russian authorities in the 19th century. It was replaced with the current temple, often referred to as the Refectory Church of the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra.{{cn|date=January 2023}}\n "

Record 850 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision contains several linguistic indicators that suggest a weaponization of cultural heritage. Notably, the phrase "the destruction of the cathedral followed a pattern of Soviet disregard for cultural heritage" implies a deliberate and systematic attack on cultural sites by the Soviet Union, framing the narrative in a way that emphasizes victimization and cultural loss. This aligns with the weaponization narrative of cultural oppression, particularly from a Ukrainian perspective.

Additionally, the mention of "the controversial 1941 Khreshchatyk explosions" and the tactics of "scorched earth" used by Soviet troops during their withdrawal further reinforces a narrative of destruction and disregard for cultural heritage. The historical context provided, including the destruction of the ancient St. Michael's Golden-Domed Monastery, serves to highlight a perceived ongoing threat to Ukrainian cultural identity and heritage.

The overall tone of the revision leans towards a condemnation of Soviet actions, which can be interpreted as an attempt to frame historical events in a way that justifies current cultural and territorial claims. This aligns with the examples of weaponization terms provided, particularly those that emphasize cultural oppression and destruction.

Legend (recorded in the [[Radziwiłł Chronicle]]) has it that he traveled further still, up the [[Dnieper River]], until he came to the location of present-day [[Kyiv]] in AD 55, where he erected a [[cross]] and prophesied the foundation of a great Christian city. Belief in the missionary visit of St. Andrew became widespread by the [[Middle Ages]], and by 1621, a Kyiv synod had declared him the \"Rus'-apostle\".<ref name=\"Wilson\">[[Andrew Wilson (historian)|Wilson, Andrew]] (2000). ''History of the Ukrainian Church (Історія української церкви)'', Transintekh; p. 12.</ref>\n \n@@ -47,7 +47,7 @@\n Following the [[Rus'-Byzantine War (860)|860 assault on Constantinople]] by Rus' forces under the command of [[Askold and Dir]], the two princes were baptized in that holy city. Returning to Kyiv, the two actively championed Christianity for a period of 20 years, until they were murdered by the [[pagan]] [[Oleg of Novgorod|Prince Oleg]] in the inter-princely rivalry for the Kyiv throne. [[Ecumenical Patriarch Photios I of Constantinople|Patriarch Photios]] purportedly provided a bishop and priests from [[Constantinople]] to help in the [[Christianization]] of the Slavs.<ref>Chirovsky, Nicholas (1981). ''Ancient and Kievan-Galician Ukraine-Rus'', Philosophical Library; page 216.</ref> By 900, a church was already established in Kyiv, St. Elijah's, modeled on a church of the same name in Constantinople. This gradual acceptance of Christianity is most notable in the [[Rus'-Byzantine Treaty (945)|Rus'-Byzantine Treaty]] of 945, which was signed by both \"baptized\" and unbaptized Rus'\", according to the text included in the [[Primary Chronicle]].\n \n ===Establishment of the Kyiv Metropolitan===\n-Christianity acceptance among the Rus' nobility gained a vital proponent when [[Princess Olga]], the ruler of [[Kyiv]], became baptized, taking the \"[[Given name|Christian name]]\" ''Helen''. Her baptism in 955 (or 957) in either Kyiv or Constantinople (accounts differ) was a turning point in religious life of Rus' but it was left to her grandson, [[Vladimir the Great]], to make Kyivan Rus a Christian state. Both Vladimir and Olga are venerated as the [[Equal-to-apostles|Equal-to-apostles saints]] by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]].\n+Christianity acceptance among the Rus' nobility gained a vital proponent when [[Princess Olga]], the ruler of Kyiv, became baptized, taking the \"[[Given name|Christian name]]\" ''Helen''. Her baptism in 955 (or 957) in either Kyiv or Constantinople (accounts differ) was a turning point in religious life of Rus' but it was left to her grandson, [[Vladimir the Great]], to make Kyivan Rus a Christian state. Both Vladimir and Olga are venerated as the [[Equal-to-apostles|Equal-to-apostles saints]] by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]].\n \n Princess [[Olga of Kyiv]] shortly after her baptism appealed to the [[Holy Roman Empire|Holy Roman emperor]] [[Otto I the Great|Otto the Great]] to send missionaries into Kyivan Rus. [[Adalbert (Archbishop of Magdeburg)|Saint Adalbert]], a [[Latin Church|Latin]] missionary bishop from Germany, was sent, but his missions and the priests who missionized along with him, were stopped. In the following years, the bishops of [[Volodymyr-Volynskyy]] and [[Przemyśl]] and the Metropolitan of Kyiv announced their secession from the Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople, which was increasingly influenced by the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottomans]]. In 1595 some representatives of this group arrived to Rome and asked [[Pope Clement VIII]] to take them under his jurisdiction and unite them to the [[Holy See|Apostolic See of Saint Peter]].\n \n In the [[Union of Brest]] of 1596 (colloquially known as ''unia''), a part of the Ukrainian Church was accepted under the jurisdiction of the Roman Pope, becoming a [[Byzantine Rite]] [[Eastern Catholic Churches|Catholic Church]], a Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church, colloquially known as the Uniate Church. While the new church gained many faithful among the [[Ukrainians]] in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]], the majority of Ukrainians in the rest of the lands remained within [[Eastern Orthodoxy]] with the church affairs ruled by then from Kyiv under the metropolitan [[Petro Mohyla]]. The Orthodox Church was made illegal (its legality was partially restored in 1607), its property confiscated, and Orthodox believers faced persecution and discrimination which became an important reason for large numbers of Ukrainians to emigrate to Tsardom of Russia following the Union.<ref>Magocsi, R.P. (1996). ''A History of Ukraine''. Toronto: University of Toronto Press. {{ISBN|0-8020-7820-6}} Pg. 169 and 211</ref> The eastward spread of the Union of Brest led to violent clashes, for example, assassination of the Greek Catholic [[Archbishop]] [[Josaphat Kuntsevych]] by the Orthodox mob in [[Vitebsk]] in 1623.\n "

[[User:Kevlar67|Kevlar67]] 05:57, 8 February 2007 (UTC)\n \n-==Religiousity and national self-identity connection==\n-While I added this info to the article a while ago, I would like to, perhaps, clear up certain misunderstanding that I see in recent edits. The connection was very strong indeed but it belongs to a history rather than modernity. At the time of the Polish controle up to the 17th-18th century, being a Ukrainian largely meant being an Orthodox and converion to Catholicism meant usually a complete abandonment of Ukrainianness. Practically it was equivalent to becoming a Pole (see [[Polonization#Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]] and [http://www.kulichki.com/inkwell/text/special/history/kostom/kostom22.htm Ostrozhsky] section of [[Kostomarov]]'s history.) \n-\n-Another historic period where the connection was very strong is the [[interbellum]] where in the Polish control Western Ukraine, the Greek Catholic church, which under the previous century of the Austrian rule has attained a  strong Ukrainian national character was a strong unifyinf force that prevented the Ukrainians from assimilation (see [[Polonization#Second Polish Republic]] and, eg. Snyder's \"Reconstruction of Nations\" ISBN 0-300-10586-X). However, in the modern times, the religion's role in the Ukrainian self-identity is not as significant. A significant portion of Ukrainians is non-religious and many have been attracted by the proseletysm of different Western Churches whose activity in the country is very significant in the last 20 years. Nevertheless, there is no indication that those people have lost their Ukrainian self-identification by being non-Orthodox and non-Greek Catholic. So, let's make sure that the article emphasizes the connection as the historical only rather than the modern. --[[User:Irpen|Irpen]] 22:54, 8 February 2007 (UTC)\n \n \n ==\"Red Army Liberation\" v. \"Soviet Occupation\"=="
}

Analysis:
Record 290 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:** The revision comment by the user "Irpen" indicates a deliberate effort to frame the historical connection between religiosity and national self-identity in a specific light. The phrase "let's make sure that the article emphasizes the connection as the historical only rather than the modern" suggests an intention to downplay contemporary relevance and potentially dismiss current identities that diverge from traditional narratives. This aligns with the weaponization of cultural heritage by reinforcing a historical narrative that may serve to legitimize certain political or cultural claims, particularly in the context of Ukrainian identity. The removal of detailed historical context regarding the role of religion in Ukrainian self-identity further indicates an attempt to simplify and control the narrative, which can be seen as a form of cultural manipulation.

Judgment: Weaponised
=============================================

At the time the [[Ministry of Culture (Ukraine)|Minister of Culture]] [[Mykhailo Kulynyak]] stated the historic site along with the [[Saint Sophia's Cathedral, Kiev|Saint Sophia Cathedral]] was not threatened by the \"black list\" of the organization.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mincult.kmu.gov.ua/mincult/uk/publish/article/238820|title=«Софії Київській та Києво-Печерській лаврі «чорний список» ЮНЕСКО не загрожує» – Міністр культури Михайло Кулиняк|publisher=|accessdate=23 June 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150711080914/http://mincult.kmu.gov.ua/mincult/uk/publish/article/238820|archivedate=11 July 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The [[World Heritage Committee]] of UNESCO decided in June 2013 that Kiev Pechersk Lavra, and St. Sofia Cathedral and related monastery buildings would remain on the [[World Heritage List]].<ref name=\"Kyiv Pechersk Lavra, St. Sophia Cathedral remain on UNESCO’s World Heritage List\"/>|group=nb}} The monastery complex is considered a separate national historic-cultural preserve (sanctuary), the national status to which was granted on 13 March 1996.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=181/96&p=1260343170231885|title=Про надання статусу національного Києво-Печерському держав... -  від 13.03.1996 № 181/96|website=zakon1.rada.gov.ua|accessdate=23 June 2017}}</ref> The Lavra is not only located in another part of the city, but is part of a different national sanctuary than Saint Sophia Cathedral. While being a cultural attraction, the monastery is once again active, with over 100 monks in residence.{{fact|date=May 2017}} It was named one of the [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine]] on 21 August 2007, based on voting by experts and the internet community.{{fact|date=May 2017}}\n-\n-Currently, the jurisdiction over the site is divided between the state museum, National Kiev-Pechersk Historic-Cultural Preserve,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kplavra.kiev.ua/#|title=Сайт Національного Києво-Печерського історико-культурного заповідника|website=www.kplavra.kiev.ua|accessdate=23 June 2017}}</ref> and the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] as the site of the chief monastery of that Church and the residence of its leader, [[Onuphrius (Berezovsky)|Metropolitan Onuphrius]].\n+'''Kyiv Pechersk Lavra''' or '''Kiev Pechersk Lavra'''<ref>[http://www.rada.gov.ua/ukraine.htm Verkhovna Rada Portal] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727035555/http://www.rada.gov.ua/ukraine.htm |date=27 July 2011 }} This is the official English spelling used by the Ukrainian government</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/city/detail/69789/  Parliament votes down law on preservation of Kyiv Pechersk Lavra complex] Interfax-Ukraine, 16 June 2010 at 10:42</ref>({{lang-uk|Києво-Печерська лавра}}: ''Kyievo-Pechers'ka lavra'', {{lang-ru|link=no|Киeво-Печерская лавра}}: ''Kyivo-Pecherskaya lavra''), also known as the '''Kyiv Monastery of the Caves''', is a historic [[Monastery#Orthodox Christian monasteries|Orthodox Christian monastery]] which gave its name to [[Pechersk Raion|one of the city districts]] where it is located in [[Kyiv]].\n+\n+Since its foundation as the [[cave monastery]] in 1051<ref>[Magocsi P.R. While being a cultural attraction, the monastery is once again active, with over 100 monks in residence.{{fact|date=May 2017}} It was named one of the [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine]] on 21 August 2007, based on voting by experts and the internet community.{{fact|date=May 2017}}\n+\n+Currently, the jurisdiction over the site is divided between the state museum, National Kyiv-Pechersk Historic-Cultural Preserve,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kplavra.Kyiv.ua/#|title=Сайт Національного Києво-Печерського історико-культурного заповідника|website=www.kplavra.Kyiv.ua|accessdate=23 June 2017}}</ref> and the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] as the site of the chief monastery of that Church and the residence of its leader, [[Onuphrius (Berezovsky)|Metropolitan Onuphrius]].\n \n ==Etymology and other names==\n [[File:Lavra Kyiv.JPG|thumb|Panorama of the monastery (southward view)]]\n [[Image:Uspensky Sobor.jpg|thumb|right|225px|The reconstructed Cathedral of the Dormition, as seen in 2005.]]\n-The word ''pechera'' means ''cave''. The word ''[[lavra]]'' is used to describe high-ranking male monasteries for monks of the Eastern Orthodox Church. Therefore, the name of the monastery is also translated as '''Kiev Cave Monastery''', '''Kiev Caves Monastery''' or the '''Kiev Monastery of the Caves''' (''на печерах'').\n+The word ''pechera'' means ''cave''. The word ''[[lavra]]'' is used to describe high-ranking male monasteries for monks of the Eastern Orthodox Church. Therefore, the name of the monastery is also translated as '''Kyiv Cave Monastery''', '''Kyiv Caves Monastery''' or the '''Kyiv Monastery of the Caves''' (''на печерах'').\n \n ==Foundation and early history==\n-According to the [[Primary Chronicle]], in the early 11th century, [[Saint Anthony of Kiev|Anthony]], an [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox]] [[monk]] from [[Esphigmenou Monastery|Esphigmenon monastery]] on [[Mount Athos]], originally from [[Liubech]] of the [[Principality of Chernigov|Principality of Chernihiv]], returned to [[Kievan Rus'|Rus']] and settled in Kiev as a [[missionary]] of monastic tradition to Kievan Rus'. He chose a cave at the Berestov Mount that overlooked the [[Dnieper River]] and a community of disciples soon grew. [[Knyaz|Prince]] [[Iziaslav I of Kiev]] ceded the whole mount to the Antonite monks who founded a monastery built by architects from [[Constantinople]].\n-\n-[[Image:Kievo-Pecherska Lavra Belltower.jpg|thumb|right|225px|Up-close view of the ''[[Great Lavra Belltower]]'' with its four tiers in 2005.]]\n-\n-[[Image:Near Caves.jpg|thumb|right|225px|The ''[[Near Caves (Pechersk Lavra)|Near Caves]]'' of the Kiev Pechersk Lavra. Sketch by the Dutch artist [[Abraham van Westerveldt]] made in 1651.]]\n+According to the [[Primary Chronicle]], in the early 11th century, [[Saint Anthony of Kyiv|Anthony]], an [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox]] [[monk]] from [[Esphigmenou Monastery|Esphigmenon monastery]] on [[Mount Athos]], originally from [[Liubech]] of the [[Principality of Chernigov|Principality of Chernihiv]], returned to [[Kyivan Rus'|Rus']] and settled in Kyiv as a [[missionary]] of monastic tradition to Kyivan Rus'. He chose a cave at the Berestov Mount that overlooked the [[Dnieper River]] and a community of disciples soon grew. [[Knyaz|Prince]] [[Iziaslav I of Kyiv]] ceded the whole mount to the Antonite monks who founded a monastery built by architects from [[Constantinople]].\n+\n+[[Image:Kyivo-Pecherska Lavra Belltower.jpg|thumb|right|225px|Up-close view of the ''[[Great Lavra Belltower]]'' with its four tiers in 2005.]]\n+\n+[[Image:Near Caves.jpg|thumb|right|225px|The ''[[Near Caves (Pechersk Lavra)|Near Caves]]'' of the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra. The main attractions of the Lavra include ''[[Great Lavra Belltower]]'', the notable feature of the Kiev skyline, and the ''[[Cathedral of the Dormition (Pechersk Lavra)|Dormition Cathedral]],'' destroyed in [[World War II]], and fully reconstructed in recent years. Other churches and cathedrals of the Lavra include: the [[Refectory Church (Pechersk Lavra)|Refectory Church]], the Church of All Saints, the [[Church of the Saviour at Berestove]], the Church of the Exaltation of Cross, the Church of the Trinity, the Church of the Nativity of the Virgin, the Church of the Conception of St. Anne, and the Church of the Life-Giving Spring. The Lavra also contains many other constructions, including: the St. Nicholas Monastery, the Kiev Theological Academy and Seminary, and the Debosquette Wall.\n+The Kyiv Pechersk Lavra contains numerous architectural monuments, ranging from [[bell tower]]s to cathedrals to cave systems and to strong stone [[Lavra fortification|fortification walls]]. The main attractions of the Lavra include ''[[Great Lavra Belltower]]'', the notable feature of the Kyiv skyline, and the ''[[Cathedral of the Dormition (Pechersk Lavra)|Dormition Cathedral]],'' destroyed in [[World War II]], and fully reconstructed in recent years. Other churches and cathedrals of the Lavra include: the [[Refectory Church (Pechersk Lavra)|Refectory Church]], the Church of All Saints, the [[Church of the Saviour at Berestove]], the Church of the Exaltation of Cross, the Church of the Trinity, the Church of the Nativity of the Virgin, the Church of the Conception of St. Anne, and the Church of the Life-Giving Spring. The Lavra also contains many other constructions, including: the St. Nicholas Monastery, the Kyiv Theological Academy and Seminary, and the Debosquette Wall.\n \n ===Great Lavra Belltower===\n {{main|Great Lavra Belltower}}\n \n-The Great Lavra Belltower is one of the most notable features of the Kiev skyline and among the main attractions of the Lavra. 96.5 meters in height, it was the tallest free-standing belltower at the time of its construction in 1731–1745, and was designed by the architect Johann Gottfried Schädel. It is a [[Classical architecture|Classical style]] construction and consists of [[storey|tier]]s, surmounted by a [[gilding|gilded]] [[dome]].\n+The Great Lavra Belltower is one of the most notable features of the Kyiv skyline and among the main attractions of the Lavra. 96.5 meters in height, it was the tallest free-standing belltower at the time of its construction in 1731–1745, and was designed by the architect Johann Gottfried Schädel. It is a [[Classical architecture|Classical style]] construction and consists of [[storey|tier]]s, surmounted by a [[gilding|gilded]] [[dome]].\n \n ===Dormition Cathedral===\n [[File:Успенський собор - Catedral de la ASuncion 2.jpg|thumb|Restored Dormition Church]]\n-Built in the 11th century, the main church of the monastery was destroyed during the [[World War II]] couple of months after the Nazi Germany troops occupied the city of [[Kiev]] and the controversial [[1941 Khreshchatyk explosions]] that destroyed the city's main street. According to the Soviet authorities, the temple was destroyed by the advancing German troops, while at the same time German authorities hanged the blame onto the withdrawing Soviet troops who did practiced the tactics of [[scorched earth]] and blew up all the Kiev bridges over [[Dnieper]] as well as being accused in the 1941 Khreshchatyk explosions.\n+Built in the 11th century, the main church of the monastery was destroyed during the [[World War II]] couple of months after the Nazi Germany troops occupied the city of [[Kyiv]] and the controversial [[1941 Khreshchatyk explosions]] that destroyed the city's main street. According to the Soviet authorities, the temple was destroyed by the advancing German troops, while at the same time German authorities hanged the blame onto the withdrawing Soviet troops who did practiced the tactics of [[scorched earth]] and blew up all the Kyiv bridges over [[Dnieper]] as well as being accused in the 1941 Khreshchatyk explosions.\n \n It should be noted that since 1928 the monastery was converted into a museum park by the Soviet authorities and after its return no efforts were provided to restore the church. The temple was finally restored in 1995 after Ukraine obtained its independence and the construction was accomplished in two years. The new Dormition Church was consecrated in 2000.\n \n ===Gate Church of the Trinity===\n {{main|Gate Church of the Trinity (Pechersk Lavra)}}\n \n-The Gate Church of the Trinity is located atop the ''Holy Gates'', which houses the entrance to the monastery. According to a legend, this church was founded by the [[Chernihiv]] [[Rulers of Kievan Rus'|Prince]] [[Sviatoslav II of Kiev|Sviatoslav II]]. It was built atop an [[Architecture of Kievan Rus'|ancient stone church]] which used to stand in its place.\n+The Gate Church of the Trinity is located atop the ''Holy Gates'', which houses the entrance to the monastery. According to a legend, this church was founded by the [[Chernihiv]] [[Rulers of Kyivan Rus'|Prince]] [[Sviatoslav II of Kyiv|Sviatoslav II]]. It was built atop an [[Architecture of Kyivan Rus'|ancient stone church]] which used to stand in its place.\n After the fire of 1718 the church was rebuilt, its revered facades and interior walls enriched with ornate stucco work made by master craftsman V. Stefaovych.\n In the 18th century a new gilded pear-shaped dome was built, the facade and exterior walls were decorated with stucco-moulded plant ornaments and a vestibule built of stone attached to the north end. In the early 20th century the fronts and the walls flanking the entrance were painted by icon painters under the guidance of V. Sonin.\n The interior of the Gate Trinity Church with murals by the early 18th century painter Alimpy Galik is of great artistic value.\n@@ -265,7 +265,7 @@\n ===Refectory chambers with Church of the Saints Anthony and Theodosius===\n {{main|Refectory Church (Pechersk Lavra)}}\n [[File:Trapezna lavra.jpg|thumb|Refectory Church|right]]\n-The refectory chambers with the Church of the Saints Anthony and Theodosius is the third in a series of temples. The original temple was built in the 12th century and no drawings or visual depictions of it remain. The second temple was built at the time of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] and was disassembled by the Russian authorities in the 19th century. It was replaced with the current temple, often referred to as the Refectory Church of the Kiev Pechersk Lavra.\n+The refectory chambers with the Church of the Saints Anthony and Theodosius is the third in a series of temples. The original temple was built in the 12th century and no drawings or visual depictions of it remain. The second temple was built at the time of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] and was disassembled by the Russian authorities in the 19th century. It was replaced with the current temple, often referred to as the Refectory Church of the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra.\n \n ===The All Saints Church===\n The All Saints Church erected in 1696–1698 is a fine specimen of Ukrainian baroque architecture. Characteristic of the church facades are rich architectural embellishments. In 1905 students of the Lavra art school painted the interior walls of the church. The carved wooden iconostasis is multi-tiered and was made for the All Saints church in the early 18th century.\n@@ -274,14 +274,14 @@\n {{main|Church of the Saviour at Berestove}}\n [[Image:Church of the Saviour at Berestove (Side view).jpg|thumb|left|225px|Side view of the ''[[Church of the Saviour at Berestove]]'' seen with its [[campanile]], designed by architect Andrei Melenskyi in the [[Classical architecture|Classical style]].]]\n \n-The Church of the Saviour at Berestove is located to the North of the Kiev Pechersk Lavra. It was constructed in the village of Berestove around the start of the 11th century during the reign of Prince [[Vladimir II Monomakh|Volodymyr Monomakh]]. It later served as the mausoleum of the Monomakh dynasty, also including [[Yuri Dolgoruki]], the founder of Moscow. Despite being outside the Lavra fortifications, the Church of the Saviour at Berestove is part of the Kiev Pechersk Lavra complex.\n+The Church of the Saviour at Berestove is located to the North of the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra. It was constructed in the village of Berestove around the start of the 11th century during the reign of Prince [[Vladimir II Monomakh|Volodymyr Monomakh]]. It later served as the mausoleum of the Monomakh dynasty, also including [[Yuri Dolgoruki]], the founder of Moscow. Despite being outside the Lavra fortifications, the Church of the Saviour at Berestove is part of the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra complex.\n \n ===Caves===\n {{main|Near Caves}}\n-[[Image:Iliya Muromets Kiev.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Imperishable relic of saint [[Ilya Muromets]] in Kiev Pechersk Lavra]] \n-The Kiev Pechersk Lavra caverns are a very complex system of narrow underground corridors (''about 1-1½ metres wide and 2-2½ metres high''), along with numerous living quarters and underground chapels. In 1051, the monk [[Saint Anthony of Kiev|Anthony]] settled in an old cave in a hill near the Kiev Pechersk Lavra. This cave received additions including corridors and a church, and is now what we know as the ''[[Far Caves]]''. In 1057, Anthony moved to a cave near the ''Upper Lavra'', now called the ''[[Near Caves]]''.\n-\n-Foreign travellers in the 16th–17th centuries wrote that the catacombs of the Lavra stretched for hundreds of kilometres, reaching as far as Moscow and [[Velikiy Novgorod|Novgorod]],<ref name=\"Touring Kyiv\">{{cite book | first=Ruta | last=Malikenaite | year=2003 | title=Guidebook: Touring Kyiv | publisher=Baltia Druk | location=Kiev | isbn=966-96041-3-3}}</ref> spreading awareness of the Kiev Pechersk Lavra.\n+[[Image:Iliya Muromets Kyiv.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Imperishable relic of saint [[Ilya Muromets]] in Kyiv Pechersk Lavra]] \n+The Kyiv Pechersk Lavra caverns are a very complex system of narrow underground corridors (''about 1-1½ metres wide and 2-2½ metres high''), along with numerous living quarters and underground chapels. In 1051, the monk [[Saint Anthony of Kyiv|Anthony]] settled in an old cave in a hill near the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra. This cave received additions including corridors and a church, and is now what we know as the ''[[Far Caves]]''. In 1057, Anthony moved to a cave near the ''Upper Lavra'', now called the ''[[Near Caves]]''.\n+\n+Foreign travellers in the 16th–17th centuries wrote that the catacombs of the Lavra stretched for hundreds of kilometres, reaching as far as Moscow and [[Velikiy Novgorod|Novgorod]],<ref name=\"Touring Kyiv\">{{cite book | first=Ruta | last=Malikenaite | year=2003 | title=Guidebook: Touring Kyiv | publisher=Baltia Druk | location=Kyiv | isbn=966-96041-3-3}}</ref> spreading awareness of the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra.\n \n ==Burials==\n [[Image:Надгробок Костянтина However, after the fall of the Soviet Union, the bodies were covered with a cloth and to this day remain in the same state. {{Citation needed|date=January 2008}}.\n \n ==Museum==\n-[[File:Orthodox pilgrim.jpg|thumb|200px|Orthodox pilgrim in Kiev Pechersk Lavra – women must cover their head when entering Lavra.]]\n-The Kiev Pechersk Lavra is one of the largest museums in Kiev. The exposition is the actual ensemble of the Upper (''[[Near Caves]]'') and Lower (''[[Far Caves]]'') Lavra territories, which house many architectural relics of the past. The collection within the churches and caves includes articles of precious metal, prints, higher clergy portraits and rare church hierarchy photographs. The main exposition contains articles from 16th to early 20th centuries, which include [[chalice (cup)|chalice]]s, [[crucifix]]es, and textiles from 16th–19th centuries, with needlework and [[embroidery]] of Ukrainian masters. The remainder of the collection consists of pieces from the Lavra's Printing House and the Lavra's Icon Painting Workshop.<ref name=\"Kyiv Sightseeing Guide\">{{cite book | year=2001 | title=Kyiv Sightseeing Guide | publisher=Centre d'Europe | location=Kiev/Lviv | isbn=966-7022-29-3}}</ref>\n+[[File:Orthodox pilgrim.jpg|thumb|200px|Orthodox pilgrim in Kyiv Pechersk Lavra – women must cover their head when entering Lavra.]]\n+The Kyiv Pechersk Lavra is one of the largest museums in Kyiv. The exposition is the actual ensemble of the Upper (''[[Near Caves]]'') and Lower (''[[Far Caves]]'') Lavra territories, which house many architectural relics of the past. The collection within the churches and caves includes articles of precious metal, prints, higher clergy portraits and rare church hierarchy photographs. The main exposition contains articles from 16th to early 20th centuries, which include [[chalice (cup)|chalice]]s, [[crucifix]]es, and textiles from 16th–19th centuries, with needlework and [[embroidery]] of Ukrainian masters. The remainder of the collection consists of pieces from the Lavra's Printing House and the Lavra's Icon Painting Workshop.<ref name=\"Kyiv Sightseeing Guide\">{{cite book | year=2001 | title=Kyiv Sightseeing Guide | publisher=Centre d'Europe | location=Kyiv/Lviv | isbn=966-7022-29-3}}</ref>\n The museum provides tours of the [[catacombs]], which contain remains of Orthodox saints or their relics. The Caves are of geological interest because they are excavated into [[loess]] ground. They form one of the most extensive occurrences of loess caves in the world.\n \n The Lavra museums include:\n@@ -328,7 +328,7 @@\n Вид на Києво-Печерську Лавру.jpg\n Різдва Analysis:
Record 517 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision reflects a significant shift in the spelling of "Kiev" to "Kyiv" throughout the text. This change is not merely a matter of orthography; it aligns with a broader narrative of asserting Ukrainian identity and sovereignty, particularly in the context of the ongoing geopolitical tensions between Ukraine and Russia. The use of "Kyiv" is the official Ukrainian spelling and is often employed to emphasize Ukraine's independence and cultural heritage, contrasting with the Russian-influenced "Kiev."

Specific linguistic indicators include:
- The consistent replacement of "Kiev" with "Kyiv" in various contexts, such as "Kyiv Pechersk Lavra," "Kyiv skyline," and "Kyiv Arsenal." This reflects a conscious effort to promote the Ukrainian perspective and assert cultural ownership.
- The mention of the "Ukrainian government" in relation to the official English spelling further underscores the political implications of this revision.

Overall, the changes in the text serve to reinforce a narrative of Ukrainian cultural heritage and identity, which can be seen as a form of weaponization in the context of the ongoing conflict and cultural disputes between Ukraine and Russia.

Judgment: Weaponised
=============================================

The change from "Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)" to "Orthodox Church of Ukraine" is indicative of a broader narrative surrounding the control and legitimacy of cultural heritage in the context of the ongoing conflict between Ukraine and Russia.

The use of the term "controlled" also carries implications of conflict and dominance, which can further polarize the narrative surrounding the cultural site. This linguistic choice can be seen as an attempt to legitimize the authority of the Orthodox Church of Ukraine while delegitimizing the previous affiliation with the Moscow Patriarchate, which is often viewed in the context of Russian cultural and political influence.

Men often hold the door open for a woman when she enters a building, stand up when a woman enters the room, and, if there is a shortage of seats, men will give up their seats to the women. In rural areas, men will sometimes kiss a woman's hand, but this is starting to go out of fashion."

[[Nazi]] occupation authorities and pro-Russian hierarchs of the Autonomous Church forced Metropolitan Oleksiy to remove his signature.  Metropolitan Oleksiy was executed in [[Volhynia]] on [[May 7]], [[1943]].\n \n-The Russian Orthodox Church regained its general monopoly in the [[Ukrainian SSR]] after [[World War II]]. Most of the other churches were forced out as the Soviet government only recognized the Moscow Patriarchate, revived at the time of the [[Russian Revolution]], as the only legitimate church in most of the Soviet Union.  Many accused it of being a [[puppet]] of the [[Communist Party]].  After the suspicious death of [[Tikhon of Moscow]] these autocephalic churches sought to remain independent; something that Moscow tolerated until after World War II when many Ukrainian Orthodox clergy not affiliated with Moscow fled to [[Germany]], the [[United States]], or [[Canada]]. The UAOC and UGCC and their church property in Ukraine were liquidated by the Soviets with the assistance of the Patriarchate of Moscow, which could legally lay claim to any Orthodox church property that was within the territory of its uncontested jurisdiction.  Any UAOC hierarchs or clergy who remained in Ukraine and refused to join the Russian Church were executed or sent to [[gulag|concentration camps]]. In the next several years, similar actions were taken against the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] in Western Ukraine and [[Transcarpathia]].\n+The Russian Orthodox Church regained its general monopoly in the [[Ukrainian SSR]] after [[World War II]].  Many accused it of being a [[puppet]] of the [[Communist Party]].  After the suspicious death of [[Tikhon of Moscow]] these autocephalic churches sought to remain independent; something that Moscow tolerated until after World War II when many Ukrainian Orthodox clergy not affiliated with Moscow fled to [[Germany]], the [[United States]], or [[Canada]]. The UAOC and UGCC and their church property in Ukraine were liquidated by the Soviets with the assistance of the Patriarchate of Moscow, which could legally lay claim to any Orthodox church property that was within the territory of its uncontested jurisdiction.  Any UAOC hierarchs or clergy who remained in Ukraine and refused to join the Russian Church were executed or sent to [[gulag|concentration camps]]. In the next several years, similar actions were taken against the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] in Western Ukraine and [[Transcarpathia]].\n \n == External links ==\n *[http://www.orthodox.org.ua/ Ukrainian Orthodox Church - Moscow Patriarchy] "

**Judgment: Weaponised**

The revision made by the user "Fisenko" includes a comment that emphasizes the suffering of the Russian Orthodox Church compared to other church bodies, stating it was "almost wiped out and suffered more than any other." This language subtly shifts the narrative to frame the Russian Orthodox Church as a victim, which can be seen as an attempt to invoke sympathy and justify its historical actions and claims to legitimacy in Ukraine.

The use of terms like "almost wiped out" and "suffered more than any other" serves to elevate the status of the Russian Orthodox Church while potentially downplaying the historical context of its actions during the Soviet era, including its role in the suppression of other religious groups. This framing can be interpreted as an effort to weaponize cultural heritage by positioning the Russian Orthodox Church as a martyr in the context of its historical narrative, which aligns with the broader Russian perspective on cultural and territorial claims in Ukraine. 

Additionally, the removal of the term "revived" in the context of the church's history suggests a deliberate attempt to reshape the narrative around the church's legitimacy and its historical continuity, further indicating a weaponization of cultural heritage.

They are not identical. Ukrainian culture is the result of creativity of all Ukrainians (even that groups and communities where live abroad). Culture of Ukraine includes masterpieces of representatives of other nations and cultures, but they existed and created on the territory of our state (Ukraine) or the Crimean peninsula. For example, the mosk (DjumaOdjami) in Evpatoria was designed by Hoca Mimar Sinan (? –1588), the famous Ottoman architect.'' If so, it probably is not a culture of Ukraine: ''Culture of Ukraine includes masterpieces of representatives of other nations and cultures, but they existed and created on the territory of our state (Ukraine)''.{{pb}}{{tq|1=, or a \"Ukrainian culture\" outside Ukraine that is distinct from Ukrainian culture inside Ukraine}}<br>It must not be distinct. In fact, the opposite is true: sources on Ukrainian culture abroad describe how the same Ukrainian culture is spread and preserved by Ukrainians living abroad: [https://ruor.uottawa.ca/items/7a5980fb-c051-4459-8b4c-7cc4da01c359 Ukrainian cultural traditions in Canada: Theatre, choral music and dance, 1891-1967. They have attempted to mold themselves by means of their own cultural traditions, as a separate ethnic entity, possessing their own innate values and distinct cultural characteristics.'' Analysis:

The Museum of Folk Architecture and Way of Life of Central [[Naddnipryanshchyna]] is located in [[Pereiaslav-Khmelnytskyi]]. The open air museum contains 13 theme museums, 122 examples of national architecture, and over 30,000 historical cultural objects. The Museum of Decorative Finishes is one of the featured museums that preserves the handiwork of decorative architectural applications in [[Ukrainian architecture]]. Decorative finishes use ancient traditional design patterns.\n \n ===Ornamental and visual art===\n+[[File:Hnizdovsky Rizdvo2.gif|thumbnail|[[Christmas in Ukraine|Christmas]] card by [[Jacques Hnizdovsky]]]]\n On special occasions, every aspect of ordinary life is transformed into ornamental art form of artistic expression. Ornamentation and design motifs are steeped in symbolism, religious [[ritual]] and meaning. From the [[illuminated manuscripts]] of the [[Peresopnytsia Gospel]] to the famous [[Pysanka|pysanky]] and [[Vytynanky (Wycinanki)|vytynanky]], intricate details have ancient meaning. Much of the oral history was lost during the past 300 years of [[Russification of Ukraine]] when Ukrainian culture and language were forbidden. Organizations like the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]], [[Pysanka Museum]] and the [[Ukrainian Museum]] are dedicated to historic preservation. Different regions of Ukraine have their own traditional ornamentation with their own variation of style and meaning. Examples can be seen in [[Petrykivsky Painting]], ornamental architecture, [[Ukrainian embroidery]], and textile motifs from various [[Ukrainian historical regions]]. \n \n ====Jewelry===="
}

Analysis:
Record 590 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision introduces several linguistic indicators that suggest a weaponization of cultural heritage. Notably, the phrase "Russification of Ukraine" is a charged term that implies a historical narrative of oppression and cultural erasure, which aligns with the Ukrainian perspective on the conflict. This term is used to frame the loss of oral history and cultural identity as a direct consequence of external aggression, thus reinforcing a narrative of victimhood and cultural preservation.

Additionally, the mention of organizations like the "Ivan Honchar Museum" and the "Pysanka Museum" dedicated to historic preservation serves to highlight the importance of Ukrainian cultural heritage in the face of perceived threats. The emphasis on "traditional ornamentation" and "intricate details" with "ancient meaning" further romanticizes and elevates Ukrainian culture, potentially positioning it as something that needs to be defended against external forces.

Overall, the language shifts towards a narrative that not only celebrates Ukrainian cultural heritage but also frames it within a context of struggle against historical oppression, which can be seen as a form of cultural weaponization.
