  "Diff": "--- \n+++ \n@@ -90,7 +90,7 @@\n \n Nevertheless the first [[Russophilia|Russophile]] tendencies began to surface, and came in face of the Uniate Bishop [[Joseph Semashko]]. Believing that the Uniate Church's role as an interim bridge between [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodoxy]] and their eventual path to [[Catholicism]] is over, now that the ruler of the lands is no longer a Catholic, but an Orthodox Monarch, he began to push for an eventual reversion of all Uniates. Although the idea was shared by growing number of the lower priests, the ruling Uniate [[synod]], controlled by the strong Polish influence, rejected all Semashko's suggestions. <ref> [http://www.pravoslavie.ru/arhiv/050513111111.htm#rel1 Воссоединение униатов и исторические судьбы белорусского народа] </ref> In addition many of the Latin Catholic authorities responded to this by actively converting the Uniates to [[Latin Rite]] Catholicism.\n \n-In 1831, the general discontent of the Poles with the Russian rule erupted into a revolt, now known as the [[November Uprising]], which the Uniate Church officially supported. However, the uprising failed, and the Russian authorities were quick to respond to its organisers and areas of strongest support. The outcome was that the Uniate synod's members were removed along with most of the Polish magnates privileges' and authority being taken away. With the Polish influence in the Ruthenian lands significantly reduced and in some cases eliminated, the Uniate Church began to disintegrate. In [[Volhynia]] the famous [[Pochayiv Lavra]] was returned to Russian Orthodox clergy in 1833. The final blow came from the [[Synod of Polotsk]] in 1839 headed by the ex-Uniate Bishop Semashko, where it was agreed to terminate the accords of [[Union of Brest]] and all of the remaining Uniate property on the territory of the Belarus and Right Bank Ukraine within the [[Russian Empire]] was incorporated into the [[Russian Orthodox Church]]. Those Uniate clergy who refused to join the Russian Orthodox Church (593 out of a total of 1,898 in Ukraine and Belarus) were exiled to the Russian interior or Siberia. <ref> Magocsi, R.P. (1996).  ''A History of Ukraine''.  Toronto: University of Toronto Press. ISBN 0-8020-7820-6 Pg. 375 </ref> By means of mass deportations, persecution and even executions the Uniates were practically eliminated in the Russian Empire. Only a small number of Greek Catholics in the Kholm Governorate managed to preserve their faith.<ref name=\"autogenerated3\" />     \n+In 1831, the general discontent of the Poles with the Russian rule erupted into a revolt, now known as the [[November Uprising]], which the Uniate Church officially supported. The outcome was that the Uniate synod's members were removed along with most of the Polish magnates privileges' and authority being taken away. In [[Volhynia]] the famous [[Pochayiv Lavra]] was returned to Russian Orthodox clergy in 1833. The final blow came from the [[Synod of Polotsk]] in 1839 headed by the ex-Uniate Bishop Semashko, where it was agreed to terminate the accords of [[Union of Brest]] and all of the remaining Uniate property on the territory of the Belarus and Right Bank Ukraine within the [[Russian Empire]] was incorporated into the [[Russian Orthodox Church]]. Within Chelm, the conversion to Orthodoxy met with strong resistance from the local ethnic Ukrainian priests and parishioners, and was accomplished largely through the efforts of Russian police, Cossacks, and immigrating [[Ukrainian Russophiles|Russophile]] [[Pope (disambiguation)|priests]] from [[Galicia (Central Europe)|eastern Galicia]].  The resistance was strong enough that when, a generation later in 1905, the formally Orthodox population of Chelm was allowed to return to Catholicism (Russian authorities only allowing conversion to the [[Latin Rite]]), 170,000 out of 450,000 did so by [[1908]].<ref> Himka, John Paul.  (1999). ''Religion and Nationality in Western Ukraine.'' McGill-Queen's University Press: Montreal and Kingston.  Pg. 32 and pp. 58-60. </ref>\n "
}

Since its foundation as the [[cave monastery]] in 1015<ref>[Magocsi P.R. A History of Ukraine. University of Toronto Press: Toronto, 1996. p 98.]</ref> the Lavra has been a preeminent center of the [[Eastern Orthodox Christianity]] in [[Eastern Europe]]. Together with the [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev|Saint-Sophia Cathedral]], it is inscribed as a [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]]. \n+'''Kiev Pechersk Lavra''' ({{lang-uk|Києво-Печерська лавра, ''Kyievo-Pechers’ka lavra''}}; {{lang-ru|Киево-Печерская лавра, ''Kievo-Pecherskaya lavra''}}), also known as the '''Kiev Monastery of the Caves''', is a historic [[Monastery#Orthodox Christian monasteries|Orthodox Christian monastery]] in [[Kiev]], [[Ukraine]]. Since its foundation as the [[cave monastery]] in 1015<ref>[Magocsi P.R. A History of Ukraine. University of Toronto Press: Toronto, 1996. p 98.]</ref> the Lavra has been a preeminent center of the [[Eastern Orthodox Christianity]] in [[Eastern Europe]]. Together with the [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev|Saint-Sophia Cathedral]], it is inscribed as a [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]]. It was named one of the [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine]] on [[August 21]], [[2007]], based on voting by experts and the internet community.\n+\n \n Currently, the jurisdiction over the site is divided between the state museum, National Kyiv-Pechersk Historic-Cultural Preserve<ref>[http://www.kplavra.kiev.ua/#]</ref>, and the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchy)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church]] as the site of the chief monastery of that Church and the residence of its leader, [[Metropolitan Volodymyr (Viktor Sabodan)|Metropolitan Volodymyr]].\n \n@@ -69,18 +70,12 @@\n * [[Ivan Iskra]] - near the [[Refectory Church (Pechersk Lavra)|Refectory Church]] (1708)\n * [[Pyotr Stolypin]] - near the [[Refectory Church (Pechersk Lavra)|Refectory Church]] (1911)\n \n+During the Soviet times, the bodies of the mummified saints that lay in the caves were left uncovered due to the regime's disregard for religion. However, after the fall of the Soviet Union, the bodes were covered with a cloth and to this day remain in the same state {{Fact|date=January 2008}}.  \n+\n ==Museum==\n The Kiev Pechersk Lavra is also one of the largest Ukrainian museums in Kiev. The exposition is the actual ensemble of the Upper (''[[Near Caves]]'') and Lower (''[[Far Caves]]'') Lavra territories that houses more than 100 architectural relics of the past. The collection within the churches and caves include articles of precious metal, prints, higher clergy portraits and rare church hierarchy photographs. The main exposition contains articles from 16 to early 20th centuries which include [[chalice]]s, [[crucifix]]es, and [[textile]]s from 16-19th centuries with needlework and [[embroidery]] of Ukrainian masters. The remainder of collection consists of pieces from Lavra's Printing House and Lavra's Icon Painting Workshop.\n <ref name=\"Kyiv Sightseeing Guide\">{{cite book | year=2001 | title=Kyiv Sightseeing Guide | publisher=Centre d'Europe | location=Kyiv/Lviv | isbn=966-7022-29-3}}</ref>\n The museum also provides tours to the [[catacombs]], which contain mummified remains of Orthodox saints or their relics.\n-\n-==Trivia==\n-{{Trivia|date=March 2008}}\n-The Embassy of Italy was located, from 1994 to 1999 in the territory of the Lavra, within the portion then belonging to the Ukrainian State, after the renewal of the building hosting the ancient baths.\n-\n-During the Soviet times, the bodies of the mummified saints that lay in the caves were left uncovered due to the regime's disregard for religion. However, after the fall of the Soviet Union, the bodes were covered with a cloth and to this day remain in the same state {{Fact|date=January 2008}}.  \n-\n-The Kiev Pechersk Lavra was named one of the [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine]] on [[August 21]], [[2007]], based on voting by experts and the internet community.\n \n ==See also==\n *[[Near Caves]]"

In a recent survey only 33.3% of the people felt satisfied with the current condition of several Orthodox Churches. At the same time up to 42.1% felt it would be important for a single united church, with 30.7% favoring the UOC-KP and 11.4% the UOC (MP).   "Diff": "--- \n+++ \n@@ -75,7 +75,6 @@\n In the [[Union of Brest]] of 1596 (colloquially known as ''unia''), a part of the Ukrainian Church was accepted under the jurisdiction of the Roman Pope, becoming a [[Byzantine Rite]] [[Eastern Catholic Churches|Catholic Church]], a Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church, colloquially known as the Uniate Church. While the new church gained many faithful among the [[Ukrainians]] in [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]], the majority of Ukrainians in the rest of the lands remained within [[Eastern Orthodoxy]] with the church affairs ruled by then from Kiev under the metropolitan [[Peter Mogila]] ''(Petro Mohyla)''. The Orthodox Church was made illegal (its legality was partially restored in 1607), its property confiscated, and Orthodox believers faced persecution and discrimination which became an important reason for large numbers of Ukrainians to emigrate to Tsardom of Russia following the Union.<ref>Magocsi, R.P. (1996). ''A History of Ukraine''. Toronto: University of Toronto Press. ISBN 0-8020-7820-6 Pg. 169 and 211</ref> The eastward spread of the Union of Brest led to violent clashes, for example, assassination of the Greek Catholic [[Metropolitan bishop|metropolitan]] [[Josaphat Kuntsevych]] by the Orthodox mob in [[Polotsk]] in 1623.\n \n ===Khmelnytsky Uprising===\n-[[File:Saint Sophia Cathedral.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The cradle of Ukrainian Orthodoxy: [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev]]]]\n {{Main|Khmelnytsky Uprising}}\n \n As the ''unia'' continued its expansion into Ukraine, its unpopularity grew, particularly in the southern [[steppe]]s where [[Dnieper Cossacks]] lived. The Cossacks valued their traditions and culture saw the ''unia'' as a final step of [[Polonization]]. As a result they reacted by becoming fierce proponents of Orthodoxy. Such feelings played a role in the [[Khmelnytsky Uprising|mass uprising]] whose targets included all non-Orthodox religious proponents, the Catholic and Uniate clergy and Jews. During this time metropolitan [[Peter Mogila|Mogila]] took full advantage of the moment to restore the Orthodox domination in Ukraine, including returning one of its sacred buildings, the [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev]]."
}

Analysis:
Record 889 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision introduces a narrative that emphasizes the conflict between Orthodox and non-Orthodox groups during the Khmelnytsky Uprising, framing it as a reaction against perceived cultural and religious imposition (specifically the "unia" and Polonization). The phrase "fierce proponents of Orthodoxy" suggests a strong, almost militant defense of cultural identity, which can be interpreted as a rallying cry for Orthodox Ukrainians against external influences. 

Additionally, the mention of "targets included all non-Orthodox religious proponents, the Catholic and Uniate clergy and Jews" highlights a violent aspect of the uprising, which can be weaponized to frame the conflict in terms of cultural survival versus oppression. This aligns with the narratives of cultural oppression and defense of heritage, which are often used in contemporary discussions surrounding the historical context of Ukraine and its religious affiliations. 

The overall tone shifts towards a more confrontational stance, which can be seen as an attempt to justify historical grievances and present the Orthodox Church as a bastion of Ukrainian identity against foreign influence, thus weaponizing the cultural heritage narrative.

Returning to Kiev, the two actively championed Christianity for a period of 20 years, until they were murdered by the [[pagan]] [[Oleg of Novgorod|Prince Oleg]] in the inter-princely rivalry for the Kiev throne. [[Ecumenical Patriarch Photios I of Constantinople|Patriarch Photios]] purportedly provided a bishop and priests from [[Constantinople]] to help in the [[Christianization]] of the Slavs.<ref>Chirovsky, Nicholas (1981). ''Ancient and Kievan-Galician Ukraine-Rus'', Philosophical Library; page 216.</ref> By 900, a [[church]] was already established in Kiev, St. Elijah's, modeled on a church of the same name in Constantinople. This gradual acceptance of Christianity is most notable in the [[Rus'-Byzantine Treaty (945)|Rus'-Byzantine Treaty]] of 945, which was signed by both \"baptized\" and unbaptized Rus'\", according to the text included in the [[Primary Chronicle]]."

  "Diff": "--- \n+++ \n@@ -81,7 +81,7 @@\n ===Czechoslovakia===\n The redrawal of national boundaries following [[World War I]] also affected yet another ethnically Ruthenian territory. In [[1918]], the country of [[Czechoslovakia]] was formed, the nation included several minorities. In the easternmost end of the country, [[Transcarpathia]] lived the [[Rusyn]] population. For most of their history they were ruiled by the Hungarians, who unlike the Austrians ruling [[Galicia]] were quite active in opposing Ukrainophile sentiments.  Instead, the Hungarians supported a Rusyn identity (separate from either a pro-Ukrainian or pro-Russian orientation) through pro-Hungarian priests in an effort to separate the Ruthenian people under their rule from their brethren across the mountains.<ref name=Subtelny>{{cite book| author=Subtelny, O. | title=Ukraine: A History| location= Toronto | publisher= University of Toronto Press | year = 1988| }}</ref>  Thus despite being Uniate at the time of the formation of Czechoslovakia, the population was about evenly divided between Rusynophile, Ukrainophile and Russophile orientation.  The general Russophilic sentiment was very strong amongst them, and these cultural and political orientation impacted the local religious communities.  Even before the first world war already quite a lot of distant mountain communities were de facto Orthodox, where priests simply ceased to follow the Uniate canons. However, much more significant changes took place in the interwar period. \n \n-In the [[1920]]s many Russian emigres, particularly Orthodox clergy, settled in [[Serbia]]. Loyal to the Orthodox state, they became actively involved in missionary work in central Europe. A group, headed by Bishop Dosifei went to Transcarpathia. Because of the historical links between the local Greek Catholic clergy to the disliked Hungarian authorites, mass conversions to the Orthodox Church occurred. By the start of the [[Second World War]], approximately one third of all of the [[Rusyn]] population reverted to Orthodoxy [http://www.rusyn.org/?root=rusyns&rusyns=religion&article=94].  The region's local Hungarian population, estimated at slightly less than 20% of the population, remained overhwlemingly Calvinist or Roman Catholic. (For the Ruthenian population left outside Ukraine in 1945 (Preshov territory in Slovakia) see [[Czech and Slovak Orthodox Church]])\n \n ===Second World War===\n \n@@ -92,7 +92,7 @@\n On [[October 8]], [[1942]] Archbishop Nikanor and Bishop Mstyslav (later a [[Patriarch]]) of the UAOC and Metropolitan Oleksiy (Hromadsky) of the Ukrainian Autonomous Orthodox Church concluded an [[Act of Union]], uniting the two national churches at the [[Pochayiv Lavra]]. Later [[Nazi Germany|German]] occupation authorities and pro-Russian hierarchs of the Autonomous Church convinced Metropolitan Oleksiy to remove his signature. Metropolitan Oleksiy was murdered in [[Volhynia]] on [[May 7]], [[1943]] by the nationalists of the [[Ukrainian Insurgent Army]] which saw this as treason.\n \n ===Post War Situations===\n-The Russian Orthodox Church regained its general monopoly in the [[Ukrainian SSR]] after [[World War II]] following another shift in the official Soviet attitude towards Christian churches. As a result many started to accuse it of being a [[puppet]] of the [[Communist Party]]. After the suspicious death of Patriarch Tikhon, the UAOC and UGCC sought to avoid the transfer under the Moscow Patriarchy; something that Moscow tolerated until after World War II, for example the head of the Ukrainian Communist Party, [[Nikita Khruschev]] attended the funeral of the head of the Uniate Church in [[1946]]. Nevertheless as the Uniate Church did in some cases support the Nazi regime, the overall Soviet attitude was negative. In [[1948]] a small group of priests started to proclaim a reunion with Orthodoxy. The Soviet state organized in [[1948]] a synod in [[Lviv]], where the [[1596]] [[Union of Brest]] was annuled. Thereby breaking the canonical ties with [[Catholic see|Rome]] and transferring under the Moscow Patriarchy. In Transcarpathia, the reigning Greek Catholic bishop was murdered[http://www.ewtn.com/library/MARY/theoromz.htm] and the remaining priests were forced to return their Church to Orthodoxy.  This move's acceptance was mixed. With many clergy members and lay believers turning to the ROC, some adamantly refused. As a result of this the Patriarchate of Moscow could now legally lay claim to any Orthodox church property that was within the territory of its uncontested jurisdiction, which it did. Some believers refused to accept liquidation of their churches and for nearly 40 years the UAOC and UGCC existed in Western Ukraine underground lead by the clergy members under the threat of prosecution by the Soviet state. Much of the UGCC and UAOC clergy not willing to serve in the ROC emigrated to [[Germany]], the [[United States]], or [[Canada]]. Others were sent to Siberia and even chose to be martyred [http://www.ugcc.org.ua/eng/press-releases/article;3254/][http://www.risu.org.ua/article.php?l=en&sid=1431].    Officially the Moscow Patriarchate never recognised the cannonical right of the synod as it lacked any bishops there. \n+The Russian Orthodox Church regained its general monopoly in the [[Ukrainian SSR]] after [[World War II]] following another shift in the official Soviet attitude towards Christian churches. As a result many started to accuse it of being a [[puppet]] of the [[Communist Party]]. After the suspicious death of Patriarch Tikhon, the UAOC and UGCC sought to avoid the transfer under the Moscow Patriarchy; something that Moscow tolerated until after World War II, for example the head of the Ukrainian Communist Party, [[Nikita Khruschev]] attended the funeral of the head of the Uniate Church in [[1946]]. Nevertheless as the Uniate Church did in some cases support the Nazi regime, the overall Soviet attitude was negative. In [[1948]] a small group of priests started to proclaim a reunion with Orthodoxy. The Soviet state organized in [[1948]] a synod in [[Lviv]], where the [[1596]] [[Union of Brest]] was annulled. Thereby breaking the canonical ties with [[Catholic see|Rome]] and transferring under the Moscow Patriarchy. In Transcarpathia, the reigning Greek Catholic bishop was murdered[http://www.ewtn.com/library/MARY/theoromz.htm] and the remaining priests were forced to return their Church to Orthodoxy.  This move's acceptance was mixed. With many clergy members and lay believers turning to the ROC, some adamantly refused. As a result of this the Patriarchate of Moscow could now legally lay claim to any Orthodox church property that was within the territory of its uncontested jurisdiction, which it did. Some believers refused to accept liquidation of their churches and for nearly 40 years the UAOC and UGCC existed in Western Ukraine underground lead by the clergy members under the threat of prosecution by the Soviet state. Much of the UGCC and UAOC clergy not willing to serve in the ROC emigrated to [[Germany]], the [[United States]], or [[Canada]]. Others were sent to Siberia and even chose to be martyred [http://www.ugcc.org.ua/eng/press-releases/article;3254/][http://www.risu.org.ua/article.php?l=en&sid=1431].    Officially the Moscow Patriarchate never recognised the canonical right of the synod as it lacked any bishops there. \n \n The relatively permissive post-war government attitude towards the Orthodox Church came to an end with [[Nikita Khruschev]]'s \"Thaw\" programme, which included closing the recently opened Kiev's Caves Lavra. However in the west-Ukrainian dioceses, which were the largest in the USSR, the Soviet attitude was \"softest\". In fact in the western city of Lviv, only one church was closed. The Moscow patriarchy also relaxed its canons on the clergy, especially those from the former-uniate territories, allowing them, for example to shave beards (a very uncommon Orthodox practice) and conduct liturgy in Ukrainian instead of Slavonic.\n "
}

This can serve to reinforce a dominant narrative while marginalizing alternative views.

3. **Claims of Forgery**: The mention of "100% forgery" in relation to survey results is a strong accusation that can be used to discredit the opposing side's claims about cultural heritage and church representation. This kind of language can escalate tensions and frame the discussion in a way that aligns with broader cultural and political conflicts.

Analysis:
Record 725 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision includes a subtle but significant change in the spelling of "Kiev" to "Kyiv." This shift is not merely a matter of orthography; it reflects a broader narrative surrounding Ukrainian identity and sovereignty, particularly in the context of the ongoing conflict with Russia. The term "Kyiv" is increasingly used to assert Ukrainian cultural heritage and independence, distancing the name from its Russian connotations associated with "Kiev." 

The absence of a comment from the user "Yezheha" does not diminish the impact of this change, as the linguistic shift itself serves to reinforce a narrative of Ukrainian identity and resistance against perceived Russian cultural dominance. The use of "Kyiv" aligns with the Ukrainian government's efforts to promote the Ukrainian language and heritage, which can be seen as a response to the historical suppression of these elements. 

Thus, the change in terminology can be interpreted as a weaponization of cultural heritage, as it is employed to assert national identity and challenge narratives that may undermine Ukraine's sovereignty.

Judgment: Weaponised
=============================================

The legality of this step is occasionally questioned to this day along with the fact that the transfer was accompanied by graft and bribery, which in church affairs amounts to an ecclesiastical crime. The transfer itself, however, led to the significant Ukrainian domination of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]], which continued well into the 18th century, [[Feofan Prokopovich]], [[Epifany Slavinetsky]], [[Stephen Yavorsky]] and [[Demetrius of Rostov]] being among the most notable representatives of this trend.<ref name=Kargamanov>\"As a result, the Kievans practically controlled the Russian church obtaining key posts there (and holding them to almost the end of the 18th century)\"<br>Yuri Kagramanov, \"[http://magazines.russ.ru/novyi_mi/2006/8/ka10.html The war of languages in Ukraine]\", [[Novy Mir]], 2006, № 8</ref>\n+In [[1686]], 40 years after [[Petro Mohyla|Mohyla's]] death, the [[Ottomans]], acting on the behalf of the [[regent]] of Moscovy [[Sophia Alekseyevna]], pressured the [[Patriarch of Constantinople]] into transferring the Orthodox Church of Kiev and all Rus' from the jurisdiction of Constantinople to the [[Patriarch of Moscow]], established a century prior to that. Colonization of these lands was actively encouraged, particularly of Ukrainians and Serbs. As [[New Russia]] (Novorossiya, as it was then known) was settled, new Orthodox parishes were created. Construction of Cathedrals that demonstrate some of the finest examples of late 19th century [[East European Architecture]] was undertaken in large cities such as [[Odessa]] and [[Sevastopol]].\n \n ===Territories gained from partitions===\n In the late 17th century the Poland became less and less influential and internal corruption as well as the pressure from its powerful neighbors resulted in its [[Partitions of Poland|partitions]] by neighbouring empires. The [[Russian Empire]], in particular, gained most of ethnically [[Ukrainians|Ukrainian]] land and all of the [[Belarusians|Belarusian]] lands. After nearely two centuries of [[polonization]], the Uniate influence on the Ukrainian population was so great that hardly any remained Orthodox. Although some, particularly in [[Podolia]], chose to revert to Orthodoxy soon after, this in many cases was an exception rather than trend and in locations where the Unia already gave deep roots into the population all of the church property remained in the Catholic and Uniate authority. Also significant was Empress [[Catherine II]]'s decree \"On the newely acquired territory\", according to which most of the Polish magnates retained all their lands and property (thus a significant control over population) in the newly acquired lands.  \n@@ -91,10 +91,11 @@\n ===Soviet Union===\n After the [[Russian Revolution of 1917|Russian Revolution]] and the [[Russian Civil War]] the Bolsheviks seized power in the [[Russian Empire]] and transformed it into the [[Soviet Union]]. Religion in the new [[socialist]] state had little value, but particularly the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] who was actively supportive of the [[White Movement]]. Massive arrests and repressions began immediately. In the [[Ukrainian SSR]] (one of the founding republics of the USSR) as early as in December [[1918]] the first execution of the head of the Ukrainian Exarchate Metropolitan of Kiev and [[Halych]] took place. This was only the start which culminated in mass closing and destruction of churches that (some standing since the days of the [[Kievan Rus]]) and executions of clergy and followers.\n \n-Prior to the [[Bolshevik]]s victory, Ukraine was controlled by several [[Ukrainian People's Republic|short-lived yet independent governments]] which revived the Ukrainian national idea. Ukraine declared its political independence from Russia in 1918 and the Ukrainian [[autocephalous]] Orthodox Church was established. Following the Soviet regime's taking root in Ukraine and despite the ongoing Soviet-wide antireligious campaign, the Bolshevik authorities saw the national churches as a tool in their goal to suppress the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] always viewed with the great suspicion by the regime for its being the cornerstone of pre-revolutionary [[Russian Empire]] and the initially strong opposition the church took towards the regime change (the position of the [[patriarch]] [[Tikhon of Moscow]] was especially critical). The Communist authorities initially supported the Ukrainian national churches as a tool in their goal to weaken the anti-Soviet stance of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]]. In [[1921]] the first formation of the [[Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church]] (UAOC) was recognized. The [[Russian Orthodox Church]] strongly opposed the formation of the Ukrainian autocephaly and not a single ordained bishop was willing or able to ordain the hierarchi for an new Church. Therefore, \"ordained\" its own hierarchy itself, a practice questionable under the [[canon law]], in the \"Alexandrian\" manner - by laying on priests' hands on two senior candidates who became known as [[Metropolitan Vasyl (Lypkivsky)]] and [[Archbishop Nestor (Sharayivsky)]] (reportedly the relics of St. Clement of Rome who died in Ukraine in the first century were also used).[http://www.unicorne.org/ORTHODOXY/articles/contributors/articles/historyuocc.htm] Despite the [[canon law]] controversy, the new church was recognized in 1924 by the [[Ecumenical Patriarch]] Gregory VII.{{fact|date=February 2007}}  In the wake of the [[Ukrainization]] policies carried out in Soviet Ukraine in the first decade of the Soviet rule many of the Orthodox clergy willfully joined the church thus avoiding the persecution suffered by many clergy members who remained inside the Russian Orthodoc Church. During the period in which the Soviet government tolerated the renewed Ukrainian national church the UAOC gained a wide following particularly among the Ukrainian peasantry.<ref>{{cite book| author=Robert Conquest | title=The harvest of sorrow: Soviet collectivization and the terror-famine.| location= Oxford, United Kingdom | publisher= Oxford University Press| year = 1986 |isbn=0-19-505180-7 |pages=211-212}}</ref>\n+Prior to the [[Bolshevik]]s takeover, Ukraine declared its political independence from Russia in 1918. During that period the Ukrainian [[autocephalous]] Orthodox Church was re-established. \n+\n+With the Bolshevik takeover the Communist authorities initially supported the Ukrainian national churches as a tool in their goal to weaken the anti-Soviet stance of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]]. In [[1921]] the first formation of the [[Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church]] (UAOC) was recognized. Because of strong opposition from the Russian Orthodox Church, the church ordained its own hierarchy itself, a practice questionable under the [[canon law]], in the \"Alexandrian\" manner - by laying on priests' hands on two senior candidates who became known as [[Metropolitan Vasyl (Lypkivsky)]] and [[Archbishop Nestor (Sharayivsky)]] (reportedly the relics of St. Clement of Rome who died in Ukraine in the first century were also used).[http://www.unicorne.org/ORTHODOXY/articles/contributors/articles/historyuocc.htm] Despite the [[canon law]] controversy, the new church was recognized in 1924 by the [[Ecumenical Patriarch]] Gregory VII.{{fact|date=February 2007}}  In the wake of the [[Ukrainization]] policies carried out in Soviet Ukraine in the first decade of the Soviet rule many of the Orthodox clergy willfully joined the church. During the period in which the Soviet government tolerated the renewed Ukrainian national church the UAOC gained a wide following particularly among the Ukrainian peasantry.<ref>{{cite book| author=Robert Conquest | title=The harvest of sorrow: Soviet collectivization and the terror-famine.| location= Oxford, United Kingdom | publisher= Oxford University Press| year = 1986 |isbn=0-19-505180-7 |pages=211-212}}</ref>\n \n In the early-[[1930s]] the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] government abruptly reversed the policies in the national republics and mass arrests of UAOC's hierarchy and clergy culminated in the liquidation of the church in 1930. Most of the property was officially transferred to the ROC, with some churches closed for good and destroyed. On the eve of the [[Second World War]] only 3% of the pre-revolutionary parishes on the territory of Ukraine remained open to the public, often hidden in deep rural areas.\n-\n \n ===Second Polish Republic===\n The 1921 [[Peace of Riga]] treaty that ended the [[Polish-Soviet War]] gave the significant areas of the ethnically Ukrainian (and Belarusian) territories to the reborn [[Second Polish Republic|Polish state]]. This included [[Polesie]] and [[Volhynia]], areas with almost exclussively Orthodox population amongst the rural peasants, as well as the former Austrian province of [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]] with its [[Uniate]] population. \n@@ -121,18 +122,18 @@\n ===Post War Situations===\n The Russian Orthodox Church regained its general monopoly in the [[Ukrainian SSR]] after [[World War II]] following another shift in the official Soviet attitude towards Christian churches. As a result many started to accuse it of being a [[puppet]] of the [[Communist Party]]. After the suspicious death of Patriarch Tikhon, the UAOC and UGCC sought to avoid the transfer under the Moscow Patriarchate; something that Moscow tolerated until after World War II, for example the head of the Ukrainian Communist Party, [[Nikita Khruschev]] attended the funeral of the head of the Uniate Church in [[1946]]. Nevertheless as the Uniate Church did in some cases support the Nazi regime, the overall Soviet attitude was negative. In [[1948]] a small group of priests started to proclaim a reunion with Orthodoxy. The Soviet state organized in [[1948]] a synod in [[Lviv]], where the [[1596]] [[Union of Brest]] was annulled. Thereby breaking the canonical ties with [[Catholic see|Rome]] and transferring under the Moscow Patriarchate. In Transcarpathia, the reigning Greek Catholic bishop was murdered[http://www.ewtn.com/library/MARY/theoromz.htm] and the remaining priests were forced to return their Church to Orthodoxy. This move's acceptance was mixed. With many clergy members and lay believers turning to the ROC, some adamantly refused. As a result of this the Patriarchate of Moscow could now legally lay claim to any Orthodox church property that was within the territory of its uncontested jurisdiction, which it did. Some believers refused to accept liquidation of their churches and for nearly 40 years the UAOC and UGCC existed in Western Ukraine underground lead by the clergy members under the threat of prosecution by the Soviet state. Much of the UGCC and UAOC clergy not willing to serve in the ROC emigrated to [[Germany]], the [[United States]], or [[Canada]]. Others were sent to Siberia and even chose to be martyred [http://www.ugcc.org.ua/eng/press-releases/article;3254/][http://www.risu.org.ua/article.php?l=en&sid=1431]. Officially the Moscow Patriarchate never recognised the canonical right of the synod as it lacked any bishops there. \n \n-The relatively permissive post-war government attitude towards the Orthodox Church came to an end with [[Nikita Khruschev]]'s \"Thaw\" programme, which included closing the recently opened Kiev's Caves Lavra. However, in the west-Ukrainian dioceses, which were the largest in the USSR, the Soviet attitude was \"softest\". In fact in the western city of Lviv, only one church was closed. The Moscow Patriarchate also relaxed its canons on the clergy, especially those from the former-uniate territories, allowing them, for example to shave beards (a very uncommon Orthodox practice) and conduct eulogy in Ukrainian instead of [[Church Slavonic]].\n+The relatively permissive post-war government attitude towards the Orthodox Church came to an end with [[Nikita Khruschev]]'s \"Thaw\" programme, which included closing the recently opened Kiev's Caves Lavra. However, in the west-Ukrainian dioceses, which were the largest in the USSR, the Soviet attitude was \"softest\". In fact in the western city of Lviv, only one church was closed. The Moscow Patriarchate also relaxed its canons on the clergy, especially those from the former-uniate territories, allowing them, for example to shave beards (a very uncommon Orthodox practice) and conduct eulogy in Ukrainian instead of Russian.\n \n ===Late Soviet period===\n In [[1988]] with the millennium anniversary of the baptism of [[Kievan Rus|Rus]], there was yet another shift in the Soviet attitude towards religion, coinciding with the [[Perestroika]] and [[Glasnost]] programmes. The Soviet Government publicly apologized for oppression of religion and promised to return all property to the rightful owners. As a result thousands of closed religious buildings in all areas of the USSR were returned to their original owners. In Ukraine this was the then ROC's [[Ukrainian Exarchate]], which took place in the central, eastern and southern Ukraine. In the former-uniate areas of western Ukraine things were more turbulent. As UGCC survived in diaspora and in the underground they took their chance and were immediately revived in Ukraine, where in the wake of general liberalization of the Soviet policies in the late-1980s also prompted the activization of Ukrainian national political movements. The [[Russian Orthodox Church]] became viewed by some as an attribute of Soviet domination, and bitter, often violent clashes over church buildings followed with the ROC slowly losing its parishes to the UGCC. \n \n-The UAOC also followed suit. Sometimes possessors of Church buildings changed several times within days. Although the Soviet law-enforcement did attempt to pacify the almost-warring parties, these were often unsuccessful, as many of the local branches in the ever-crumbling Soviet authority, sympathised with the national sentiments in their areas. Violence grew especially after the UGCC's demand that all property that was held prior to [[1939]] would be returned returned including the property that was initially of the Orthodox church. \n+The UAOC also followed suit. Sometimes possessors of Church buildings changed several times within days. Although the Soviet law-enforcement did attempt to pacify the almost-warring parties, these were often unsuccessful, as many of the local branches in the ever-crumbling Soviet authority, sympathised with the national sentiments in their areas. Violence grew especially after the UGCC's demand that all property that was held prior to [[1939]] would be returned.\n \n It is now believed that the only real event which helped to contain the growing schism in the former-uniate territories was the ROC's reaction of raising its Ukrainian Exarchate to the status of an [[Autonomous entity|autonomous church]], which took place in [[1990]], and up until the [[History of the Soviet Union (1985-1991)|break up of the USSR]] in late [[1991]] there was an uneasy peace in western Ukraine. After the nation became independent, the question of an independent and an [[autocephalous]] Orthodox Church arose once again.\n \n ===Post-Soviet period===\n \n-What historians now see as the reason for the following events was the decision of the head of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church Metropolitan of Kiev and all Ukraine [[Patriarch Filaret (Mykhailo Denysenko)|Filaret]] to achieve total [[autocephaly]] (independence) of his [[metropolitan see]] with or without the approval of the [[mother church]] required by the [[canon law]]. These events followed Filaret's own unsuccessful attempt to gain a seat of the [[Moscow Patriarch]] to himself ([[1990]]) and the Ukrainian independence following the [[collapse of the Soviet Union]] in August, 1991. In November 1991 Metropolitan Filaret requested the hierarchy of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] to grant the Ukrainian Orthodox Church autocephalous status. The skeptical hierarchy of the Russian Orthodox Church called for a full Synodical council (Sobor) where this issue would have been discussed at length. Filaret, using his support from the old friendship ties with the then newly elected [[President of Ukraine]] ([[Leonid Kravchuk]]), convinced him that a new independent government should have its own independent church. Despite the unpopularity of the UAOC outside [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]], Filaret managed to organise a covert communion with the UAOC in case [[Moscow Patriarchate]] refused.\n+What historians now see as the reason for the following events was the decision of the head of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church Metropolitan of Kiev and all Ukraine [[Patriarch Filaret (Mykhailo Denysenko)|Filaret]] to achieve total [[autocephaly]] (independence) of his [[metropolitan see]] with or without the approval of the [[mother church]] required by the [[canon law]]. These events followed Filaret's own unsuccessful attempt to gain a seat of the [[Moscow Patriarch]] to himself ([[1990]]) and the Ukrainian independence following the [[collapse of the Soviet Union]] in August, 1991. In November 1991, Metropolitan Filaret requested the hierarchy of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] to grant the Ukrainian Orthodox Church autocephalous status. The skeptical hierarchy of the Russian Orthodox Church called for a full Synodical council (Sobor) where this issue would have been discussed at length. Filaret, using his support from the old friendship ties with the then newly elected [[President of Ukraine]] ([[Leonid Kravchuk]]), convinced him that a new independent government should have its own independent church. Filaret was able to organise a covert communion with the UAOC in case [[Moscow Patriarchate]] refused.\n \n At the synod in March-April of [[1992]], however, most of the clergy of the UOC who initially supported Filaret, openly criticised this move, and put most of the other bishops against him. Questions of his unpopular disregard to [[monastic vows]] (having a [[common-law wife]]) as well as the allegations of improper financial dealings with the church finances made the council vote for Filaret to retire from his position which was confirmed by a sworn oath. \n "

Analysis:
Record 576 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision made by the user "Ukrained" contains several linguistic indicators that suggest an attempt to frame the narrative around Ukrainian cultural heritage in a way that could be seen as weaponized. 

1. **Contextual Language**: The comment by the user, which mentions "deliberately false edits," indicates a strong bias against the previous editor, "Irpen." This language suggests an adversarial stance that could be used to delegitimize opposing viewpoints, which is a common tactic in cultural heritage disputes.

2. **Terminology Changes**: The revision includes changes such as "Moscovy" instead of "Russia" and "colonization" instead of "annexation." These shifts in terminology can carry significant implications. "Colonization" has a more negative connotation and implies a forceful takeover, which aligns with narratives of oppression and cultural erasure, particularly in the context of Ukrainian history.

3. **Cultural Identity Framing**: The text emphasizes the historical significance of Christianity in Ukraine and its ties to national identity. Phrases like "Ukrainian domination of the Russian Orthodox Church" and references to the "Ukrainian national idea" serve to reinforce a narrative of Ukrainian cultural resilience and identity, which can be weaponized against narratives that seek to diminish or deny Ukrainian sovereignty and cultural heritage.

4. **Historical Context**: The revision discusses the historical context of the Orthodox Church's influence in

Judgment: Weaponised

While being a cultural attraction, the monastery is once again active, with over 100 monks in residence.{{fact|date=May 2017}} It was named one of the [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine]] on 21 August 2007, based on voting by experts and the internet community.{{fact|date=May 2017}}\n "
}

Analysis:
Record 564 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision changes the spelling of "Kiev" to "Kyiv" in the article, which is significant in the context of cultural heritage and national identity. The term "Kyiv" is the Ukrainian name for the capital and is increasingly used in international contexts to assert Ukrainian sovereignty and identity, especially in light of ongoing conflicts with Russia. The comment in the diff indicates that this spelling is the "official English spelling used by the Ukrainian government," which implies a recognition of Ukraine's cultural and political stance.

The shift from "Kiev" to "Kyiv" can be seen as a subtle but powerful linguistic weaponization, as it aligns with Ukraine's efforts to promote its cultural heritage and assert its national identity against Russian narratives that often use "Kiev." This change reflects a broader narrative of cultural oppression and the importance of language in the context of territorial and cultural disputes. The revision thus serves to reinforce Ukrainian identity and counteract Russian claims, making it a clear example of weaponization of cultural heritage through language.

Judgment: Weaponised
=============================================

Analysis:
Record 837 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision made by the user "Nikolaj1905" includes a significant focus on the Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate (UOC-MP) and its relationship with the Ukrainian government, particularly regarding the termination of its lease on historic sites. The language used in the diff, such as "the church had violated their lease by making alterations to the historic site," and the framing of the UOC-MP's response as "a whim of officials" suggests a narrative that could be interpreted as delegitimizing the church's claims and reinforcing the authority of the Ukrainian state over cultural heritage.

Additionally, the mention of Dmitry Peskov's statement that the Ukrainian authorities' decision "confirms the correctness" of the Russian invasion introduces a contentious political narrative that could be weaponized to frame the church's situation as part of a broader conflict. This aligns with the weaponization of cultural heritage by framing the UOC-MP as an entity that is not only violating agreements but also as a pawn in a larger geopolitical struggle, thus potentially justifying actions taken against it.

The overall tone and context of the changes reflect a shift towards a narrative that could be used to justify state actions against a religious institution associated with Russian influence, which is a sensitive topic in the context of the ongoing conflict.

Judgment: Weaponised

Analysis:
Record 538 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision reflects a significant shift in the spelling of "Kiev" to "Kyiv," which aligns with the Ukrainian government's official stance on the name of the city. This change is not merely a linguistic preference; it carries political implications, as "Kyiv" is often used to assert Ukrainian sovereignty and identity, especially in the context of ongoing tensions with Russia. The user making the edit appears to be reinforcing this perspective by adopting the Ukrainian spelling throughout the text, including in the context of the "Kyiv Pechersk Lavra," which is a culturally significant site.

Additionally, the removal of the reference to the "Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)" without a clear replacement could suggest an attempt to diminish the visibility of Russian influence in the narrative surrounding this heritage site. This aligns with the broader narrative of cultural oppression and the desire to assert Ukrainian heritage against perceived Russian encroachment.

Overall, the linguistic choices made in this revision serve to reinforce a specific national identity and political narrative, which can be seen as a form of weaponization of cultural heritage in the context of the Ukraine-Russia conflict.

Judgment: Weaponised
=============================================

================= EDIT #92 =================

JSON Record:
{
  "version": "diff",
  "Timestamp": "2006-03-07T21:06:43Z",
  "User": "Ukrained",
  "Comment": "rv contionuous POV-pushing by the Russian Group",
  "Diff": "--- \n+++ \n@@ -30,9 +30,21 @@\n \n In [[1686]], 40 years after Mohyla's death, the Orthodox Church of Kiev and all Rus' was transferred from the jurisdiction of the [[Patriarch of Constantinople]] to the [[Patriarchate of Moscow]], established a century prior to that. This led to the Ukrainian domination of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]], which continued well into the 18th century, [[Feofan Prokopovich]] and [[Demetrius of Rostov]] being among the most notable representatives of this trend.\n \n-== Distinguishing between church bodies ==\n+== 20 th Century ==\n \n-Currently, the major Ukrainian Christian churches are: \n+After the [[Russian Revolution of 1917|Russian Revolution]] and the [[Russian Civil War]] the [[Bolshevik]] authorities initially tolerated and even encouraged Ukrainian nationalism following their victory in Ukraine. In [[1921]] a [[Sobor]] announced a new [[Autocephaly]], and created the [[Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church]] (UAOC) in Kiev with [[Metropolitan Wasyl Lypkivskyj]] ordained as a  head of the UAOC.  In the wake of the break up of the [[Russian Empire]], Russian Orthodox church was seen as counterrevolutionary and pro-White by the Communists, and a [[Ukrainian Autonomous Orthodox Church]] was  founded  with their encouragement in order to reduce the influence of patriarch [[Tikhon of Moscow]] whose position towards the revolution was strongly critical. The [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] government later changed its religious policy and started to persecute UAOC along with the Russian Orthodox church. \n+\n+On [[October 8]], [[1942]] Archbishop Nikanor and Bishop Mstyslav (later a [[Patriarch]]) of the UAOC and Metropolitan Oleksiy (Hromadsky) of the Ukrainian Autonomous Orthodox Church concluded an [[Act of Union]], uniting the two national churches at the [[Pochaev Lavra]]. Later [[Nazi Germany|German]] occupation authorities and pro-Russian hierarchs of the Autonomous Church convinced Metropolitan Oleksiy to remove his signature. Metropolitan Oleksiy was murdered in [[Volhynia]] on [[May 7]], [[1943]] by the nationalist guerillas of the [[Ukrainian Insurgent Army]].\n+\n+The Russian Orthodox Church regained its general monopoly in the [[Ukrainian SSR]] after [[World War II]] following another shift in the official Soviet attitude towards Christian churches. As a result many started to accuse it of being a [[puppet]] of the [[Communist Party]]. After the suspicious death of Patriarch Tikhon, the UAOC and UGCC sought to avoid the transfer under the Moscow Patriarchy; something that Moscow tolerated until after World War II. At the state organized [[1948]] synod in [[Lviv]] (Lvov), some UGCC clergy were coerced into proclaiming the annulment of the [[1596]] [[Union of Brest]] thereby breaking the canonical ties with [[Catholic see|Rome]] and transferring under the Moscow Patriarchy. This move's acceptance was mixed. With many clergy members and lay believers turning to ROC, some adamantly refused. While the UAOC and UGCC church property in Ukraine was liquidated by the Soviet authorities or transferred to the ROC, many believers refused to accept liquidation of their churches and for nearly 40 years the UAOC and UGCC existed in Western Ukraine underground lead by the clergy members under the threat of prosecution by the Soviet state. Much of the UGCC and UAOC clergy not willing to serve in ROC emigrated to [[Germany]], the [[United States]], or [[Canada]] and the Patriarchate of Moscow could legally lay claim to any Orthodox church property that was within the territory of its uncontested jurisdiction, which it did. \n+\n+The warm post-war attitude towards the Orthodox Church came to an end with [[Nikita Khruschev]]'s \"Thaw\" programme, which included closing the recently opened Kiev's Caves Lavra. However in the west-Ukrainian dioceses, which were the largest in the USSR, the Soviet attitude was \"softest\". In fact in the western city of Lviv, only one church was closed. The Moscow patriarchy also relaxed its canons on the clergy, especially those from the former-uniate territories, allowing them, for example to shave beards (a very uncommon Orthodox practice) and conduct liturgy in Ukrainian instead of Slavonic. \n+\n+In 1988 with the millennium anniversary of the baptism of Rus, there was yet another shift in the Soviet attitude towards religion, coinciding with the Perestroika and Glasnost programmes, the USSR apologized for all repressions towards religion and promised to return all property to the rightful owners. Although what began as a peaceful return of many closed church buildings (of course to the then ROC's Ukrainian Exarchate) in the central, eastern and southern Ukraine (as well as in other parts of the USSR), in the former-uniate regions of western Ukraine it was a different story. As UGCC survived in diaspora and in the underground they took their chance and were immediately revived in Ukraine, where in the wake of the Rukh movements the UOC-MP was viewed as a leftover of Soviet occupation, and bitter, often violent clashes over church buildings followed with the UOC-MP slowly losing its parishes to the UGCC. The UAOC also did not wait long and quickly followed suit. Sometimes possessors of Church buildings changes several times in the space of a couple of days. All Soviet attempts to pacify the almost-warring church parties were useless. It is now believed that the only real event which enabled to contain the schism in the former-uniate territory was the ROC's reaction of raising its Ukrainian Exarchate to the status of an autonomous church, which took place in 1990, and up until the break up of the USSR (late 1991) there was an uneasy peace in western Ukraine. However after the nation became independent, the question of an independent and autocephalous Orthodox Church arose once again and another schism was approaching.\n+\n+What historians now see as the reason for the following events was the decision of the head of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church Metropolitan of Kiev and all Ukraine [[Filaret]] to achieve total [[autocephalocy]] (independence) from the Russian Orthodox Church. After the fall of the USSR he led a movement for «full canonical independence, namely, autocephaly» for his Church. In November 1991 he headed a working council which requested the hierarchy of the Russian Orthodox Church to grant the Ukrainian Orthodox Church-Moscow Patriarchate autocephalous status. President of Ukraine (then, [[Leonid Kravchuk]]) supported Filaret's request but the Moscow Patriarchate strongly opposed it. Immediately a number of articles in the press accused Filaret of severe violation of his monastic vows and abuse of his ecclesiastical authority. The Hierarchical Council of the Russian Orthodox Church, that took place from March to April 1992, demanded that he resigns his position. Filaret, who attended the Council, promised that he would step down, but upon his return from Moscow, he disclosed that the promise was given under pressure and he is not leaving. Subsequently, in May 1992 at a Hierarchical Council held in [[Kharkhiv]] the majority of the bishops of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church of Moscow Patriarchate voted to depose Metropolitan Filaret from his office and suspend his clerical functioning. Despite, supported by three other bishops and political authorities in Ukraine, Filaret united with the Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church. In June of 1992 they created a new Church, the Ukrainian Orthodox Church of Kievan Patriarchate (UOC-KP) with 94-year-old [[Patriarch Mstyslav]] as a leader. Though only chosen as assistant, Filaret was in fact controlling the Church affairs. Opposing this situation, some of the Autocephalous [[bishop]]s and clergy refused to join the Ukrainian Orthodox Church-Kyivan Patriarchate.\n+\n+==Modern Times==\n \n * The [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church - Moscow Patriarchy|Ukrainian Orthodox Church]] (UOC-MP) under the [[Patriarch of Moscow]] of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] (ROC). Since 1990 the UOC-MP operates as an [[autonomy|autonomous]] church (one step short of full [[autocephaly]]). The [[Metropolitan Volodymyr (Viktor Sabodan)]] is enthroned since [[1992]] as the head of the UOC-MP under the title [[Metropolitan of Kiev and all Ukraine]].\n \n@@ -46,19 +58,9 @@\n \n The current divided and fluid situation traces its roots to the close connection between Orthodox church and the state in [[Tsarist Russia]] after the transfer of the Kiev Metropolitan [[Episcopal see|see]] from the Patriarch of Constantinople to the Patriarch of Moscow in [[1686]].  Some clerics and church historians, particularly in Ukraine, do not consider this transfer legitimate and claim it was attempted via the ecclesiastic crime of [[bribery]] by the Russian Church, then only recently elevated to patriarchal status, but eventually accepted under pressure from the [[Ottoman Empire|Turkish]] [[Sultan]]. This development, they claim, resulted in a forced policy of [[Russification]] of Ukrainian Christianity. Gradually Russophile Orthodox clergy during the 18th and 19th centuries became dominant in Ukraine. Despite the fact that the transfer was and still is occasionally questioned in Ukraine, it gained a de-facto recognition and acceptance in the Eastern Orthodox communion by 300+ years of Ukrainian Orthodoxy remaining in the see of the Patriarch of Moscow.\n \n-After the [[Russian Revolution of 1917|Russian Revolution]] and the [[Russian Civil War]] the [[Bolshevik]] authorities initially tolerated and even encouraged Ukrainian nationalism following their victory in Ukraine. In [[1921]] a [[Sobor]] announced a new [[Autocephaly]], and created the [[Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church]] (UAOC) in Kiev with [[Metropolitan Wasyl Lypkivskyj]] ordained as a  head of the UAOC.  In the wake of the break up of the [[Russian Empire]], Russian Orthodox church was seen as counterrevolutionary and pro-White by the Communists, and a [[Ukrainian Autonomous Orthodox Church]] was  founded  with their encouragement in order to reduce the influence of patriarch [[Tikhon of Moscow]] whose position towards the revolution was strongly critical. The [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] government later changed its religious policy and started to persecute UAOC along with the Russian Orthodox church. \n \n-On [[October 8]], [[1942]] Archbishop Nikanor and Bishop Mstyslav (later a Patriarch) of the UAOC and Metropolitan Oleksiy (Hromadsky) of the Ukrainian Autonomous Orthodox Church concluded an [[Act of Union]], uniting the two national churches at the [[Pochaev Lavra]]. Later [[Nazi Germany|German]] occupation authorities and pro-Russian hierarchs of the Autonomous Church convinced Metropolitan Oleksiy to remove his signature. Metropolitan Oleksiy was murdered in [[Volhynia]] on [[May 7]], [[1943]] by the nationalist guerillas of the [[Ukrainian Insurgent Army]].\n \n-The Russian Orthodox Church regained its general monopoly in the [[Ukrainian SSR]] after [[World War II]] following another shift in the official Soviet attitude towards Christian churches. As a result many started to accuse it of being a [[puppet]] of the [[Communist Party]]. After the suspicious death of Patriarch Tikhon, the UAOC and UGCC sought to avoid the transfer under the Moscow Patriarchy; something that Moscow tolerated until after World War II. At the state organized [[1948]] synod in [[Lviv]] (Lvov), some UGCC clergy were coerced into proclaiming the annulment of the [[1596]] [[Union of Brest]] thereby breaking the canonical ties with [[Catholic see|Rome]] and transferring under the Moscow Patriarchy. This move's acceptance was mixed. With many clergy members and lay believers turning to ROC, some adamantly refused. While the UAOC and UGCC church property in Ukraine was liquidated by the Soviet authorities or transferred to the ROC, many believers refused to accept liquidation of their churches and for nearly 40 years the UAOC and UGCC existed in Western Ukraine underground lead by the clergy members under the threat of prosecution by the Soviet state. Much of the UGCC and UAOC clergy not willing to serve in ROC emigrated to [[Germany]], the [[United States]], or [[Canada]] and the Patriarchate of Moscow could legally lay claim to any Orthodox church property that was within the territory of its uncontested jurisdiction, which it did. \n-\n-The warm post-war attitude towards the Orthodox Church came to an end with Nikita Khruschev's \"Thaw\" programme, which included closing the recently opened Kiev's Caves Lavra. However in the west-Ukrainian dioceses, which were the largest in the USSR, the Soviet attitude was \"softest\". In fact in the western city of Lvov, only one church was closed. The Moscow patriarchy also relaxed its canons on the clergy, especially those from the former-uniate territories, allowing them, for example to shave beards (a very uncommon Orthodox practice) and conduct liturgy in Ukrainian instead of Slavonic. \n-\n-In 1988 with the millennium anniversary of the baptism of Rus, there was yet another shift in the Soviet attitude towards religion, coinciding with the Perestroika and Glasnost programmes, the USSR apologized for all repressions towards religion and promised to return all property to the rightful owners. Although what began as a peaceful return of many closed church buildings (of course to the then ROC's Ukrainian Exarchate) in the central, eastern and southern Ukraine (as well as in other parts of the USSR), in the former-uniate regions of western Ukraine it was a different story. As UGCC survived in diaspora and in the underground they took their chance and were immediately revived in Ukraine, where in the wake of the Rukh movements the UOC-MP was viewed as a leftover of Soviet occupation, and bitter, often violent clashes over church buildings followed with the UOC-MP slowly losing its parishes to the UGCC. The UAOC also did not wait long and quickly followed suit. Sometimes possessors of Church buildings changes several times in the space of a couple of days. All Soviet attempts to pacify the almost-warring church parties were unsuccessful, especially after the UGCC's demand that all property that was held prior to 1939 would be returned (even though some it was Orthodox before the Unia came). It is now believed that the only real event which enabled to contain the schism in the former-uniate territory was the ROC's reaction of raising its Ukrainian Exarchate to the status of an autonomous church, which took place in 1990, and up until the break up of the USSR (late 1991) there was an uneasy peace in western Ukraine. However after the nation became independent, the question of an independent and autocephalous Orthodox Church arose once again and another schism was approaching.\n-\n-What historians now see as the reason for the following events was the decision of the head of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church Metropolitan of Kiev and all Ukraine Filaret to achieve total autocephalocy from the Russian Orthodox Church. To achieve that, with active support of the then president Leonid Kravchuk, he covertely organised a communion with the Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church in case Moscow refused. The skeptical hierarchy of the Russian Orthodox Church called for a full council where this issue would have been discussed, upon arrival most of the clergy of the UOC who initially supported Filaret, openely criticised this move and immediately the votes turned against him. In the end the council voted for Filaret to retire from his position which was confirmed by a swore. Upon returning to Kiev however Filaret carried out his reserve option, and Police aided by nationalist Paramilitaries supported him in retaining his rank. The UOC synod was quick to respond and in the eastern city of Kharkov elected a new leader, the Metropolitan Vladimir (Slobodan). From there most of the fate of control of church buildings was decided by the church parishes, but when most refused to follow Filaret, paramilitaries, especially in Volyn and Rovno Oblasts carried out raids bringing property under their control.\n-\n-The UOC-MP, which operates in [[full communion|communion]] with the other Eastern Orthodox Churches still owns the majority of Orthodox church buildings in Ukraine and is predominant in eastern and southern Ukraine. The UGCC and the UAOC, on the other hand, have most of their communities in the western provinces ([[oblast]]s} of [[Lviv Oblast|Lviv]],  [[Ternopil Oblast|Ternopil]] and [[Ivano-Frankivsk Oblast|Ivano-Frankivsk]].  The UOC-KP has its communities scattered across Ukraine, though only in western areas do they outnumber those of the UOC-MP. The UOC-KP and especially the UAOC and UGCC have strong support in the [[Ukrainian diaspora]].\n+The UOC-MP, which operates in [[full communion|communion]] with the other Eastern Orthodox churches still owns the majority of Orthodox church buildings in Ukraine and is predominant in eastern and southern Ukraine. The UGCC and the UAOC, on the other hand, have most of their communities in the western provinces ([[oblast]]s} of [[Lviv Oblast|Lviv]],  [[Ternopil Oblast|Ternopil]] and [[Ivano-Frankivsk Oblast|Ivano-Frankivsk]].  The UOC-KP has its communities scattered across Ukraine, though only in western areas do they outnumber those of the UOC-MP. The UOC-KP and especially the UAOC and UGCC have strong support in the [[Ukrainian diaspora]].\n \n == Diaspora churches ==\n "
}

Analysis:
Record 160 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision made by the user "Ukrained" reflects a clear attempt to shift the narrative surrounding the historical context of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church and its relationship with the Russian Orthodox Church. The comment "rv continuous POV-pushing by the Russian Group" indicates a defensive stance against perceived bias, suggesting that the user is actively trying to counter what they view as a Russian-centric perspective.

Several linguistic indicators in the "Diff" section highlight this weaponization:

1. **Terminology and Framing**: The use of terms like "Ukrainian domination of the Russian Orthodox Church" and "forced policy of Russification" frames the historical narrative in a way that emphasizes Ukrainian agency and victimization, while delegitimizing Russian claims. This aligns with the Ukrainian perspective of cultural heritage being under threat from Russian influence.

2. **Historical Context**: The revision includes detailed accounts of the persecution of the Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church (UAOC) and the manipulation of church properties, which serve to reinforce a narrative of oppression and resistance against Russian control. Phrases like "many believers refused to accept liquidation of their churches" evoke a sense of cultural resilience against an oppressive regime.

3. **Conflict and Violence**: The mention of "nationalist guerillas of the Ukrainian Insurgent Army" and the violent clashes over church buildings introduces a narrative of conflict that positions Ukrainian nationalists as defenders of their cultural heritage against external threats, further polar

Judgment: Weaponised
=============================================

When they ask about mere baptism or self-identification (rather than church attendance) the figures are different.  I don't recall where I read that so I won't put it up in the article however.  [[User:Faustian|Faustian]] 21:50, 7 February 2007 (UTC)\n \n+:The major problem of the surveys is that it is simple to say that we asked 5000 people in all major cities in Ukraine, but this has one major flaw - Ukrainian society has a sharp rural/urban difference. Urban society, at most is brought up on Marxist, cosmopolitan ideals...where the majority of people are not regular church-goers. In fact it is something of similar to Soviet times, if before people were members of Comsomol and even the party, that did not mean that they actually were idiologically communist. What changed? It got a new name although retained the same abbreviation - КП, was founded by ex-Communists Kravchuk and Dinisenko, and if yesterday it talked about the bad influences of Trotskism, Maoism and Capitalism, today its any Russophilism/Moscowphilism. }

Analysis:
Record 146 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision introduces a narrative that subtly shifts the focus towards a dichotomy between urban and rural populations in Ukraine, framing the UOC-MP (Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate) as a representation of traditional and conservative values in rural areas, while portraying urban society as influenced by "Marxist, cosmopolitan ideals." This language can be interpreted as an attempt to create a cultural divide, suggesting that urban populations are disconnected from traditional values, which may serve to delegitimize their perspectives.

Additionally, the mention of "ex-Communists" and the comparison to Soviet times implies a continuity of ideological control, which can be seen as an attempt to frame the UOC-MP as a legitimate cultural institution in contrast to perceived urban liberalism. The reference to "Russophilism/Moscowphilism" further emphasizes a narrative that positions the UOC-MP as a bastion of traditional Ukrainian identity against a backdrop of urban cosmopolitanism.

The dismissal of U.S. government data with a comparison to the Iraq War narrative ("Saddam had WMO that are still to be found") suggests a broader skepticism towards Western narratives, which can be weaponized to foster distrust in external influences and reinforce a pro-Russian stance. Overall, the language used in this revision reflects a strategic framing of cultural identity that aligns with specific political narratives, thus qualifying it as weaponised.

Judgment: Weaponised
=============================================

A History of Ukraine. University of Toronto Press: Toronto, 1996. p 98.]</ref> the Lavra has been a preeminent center of the [[Eastern Orthodox Christianity]] in [[Eastern Europe]]. Together with the [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev|Saint-Sophia Cathedral]], it is inscribed as a [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]]. The monastery complex is considered a national preserve, the national status to which was granted on March 13 1996.<ref>[http://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=181%2F96&p=1260343170231885 Про надання статусу національного Києво-Печерському державному історико-культурному заповіднику]</ref> It was named one of the [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine]] on August 21, 2007, based on voting by experts and the internet community.\n+Since its foundation as the [[cave monastery]] in 1015<ref>[Magocsi P.R. A History of Ukraine. University of Toronto Press: Toronto, 1996. p 98.]</ref> the Lavra has been a preeminent center of the [[Eastern Orthodox Christianity]] in [[Eastern Europe]]. Together with the [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev|Saint-Sophia Cathedral]], it is inscribed as a [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]]. The monastery complex is considered a separate national historic-cultural preserve (sanctuary), the national status to which was granted on March 13 1996.<ref>[http://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=181%2F96&p=1260343170231885 Про надання статусу національного Києво-Печерському державному історико-культурному заповіднику]</ref> It was named one of the [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine]] on August 21, 2007, based on voting by experts and the internet community.\n \n Currently, the jurisdiction over the site is divided between the state museum, National Kiev-Pechersk Historic-Cultural Preserve<ref>[http://www.kplavra.kiev.ua/#]</ref>, and the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchy)]] as the site of the chief monastery of that Church and the residence of its leader, [[Metropolitan Volodymyr (Viktor Sabodan)|Metropolitan Volodymyr]].\n "

Dormition Caves Lavra|date=11 October 2019|access-date=12 December 2019}}</ref>\n+\n+The jurisdiction over the monastery was extrajudicially transferred to the [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine|Ukrainian Ukraine|url=https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-society/3626684-kyivpechersk-lavra-officially-registered-as-monastery-within-orthodox-church-of-ukraine.html|access-date=|website=[[Ukrinform]]|language=en}}</ref>\n \n ==Etymology and other names==\n [[File:Perchersk Lavra, Kyiv Lithograph.jpg|left|thumb|Lithograph of Pechersk Lavra, Kyiv, [https://www.nga.gov/research/library/imagecollections/features/watsons_russia.html Department of Image Collections], National Gallery of Art Library, Washington, DC]]"
}

Analysis:
Record 735 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision introduces a significant shift in the language surrounding the jurisdiction of the Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra. The phrase "extrajudicially transferred" implies a controversial and possibly illegitimate action, which can frame the transfer of authority to the Ukrainian Orthodox Church in a negative light. This choice of words suggests that the transfer was not sanctioned by legal means, thereby casting doubt on the legitimacy of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church's claim to the site.

Additionally, the context of the revision, which occurs in a politically charged environment, can be interpreted as an attempt to influence perceptions regarding the control of cultural heritage sites. The use of "extrajudicially" aligns with narratives that may seek to portray the actions of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church as overreaching or unlawful, which can be weaponized in the broader discourse about cultural and territorial control in the context of the ongoing conflict.

Overall, the linguistic indicators—specifically the term "extrajudicially"—suggest a deliberate framing that could be used to justify opposition to the Ukrainian Orthodox Church's authority and to reinforce narratives of conflict over cultural heritage.

Judgment: Weaponised

While being a cultural attraction, the monastery is once again active, with over 100 monks in residence.{{fact|date=May 2017}} It was named one of the [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine]] on 21 August 2007, based on voting by experts and the internet community.{{fact|date=May 2017}}\n+Since its foundation as the [[cave monastery]] in 1051,<ref>Magocsi P.R. ================= EDIT #104 =================

JSON Record:
{
  "version": "diff",
  "Timestamp": "2024-03-23T14:12:26Z",
  "User": "StarkReport",
  "Comment": "/* Soviet Union */  Incorporated references concerning the Church's recognition by Gregory VII.",
  "Diff": "--- \n+++ \n@@ -116,7 +116,7 @@\n \n Following the Soviet regime's taking root in Ukraine and despite the ongoing Soviet-wide antireligious campaign, the Bolshevik authorities saw the national churches as a tool in their goal to suppress the Russian Orthodox Church always viewed with the great suspicion by the regime for its being the cornerstone of pre-revolutionary Russian Empire and the initially strong opposition the church took towards the regime change (the position of the [[patriarch]] [[Tikhon of Moscow]] was especially critical).\n \n-On November 11, 1921 [http://www.day.kiev.ua/151244/], an unrecognised Church Council started in Kiev. The council would proclaim the first formation of the Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church (UAOC). The Russian Orthodox Church strongly opposed the formation of the Ukrainian autocephaly and not a single ordained bishop was willing or able to ordain the hierarchy for a new church. Therefore, the clergy  \"ordained\" its own hierarchy itself, a practice questionable under the [[canon law]], in the \"Alexandrian\" manner - by laying on priests' hands on two senior candidates who became known as [[Metropolitan Vasyl (Lypkivsky)]] and Archbishop Nestor (Sharayivsky) (reportedly the relics of Clement of Rome who died in Ukraine in the 1st century were also used).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unicorne.org/ORTHODOXY/articles/contributors/articles/historyuocc.htm |last=Unicorne |title=A Brief History of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church |date=2020 |access-date=20 February 2021}}</ref> Despite the canon law controversy, the new church was recognized in 1924 by the Ecumenical Patriarch [[Patriarch Gregory VII of Constantinople|Gregory VII]].{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}}\n+On November 11, 1921 [http://www.day.kiev.ua/151244/], an unrecognised Church Council started in Kiev. The council would proclaim the first formation of the Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church (UAOC). The Russian Orthodox Church strongly opposed the formation of the Ukrainian autocephaly and not a single ordained bishop was willing or able to ordain the hierarchy for a new church. Therefore, the clergy  \"ordained\" its own hierarchy itself, a practice questionable under the [[canon law]], in the \"Alexandrian\" manner - by laying on priests' hands on two senior candidates who became known as [[Metropolitan Vasyl (Lypkivsky)]] and Archbishop Nestor (Sharayivsky) (reportedly the relics of Clement of Rome who died in Ukraine in the 1st century were also used).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unicorne.org/ORTHODOXY/articles/contributors/articles/historyuocc.htm |last=Unicorne |title=A Brief History of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church |date=2020 |access-date=20 February 2021}}</ref> Despite the canon law controversy, the new church was recognized in 1924 by the Ecumenical Patriarch [[Patriarch Gregory VII of Constantinople|Gregory VII]].<ref>{{cite web |title=ARTICLES ON THE HISTORY OF OUR JURISDICTION |url=http://uaocamerica.com/our-history-statutes--polic/articles-on-our-jurisdictio.html |publisher=Ukrainian Orthodox Church |access-date=March 23, 2024 |date=July 25, 1999}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Zhukovsky |first1=Arkadii |title=Autocephaly |url=https://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CA%5CU%5CAutocephaly.htm |website=Encyclopedia Of Ukraine |access-date=March 23, 2024 |date=2005}}</ref>{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}}\n \n In the wake of the [[Ukrainization]] policies carried out in Soviet Ukraine in the first decade of the Soviet rule many of the Orthodox clergy willfully joined the church thus avoiding the persecution suffered by many clergy members who remained inside the Russian Orthodox Church. During the period in which the Soviet government tolerated the renewed Ukrainian national church the UAOC gained a wide following particularly among the Ukrainian peasantry.<ref>{{cite book| author = Robert Conquest | title = The harvest of sorrow: Soviet collectivization and the terror-famine | url=https://archive.org/details/harvestofsorrows00conq | url-access = registration | location = Oxford, United Kingdom | publisher = Oxford University Press | year = 1986 |isbn=0-19-505180-7 | pages =[https://archive.org/details/harvestofsorrows00conq/page/211 211–212]}}</ref>\n [[File:Saint Michaels Cathedral (Kiev) in ruins.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Ruins of the [[St. Michael's Golden-Domed Monastery]] after its destruction in 1936 ]]"
}

Analysis:
Record 1144 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Not Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision made by the user "StarkReport" primarily incorporates references to the recognition of the Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church (UAOC) by Patriarch Gregory VII. The language used in the "Diff" does not exhibit any overtly weaponized terms or narratives that align with the examples provided for either Ukraine's or Russia's perspectives. 

The content remains focused on historical events and the ecclesiastical context without invoking charged language or framing that could be interpreted as an attempt to manipulate cultural heritage for political ends. The mention of the "Soviet regime" and the "Russian Orthodox Church" is factual and does not carry the weight of propaganda or a narrative that seeks to justify actions or shift perceptions in a contentious manner. 

Overall, the changes appear to enhance the historical accuracy of the article rather than weaponize cultural heritage.

Judgment: Not Weaponised
