  "Diff": "--- \n+++ \n@@ -57,9 +57,12 @@\n ==Museum==\n The Kiev Pechersk Lavra is also one of the largest Ukrainian museums in Kiev. The exposition is the actual ensemble of the Upper (''[[Near Caves]]'') and Lower (''[[Far Caves]]'') Lavra territories that houses more than 100 architectural relics of the past. The collection within the churches and caves include articles of precious metal, prints, higher clergy portraits and rare church hierarchy photographs. The main exposition contains articles from 16 to early 20th centuries which include [[chalice]]s, [[crucifix]]es, and [[textile]]s from 16-19th centuries with needlework and [[embroidery]] of Ukrainian masters. The remainder of collection consists of pieces from Lavra's Printing House and Lavra's Icon Painting Workshop.\n <ref name=\"Kyiv Sightseeing Guide\">{{cite book | year=2001 | title=Kyiv Sightseeing Guide | publisher=Centre d'Europe | location=Kyiv/Lviv | id=ISBN 966-7022-29-3}}</ref>\n+It is also possible to tour the catacombs, which contain mummified remains of Orthodox saints or their relics. \n \n ==Trivia==\n From 1994 to 1999 in the territory of the Lavra, within the portion then belonging to the Ukrainian State, the Embassy of Italy was located, after the renewal of the building hosting the ancient baths.\n+\n+During the Soviet occupation, the bodies of the mummified saints that lay in the caves were left uncovered due to the regime's disregard for religon. However, after the fall of the Soviet Union, the bodes were covered with a cloth and to this day remain in the same state.  \n \n The Kiev Pechersk Lavra was named one of the [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine]] on [[August 21]], [[2007]], based off a voting by experts and the internet community.\n "
}

Analysis:
Record 155 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision includes specific language that frames the historical context of the Kiev Pechersk Lavra in a way that aligns with a narrative of cultural oppression. The phrases "left uncovered during the Soviet occupation" and "the regime's disregard for religion" suggest a negative portrayal of the Soviet era, implying a deliberate act of disrespect towards Orthodox saints and their relics. This language evokes a sense of victimization and cultural loss, which can be used to justify contemporary sentiments against the Soviet legacy and reinforce a Ukrainian national identity.

Additionally, the mention of the "fall of the Soviet Union" and the subsequent covering of the bodies with cloth serves to highlight a restoration of cultural and religious respect, contrasting the past oppression with a present that values and protects cultural heritage. This shift in tone and emphasis on historical grievances can be seen as a way to weaponize cultural heritage by framing the narrative in a manner that promotes a specific political agenda and fosters division.

Judgment: Weaponised

  "Diff": "--- \n+++ \n@@ -171,6 +171,7 @@\n The Ukrainian Orthodox Church or UOC, sometimes abbreveated as UOC(MP)<!--There is a reason why its UOC(MP) NOT UOC-MP-->, operates as an [[Autonomy (Eastern Christianity)|autonomous]] church under the [[Moscow Patriarchate]] and is also the only Orthodox denomination canonically recognised within the [[Eastern Orthodox Communion]]. The head of the church is [[Metropolitan Volodymyr (Viktor Sabodan)|Metropolitan Volodymyr (Sabodan)]] who was enthroned in spring [[1992]] as the ''\"Metropolitan of Kiev and all Ukraine\"''. The UOC(MP) is currently the largest religious body in Ukraine with the greatest number of parishes churches and communities counting up to half of the total in Ukraine and totaling over 10 thousand. The church also claims to have up to 75% of the Ukrainian population<ref>Pravoslvieye v Uraine [http://orthodox.org.ua/uk/node/197 Retrieved on 10 February 2007]</ref> although independent survey results vary widely both from this figure, as well as from survey to survey as many Orthodox Ukrainians do not clearly self-identify with a particular denomination and, sometimes, are even unaware of the affiliation of the church they attend as well as of the controversy itself, which indicates the impossibility to use the survey numbers as an indicator of a relative strength of the church. Also, the geographical factor plays a major role in the number of adherents, as the Ukrainian population tends to be more churchgoing in the western part of the country rather than in the UOC (MP)'s heartland in southern and eastern Ukraine.  \n \n The number of parishes statistics seems to be much more reliable and consistent even though it may not necessarily directly translate into the numbers of adherents. By number of parishes and quantity of church buildings, the UOC(MP)'s strong base is central and northernwestern Ukraine. However, percentage wise (with respect to rival Orthodox Churches) its share of parishes there varies from 60 to 70 percent. At the same time, by percentage alone (with respect to rival Orthodox Churches) the urban russophone southern and eastern Ukrainian provinces peak with up to 90% of church buildings. The same can be said about [[Transcarpathia]], although there the UOC's main rival is the Greek Catholic Church and thus in all its share is only 40%. The capital [[Kiev]] is where the greatest Orthodox rivalry takes place, there the UOC(MP) has only half of the Orthodox communities. The only place where the UOC(MP) is a true minority, in both quantity, percentage and support are the former Galician provinces of Western Ukraine. There the total share of parishes does not exceed more than five percent. The UOC(MP) does not have any parishes abroad, as its followers identify themselves under the same umbrella as those of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]].\n+According to a recent sociological study the UOC-MP has the support of 5 million parishioners and 8% support in Kiev<ref>[http://www.cerkva.info/static/church_today.html The Church today (In Ukrainian)]</ref>.\n \n ===[[Ukrainian Orthodox Church - Kiev Patriarchate]]===\n Abbreveated as the UOC-KP, the church was created in [[1992]], and aims at becoming a Ukrainian national Orthodox Church. However, it is [[canon law|canonicaly]] unrecognised amongst other [[Eastern Orthodox church organization|Eastern Orthodox churches]]. "
}

Wikipedia as I understand it is encyclopedic but it is meant for general readers, educated laypersons, and not professional academics (unless they will be so kind as to provide their knowledge to the rest of us) for whom the journals one finds in universiyty libraries are more important vehicles of information-gathering.\n \n I think that parallels can be drawn elsewhere: as I had mentioned, prior to the mid 18th century the word Ukrainians was not widely used for the Ukrainian people.  Does that mean we change all references to Ukrainian cossacks, Ukrainian haidamaks, etc.? To this narrow issue: this has been discussed by myself and Piotrus a while ago and we agreed on the following:\n+**Introduce the term as <nowiki>[[Muscovy|Muscovite Russia]]</nowiki> in the text. \n+**Keep it \"Russia\" from that moment on. \"Muscovy\" strictly speaking applies only to the times of the Moscow Principality. It was used later occasionally, but the Rus-rooted term has always been a self-appelation. Modern books use both terms and Russia is a more frequent and a more recognizable one.\n+**The idea that Muscovy isn't Russia and it later \"stole\" the name is an old Russophobic tale. --[[User:Irpen|Irpen]] 06:08, 2 July 2006 (UTC)"
}

Analysis:
Record 126 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision contains several linguistic indicators that suggest a weaponization of cultural heritage. The user "Irpen" introduces the term "Muscovite Russia" and emphasizes the distinction between "Muscovy" and "Russia," framing the latter as a "self-appellation" that has historical legitimacy. This choice of terminology can be seen as an attempt to delegitimize the historical narrative associated with "Muscovy," which is a term that may carry negative connotations in certain contexts, particularly in discussions surrounding Russian identity and heritage.

Furthermore, the phrase "the idea that Muscovy isn't Russia and it later 'stole' the name is an old Russophobic tale" explicitly labels opposing views as "Russophobic," which is a charged term that can be used to dismiss criticism and frame the discussion in a defensive manner. This framing can serve to polarize the narrative, suggesting that any questioning of the historical continuity between Muscovy and modern Russia is rooted in bias rather than legitimate historical inquiry.

Overall, the revision reflects a shift in tone that seeks to assert a specific cultural narrative while discrediting alternative perspectives, which aligns with the patterns of weaponization identified in the provided examples.

Judgment: Weaponised
=============================================

[[St. Andrew]] is thought to have preached on the southern borders of Ukraine, along the [[Black Sea]], and may have travelled up the [[Dnipro River]] as far as [[Kiev]], according to some records, possibly legendary. A representative from southern Ukraine was present at the [[First Council of Nicaea]] ([[325]]). These churches, and the inland farther north, came under the control of the [[Goths]], around this time, some of whom were Christians and seemed to have been [[Arians]].\n+Christianity in Ukraine dates to the earliest centuries of the apostolic church. [[St. Andrew]] is thought to have preached on the southern borders of Ukraine, along the [[Black Sea]], and may have travelled up the [[Dnipro River]] as far as [[Kyiv]], according to some records, possibly legendary. A representative from southern Ukraine was present at the [[First Council of Nicaea]] ([[325]]). These churches, and the inland farther north, came under the control of the [[Goths]], around this time, some of whom were Christians and seemed to have been [[Arians]].\n \n-Some of the [[Slavic peoples|Slavic]] population of Kiev and Western Ukraine under the rule of [[Great Moravia]] were Christians in the [[9th century]].  Christianity became dominant in Ukraine, then called [[Rus']] with the [[Baptism of Kiev]] in the Dnipro River in [[988]].  Early on, the Metropolitans had their seat in [[Pereyaslav]], then Kiev. The people of Rus'-Ukraine lost their Metropolitan to  the predecessors of the first [[Russia]]n state in [[1299]], but regained a Ukrainian Metropolitan in [[Halych]] in [[1303]]. The area was also ruled in part by a Metropolitan in [[White Ruthenia]] Belarus (Novahrudak). In the [[1400]]s, primacy over the Ukrainian church was restored to Kiev, under the title, \"Metropolitan of Kiev-Halych and all Rus'\". The church split in [[1596]] into [[Ukrainian Catholic Church|Catholic]] and Orthodox branches ([[Union of Brest]]).  In [[1686]], the Othodox Church of Kiev and all Rus' was tranferred from the jurisdiction of the [[Patriarch of Constantinople]] to the recently established [[Patriarch of Moscow]], and a process of forced [[russification]] begun.\n+Some of the [[Slavic peoples|Slavic]] population of Kyiv and Western Ukraine under the rule of [[Great Moravia]] were Christians in the [[9th century]].  Christianity became dominant in Ukraine, then called [[Rus']] with the [[Baptism of Kyiv]] in the Dnipro River in [[988]].  Early on, the Metropolitans had their seat in [[Pereyaslav]], then Kyiv. The people of Rus'-Ukraine lost their Metropolitan to  the predecessors of the first [[Russia]]n state in [[1299]], but regained a Ukrainian Metropolitan in [[Halych]] in [[1303]]. The area was also ruled in part by a Metropolitan in [[White Ruthenia]] Belarus (Novahrudak). In the [[1400]]s, primacy over the Ukrainian church was restored to Kyiv, under the title, \"Metropolitan of Kyiv-Halych and all Rus'\". The church split in [[1596]] into [[Ukrainian Catholic Church|Catholic]] and Orthodox branches ([[Union of Brest]]).  In [[1686]], the Othodox Church of Kyiv and all Rus' was tranferred from the jurisdiction of the [[Patriarch of Constantinople]] to the recently established [[Patriarch of Moscow]], and a process of forced [[russification]] begun.\n \n ==Distinguishing between church bodies==\n \n The current divided and fluid situation traces its roots to the gradual suppression of the distinctive Ukrainian Orthodox Church by [[Tsarist Russia]] after the transfer of the Church of Rus' proper from the Patriarch of Constantinople to the Patriarch of Moscow in [[1686]].  This transfer was resisted at first at Constantinople, since it was attempted via the ecclesiastic crime of [[bribery]] by the Russian Church, only recently elevated to patriatrchal status, but then accepted under pressure from the [[Turkish]] [[Sultan]].  A policy of ecclesiastic forced [[Russification]] began for the Ukrainian Orthodox Church.  Ukrainian bishops were slated to serve only in the foreign land of Russia, and vice-versa.  Ukrainian-Greek priestly [[vestment]]s were replaced by Russian ones. By [[1800]], all bishops of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church were henceforth only Russians.\n \n-But the Ukrainian Church immediately moved to restore its integrity when the Russian occupation appeared to cease.  In [[1921]] a [[Sobor]] of the [[Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church]] (''UAOC'') in Kiev ordained ''Metropolitan Wasyl Lupkivskyj'' as head of the UAOC. [[Autocephaly]] is the self-governing status of a particular national church that is recognized by other Orthodox jurisdictions.  In wake of the break up of the [[Russian Empire]] some national groups also sought ''autonomy'' (Autonomous Orthodox church bodies are not the same as Autocephalic church bodies) from Moscow and a [[Ukrainian Autonomous Orthodox Church]] was also founded around this time.  The [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] government persecuted these churches.  The [[Russian Orthodox Church]] also prevented the UAOC from establishing their ecclesiastical order for some time. Between the wars these national churches were tolerated to some extent by the ROC; as the UAOC had entered into communion with Constantinople the Moscow Patriarchate was grudgingly obliged to acknowledge communion with the new Ukrainian autocephalic church.\n+But the Ukrainian Church immediately moved to restore its integrity when the Russian occupation appeared to cease.  In [[1921]] a [[Sobor]] of the [[Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church]] (''UAOC'') in Kyiv ordained ''Metropolitan Wasyl Lupkivskyj'' as head of the UAOC. [[Autocephaly]] is the self-governing status of a particular national church that is recognized by other Orthodox jurisdictions.  In wake of the break up of the [[Russian Empire]] some national groups also sought ''autonomy'' (Autonomous Orthodox church bodies are not the same as Autocephalic church bodies) from Moscow and a [[Ukrainian Autonomous Orthodox Church]] was also founded around this time.  The [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] government persecuted these churches.  The [[Russian Orthodox Church]] also prevented the UAOC from establishing their ecclesiastical order for some time. Between the wars these national churches were tolerated to some extent by the ROC; as the UAOC had entered into communion with Constantinople the Moscow Patriarchate was grudgingly obliged to acknowledge communion with the new Ukrainian autocephalic church.\n \n On [[October 8]], [[1942]] ''Archbishop Nikanor'' and ''Bishop Mstyslav'' (now Patriach) of the UAOC and ''Metropolitan Oleksiy (Hromadsky)'' of the ''Ukrainian Autonomous Orthodox Church'' concluded an [[Act of Union]] uniting the two nationalist churches at the [[Pochaev] [[Lavra]] (monastery). [[Nazi]] occupation authorities and pro-Russian hierarchs of the Autonomous Church forced ''Metropolitan Oleksiy'' to remove his signature.  ''Metropolitan Oleksiy'' was executed in [[Volynia]] on [[May 7]], [[1943]].\n "
}

As such, it is the only Orthodox body in Ukraine that remains in [[full communion]] with the worldwide Orthodox Church - although the Moscow Patriarchate has been criticized by other Orthodox patriarchates for its handling of the Ukrainian situation.<ref>[http://risu.org.ua/ua/index/all_news/orthodox/orthodox_world/44182/ The patriarchs of four the oldest churches in the world reminded the ROC that Ukraine is not its canonical territory] (Ukrainian)</ref> The head of the church is [[Onufriy (Berezovsky)|Metropolitan Onufriy]] who was enthroned in August 2014 as the ''\"Metropolitan of Kiev and all Ukraine\"''. The UOC(MP) claims to be the largest religious body in Ukraine with the greatest number of parishes churches and communities counting up to half of the total in Ukraine and totaling over 10 thousand. The UOC also claims to have up to 75% of the Ukrainian population <ref>Pravoslaviye v Ukraine [http://orthodox.org.ua/uk/node/197 Retrieved on 10 February 2007] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071029043158/http://orthodox.org.ua/uk/node/197 |date=29 October 2007 }}</ref> Independent survey results, however, show significant variance, as many Orthodox Ukrainians do not clearly self-identify with a particular jurisdiction and, sometimes, are even unaware of the affiliation of the church they attend or the existence of the controversy itself. This makes it difficult to use survey numbers as an indicator of the relative strength of any given Church. Also, the geographical factor plays a major role in the number of adherents, as the Ukrainian population tends to be more churchgoing in the western part of the country rather than in the UOC(MP)'s heartland in southern and eastern Ukraine.\n+The Russian Orthodox Church in Ukraine, sometimes abbreviated as UOC(MP)<!--There is a reason why its UOC(MP) NOT UOC-MP-->, operates as an [[Autonomy (Eastern Christianity)|autonomous]] church under the Moscow Patriarchate. The head of the church is [[Onufriy (Berezovsky)|Metropolitan Onufriy]] who was enthroned in August 2014 as the ''\"Metropolitan of Kiev and all Ukraine\"''. The UOC(MP) claims to be the largest religious body in Ukraine with the greatest number of parishes churches and communities counting up to half of the total in Ukraine and totaling over 10 thousand. The UOC also claims to have up to 75% of the Ukrainian population <ref>Pravoslaviye v Ukraine [http://orthodox.org.ua/uk/node/197 Retrieved on 10 February 2007] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071029043158/http://orthodox.org.ua/uk/node/197 |date=29 October 2007 }}</ref> Independent survey results, however, show significant variance, as many Orthodox Ukrainians do not clearly self-identify with a particular jurisdiction and, sometimes, are even unaware of the affiliation of the church they attend or the existence of the controversy itself. This makes it difficult to use survey numbers as an indicator of the relative strength of any given Church. Also, the geographical factor plays a major role in the number of adherents, as the Ukrainian population tends to be more churchgoing in the western part of the country rather than in the UOC(MP)'s heartland in southern and eastern Ukraine.\n \n Statistics on the number of parishes may be more reliable and consistent, even though they may not necessarily directly translate into the numbers of adherents. By number of parishes and quantity of church buildings, the UOC(MP)'s strong base is central and northernwestern Ukraine. However, percentage wise (with respect to rival Orthodox Churches) its share of parishes there varies from 60 to 70 percent. At the same time, by percentage alone (with respect to rival Orthodox Churches) the UOC(MP)'s share of church buildings peaks in the urban [[russophone]] southern and eastern Ukrainian provinces, being as high as 90%. The same can be said about [[Carpathian Ruthenia|Transcarpathia]], although there the UOC(MP)'s main rival is the Greek Catholic Church and thus its share of ''total'' church buildings is only 40%. The capital [[Kiev]] is where the greatest Orthodox rivalry takes place, with the UOC(MP) holding about half of the Orthodox communities there. The only place where the UOC(MP) is a true minority, in both quantity, percentage and support are the former Galician provinces of Western Ukraine. There the total share of parishes does not exceed more than five percent. The UOC(MP) does not have any parishes abroad, as its followers identify themselves under the same umbrella as those of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]].\n-\n-==== Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church ====\n-[[File:Podil_30_09_13_126.jpg|thumb|[[Bartolomeo Rastrelli]]'s [[Saint Andrew's Church of Kiev|Saint Andrew's Church of Kyiv]] is used by the UAOC as its [[Mother Church]].]]\n- \n-{{main|Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church}}\n-\n-The Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church (UAOC) has undergone cycles of establishment, suppression and re-establishment since it originally formed in 1921. The Soviet régime initially supported it, then in the early 1930s destroyed its hierarchy, which it forced into exile. The Church re-established itself in Ukraine during the Nazi occupation in World War II, and was again driven underground after the War. The church re-gained official recognition in the late 1980s, and was initially administered from abroad by [[Patriarch Mstyslav]]. Following his death in 1993 it was re-organised into an independent church, after a brief union with the UOC-KP. Since then the church has been more successful in dialogue with the UOC(MP).<ref>Interview with Archbishop Ioan (Modzalevsky), [http://orthodoxy.org.ua/uk/mejkonfessionalnyy_dialog/2007/03/13/6390.html «Я - відвертий та давній прихильник порозуміння між УАПЦ та УПЦ».]</ref>\n-\n-{{As of | 2013}} the church has 1015 parishes and 697 churches. Geographically the church operates almost exclusively in the western areas of Ukraine, with minute support elsewhere. The UAOC formerly included many parishes in the Ukrainian diaspora communities in Canada and in the United States. These have, however, formed two separate churches: the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church of Canada]] (established in 1990<ref>\n-http://www.uocc.ca/en-ca/about/history/\n-</ref>) and the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the USA]]. In 1995 the [[Ecumenical Patriarch]] accepted the latter churches under his patronage, citing the transfer controversy of the Kiev Metropolitan's see to the Moscow Patriarchate in 1686 and, thus, fulfilling a necessary step for the achievement of the canonical standing by these diaspora Churches (still not universally recognised). While this move, as well as the cited reason, soured relations between the [[Orthodox Church of Constantinople]] and the ROC (which refused to recognise it), the standing of the diaspora churches does not affect the status of the UAOC itself.\n \n ====Old Believers====\n Traditionally the Ukrainian clergy, following the annexation of Kievan Metropolia, were one of the main sources of opposition to the [[Old Believer]] schism which took place at the time, under [[Patriarch Nikon]]. None of the Ukrainian parishes followed the [[Russian Orthodox Old-Rite Church]]. Although in 1905 the Tsar's decree on freedom of religion allowed the Old Believers church to reform, it gained little support in Ukraine. Presently, however the Old Believer community very much exploited the politicised schism in Ukrainian Orthodoxy and, as of 2004, number 53 communities scattered throughout Ukraine, with one of the biggest in [[Vylkove]].<ref>[http://www.starovery.ru/pravda/nzd.php?cid=81 На злобу дня<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>"
}

Analysis:
Record 994 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision reflects a significant shift in the representation of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church, particularly with the introduction of the "Orthodox Church of Ukraine" (OCU) and the removal of references to the "Ukrainian Orthodox Church – Kyiv Patriarchate" (UOC-KP). This change is indicative of a broader narrative surrounding the legitimacy and recognition of religious institutions in Ukraine, especially in the context of the ongoing conflict with Russia.

1. **Terminology Shift**: The term "Orthodox Church of Ukraine" is presented as a newly established entity that received a "tomos of autocephaly," which emphasizes its independence and legitimacy. This contrasts with the previous mention of the UOC-KP as "canonically unrecognised," which could be interpreted as delegitimizing the church's status.

2. **Contextual Implications**: The revision highlights the unification of various Ukrainian Orthodox jurisdictions under the OCU, framing it as a nationalistic move towards a "Ukrainian National Orthodox Church." This aligns with narratives that promote Ukrainian sovereignty and cultural identity against perceived Russian influence.

3. **Cultural Heritage Weaponization**: The removal of historical context regarding the UOC-KP's struggles and its previous leadership under Patriarch Filaret may serve to erase a part of the cultural heritage narrative that could be used to argue for the church's historical significance and legitimacy. Instead, the focus is shifted towards the

Judgment: Weaponised
=============================================

Analysis:
Record 47 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision includes a significant shift in the discussion surrounding the naming of Kyiv versus Kiev, which is emblematic of broader cultural and political tensions between Ukraine and Russia. The comment "Nationalist bias has no place in an encyclopedia" suggests an attempt to frame the use of "Kyiv" as a politically charged term, while simultaneously dismissing the historical context of the name "Kiev" as a reflection of Russian influence. 

The phrase "Russian occupation" and "foreign land of Russia" being labeled as inappropriate indicates a deliberate effort to sanitize the language surrounding the conflict, which can be seen as an attempt to undermine the legitimacy of Ukrainian claims to sovereignty and cultural identity. This aligns with the weaponization of cultural heritage, as it seeks to control the narrative around the historical and cultural significance of names and places, which are deeply tied to national identity.

Furthermore, the editor's insistence on "neutral and factual based" writing while dismissing terms that reflect Ukrainian perspectives can be interpreted as an effort to impose a specific narrative that favors Russian historical claims. This manipulation of language and terminology is a common tactic in cultural heritage weaponization, aiming to reshape public perception and historical understanding in a way that serves particular political agendas.

Judgment: Weaponised
=============================================

Analysis:
Record 736 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:** The revision changes the diocese affiliation from the "Orthodox Church of Ukraine" to a more explicit mention of the "Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)" as the previous affiliation until 2022. This shift in language is significant as it reflects a narrative that emphasizes the transition of religious authority in the context of the ongoing conflict between Ukraine and Russia. The use of "Orthodox Church of Ukraine" aligns with a Ukrainian national identity, while the reference to the "Moscow Patriarchate" invokes the Russian influence and historical ties, which can be seen as an attempt to frame the cultural and religious landscape in a way that supports the narrative of Ukrainian sovereignty and the rejection of Russian dominance. The explicit mention of the timeline ("since 2022") further underscores the recent changes in cultural and religious affiliations, which can be weaponized to assert claims of cultural oppression or liberation.

Judgment: Weaponised

It contains elements of other [[Eastern European]] cultures, as well as some [[Western European]] influences. Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]].\n+'''Ukrainian culture''' is the culture associated with the country of [[Ukraine]] and, in particular, with ethnic [[Ukrainians]]. It contains elements of other [[Eastern European]] cultures, as well as some [[Western European]] influences. Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]].\n \n-Ukraine has a shared culture with neighboring nations, dating back to the 9th century and the [[Rus (name)|Land of Rus]]. Mutual influence is particularly apparent among the cultures of [[Russian culture|Russia]], [[Ukraine]], [[Culture of Poland|Poland]], and [[Culture of Belarus|Belarus]].<ref name=\"ukraine1\">[http://www.ukraine.com/culture/ Culture in Ukraine | By Ukraine Channel<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>\n+Ukraine has a shared culture with neighboring nations, dating back to the 9th century and the [[Rus (name)|Land of Rus]]. Mutual influence is particularly apparent among the cultures of [[Russian culture|Russia]], [[Ukraine]], [[Culture of Poland|Poland]], and [[Culture of Belarus|Belarus]]. In addition, the culture of [[Ukrainian Cossacks]] (dress, weapons, etc.) has significant traces of the cultures of [[Turkic peoples]].{{cn|date=February 2013}}\n+\n+The 70 years of the [[Soviet era]] left their traces, often devastating, in the cultural history of the country and the people.\n \n ==Customs==\n Social gatherings like [[Vechornytsi]] have a long history in Ukrainian culture, and so do traditional [[Public holidays in Ukraine|holidays]] like [[Ivan Kupala Day]], [[Maslenitsa]], [[Koledari (orthodox carolers)|Koledaruvane]], and [[Malanka]], where people gather in large groups. \"[[Razom nas bahato, nas ne podolaty]]\" is a popular cultural and political statement of both traditional and modern Ukrainians. It translates as \"Together we are many! We cannot be defeated!\""
}

Analysis:
Record 483 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision introduces several linguistic indicators that suggest a potential weaponization of cultural heritage. 

1. **Contextual Emphasis on Shared Culture**: The phrase "Ukraine has a shared culture with neighboring nations" is a neutral statement, but the addition of "In addition, the culture of [[Ukrainian Cossacks]] (dress, weapons, etc.) has significant traces of the cultures of [[Turkic peoples]]" shifts the focus towards a specific cultural lineage that may be used to assert a distinct Ukrainian identity in contrast to Russian heritage. This can be interpreted as an attempt to emphasize Ukrainian uniqueness in the face of historical narratives that may conflate Ukrainian and Russian identities.

2. **Historical Reference to the Soviet Era**: The mention of "The 70 years of the [[Soviet era]] left their traces, often devastating, in the cultural history of the country and the people" introduces a negative connotation associated with the Soviet period. This framing can be seen as a way to invoke a narrative of victimhood and cultural oppression, which aligns with the weaponization of cultural heritage by highlighting historical grievances.

3. **Cultural Symbols and Political Statements**: The reference to the phrase "Razom nas bahato, nas ne podolaty" (Together we are many! We cannot be defeated!) serves as a rallying cry that reinforces a sense of unity and resistance among Ukrainians. This can be interpreted as

Judgment: Weaponised
=============================================

Analysis:
Record 72 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision comment and the diff text indicate a contentious discussion surrounding copyright and the integrity of content on Wikipedia. The user "Kuban Cossack" expresses frustration over perceived administrative overreach and the imposition of semi-protection on the article, which they argue restricts contributions from users who do not have accounts. This reflects a narrative of exclusion and control, which can be weaponized to frame the administrative actions as oppressive or unjust.

Specific linguistic indicators include:
- The phrase "juggling with recently obtained administrative power" suggests a negative view of authority and implies misuse of power.
- The term "sock puppet issue" is used to question the legitimacy of the administrative actions without providing evidence, which can undermine trust in the editorial process.
- The expression of being "discouraged" and the mention of "less free time" evoke a sense of personal grievance and victimization, which can be leveraged to rally support against perceived injustices.

Overall, the language used in this revision reflects a shift towards framing the administrative actions as oppressive, which can be seen as a weaponization of the cultural heritage of collaborative knowledge creation on platforms like Wikipedia.

Judgment: Weaponised

Analysis:
Record 72 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision introduces subtle shifts in language that reflect a potential weaponization of cultural heritage narratives. Specifically, the change in the description of the Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church (UAOC) includes a reference to the "Bolshevik Revolution" and the context of "Communists tolerating and at times even encouraging Ukrainian nationalism in the 1920s." This phrasing can be interpreted as an attempt to frame the historical relationship between Ukrainian nationalism and Soviet authority in a way that may evoke a sense of legitimacy or victimhood regarding Ukrainian cultural identity.

Additionally, the original text's mention of "Soviet government suppression" is retained, but the added context in the revision shifts the focus to a more complex narrative that could be used to justify contemporary claims of cultural oppression or to frame the historical struggle for Ukrainian identity in a light that aligns with current political narratives. The use of terms like "survived in the diaspora" and the emphasis on the church's re-establishment post-Soviet Union further highlight the resilience of Ukrainian cultural heritage against perceived oppression, which can be leveraged in contemporary discussions about cultural sovereignty and identity.

Overall, the revision's language choices reflect a strategic framing of historical events that could be utilized to support current political narratives, thus indicating a weaponization of cultural heritage.

Judgment: Weaponised

A History of Ukraine. University of Toronto Press: Toronto, 1996. p 98.]</ref> the Lavra has been a preeminent center of [[Eastern Orthodox Christianity]] in Eastern Europe. Together with the [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev|Saint Sophia Cathedral]], it is inscribed as a [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]].<ref name=\"Kyiv Pechersk Lavra, St. Sophia Cathedral remain on UNESCO’s World Heritage List\">[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/kyiv-pechersk-lavra-st-sophia-cathedral-remain-on-unescos-world-heritage-list/ Kyiv Pechersk Lavra, St. Sophia Cathedral remain on UNESCO’s World Heritage List], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (20 June 2013)</ref>{{#tag:ref|Late 2010 a monitoring mission of [[UNESCO]] was visiting the Kiev Pechersk Lavra to check on situation of the site. A History of Ukraine. University of Toronto Press: Toronto, 1996. p 98.]</ref> the Lavra has been a preeminent center of [[Eastern Orthodox Christianity]] in Eastern Europe. Together with the [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kiev|Saint Sophia Cathedral]], it is inscribed as a [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]].<ref name=\"Kyiv Pechersk Lavra, St. Sophia Cathedral remain on UNESCO’s World Heritage List\">[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/kyiv-pechersk-lavra-st-sophia-cathedral-remain-on-unescos-world-heritage-list/ Kyiv Pechersk Lavra, St. Sophia Cathedral remain on UNESCO’s World Heritage List], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (20 June 2013)</ref>{{#tag:ref|Late 2010 a monitoring mission of [[UNESCO]] was visiting the Kiev Pechersk Lavra to check on situation of the site. While being a cultural attraction, the monastery is once again active, with over 100 monks in residence. It was named one of the [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine]] on 21 August 2007, based on voting by experts and the internet community.\n \n Currently, the jurisdiction over the site is divided between the state museum, National Kiev-Pechersk Historic-Cultural Preserve,<ref>[http://www.kplavra.kiev.ua/#]</ref> and the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)]] as the site of the chief monastery of that Church and the residence of its leader, [[Onuphrius (Berezovsky)|Metropolitan Onuphrius]].\n "
}

Analysis:
Record 481 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision introduces a subtle but significant shift in the description of the Kiev Pechersk Lavra, particularly in the phrase "the monastery is once again active, with over 100 monks in residence." This addition emphasizes the current operational status of the monastery, which could be interpreted as a reinforcement of its cultural and religious significance amidst ongoing geopolitical tensions. 

Moreover, the mention of the "Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)" in the context of jurisdiction over the site suggests a framing that could be used to highlight divisions within the Orthodox community, potentially weaponizing the narrative around cultural heritage by implying a conflict over religious and cultural identity. 

The overall tone remains neutral, but the specific details included in the revision could be leveraged to support narratives of cultural preservation and religious legitimacy, which are often central to the discourse surrounding the conflict in Ukraine. The lack of a comment from the user also leaves the intent behind the revision ambiguous, which can further contribute to the potential for weaponization.

Judgment: Weaponised

  "Diff": "--- \n+++ \n@@ -6,30 +6,35 @@\n |- \n |{{Eastern Christianity}}\n |}\n-The [[History of Christianity]] in the lands of present-day [[Ukraine]] dates to the earliest centuries of the [[Twelve Apostles|apostolic church]]. Since the acceptance of Christianity in [[988]] by the rulers of the [[medieval]] kingdom of [[Kievan Rus']], [[Christianity]] has flourished on the territory of Ukraine, with a majority of the current inhabitants identifying themselves as [[Christian]]s. Since the acceptance of Christianity in [[988]] by the rulers of the [[Kievan Rus'||medieval Rus']], [[Christianity]] has flourished on the territory of Ukraine.\n+\n+The acceptance of [[Byzantine church|Byzantine]] [[Christianity]] as a dominant [[religion]] in the area, as well as a [[state religion]], was marked by [[988]] mass [[Baptism of Kiev]] by [[Vladimir I of Kiev]], a ruler of [[Kievan Rus]]. After the great [[East-West Schism]] that soon followed, the territory of [[Kievan Rus]] remained with the [[Byzantine Patriarch]]'s [[Eastern Orthodoxy]]. While most of the Christians in [[Ukraine]] were and still are Orthodox, since [[1598]] an [[Eastern Rite Catholic Churches|Eastern Rite]] [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGCC), which claimed varying with time but always a significant membership in western Ukraine, is in [[full communion]] with the [[Catholic see]]. Still, the Eastern Christianity, in the forms of both the  traditional [[Eastern Orthodoxy]] and the [[Eastern Rite|Eastern Rite Catholic faith]] remained a dominant religion among the Ukrainians and their ancestors and at some points in history was inseparable from most Ukrainians' national self-identity. At the same time, Western Christian traditions such as [[Roman Catholic Church|Roman Catholicism]] and [[Protestantism]] have had a limited presence on the territory of Ukraine since at least the [[sixteenth century]], however worshipers of these traditions remain a relatively small minority in today's Ukraine.\n+\n+A majority of the current inhabitants identifying themselves as [[Christian]]s. Although separated into various [[Christian denomination|denominations]], most Ukrainian Christians share a common [[Faith in Christianity|faith]], comprised of a unique blend of [[Byzantine church|Byzantine practices]] and [[Slavic mythology]]. The political jurisdiction of christian churches in Ukraine changed several times in the nation's history. Currently, three major Ukrainian Orthodox church bodies coexist, and often compete, in Ukraine, with the [[Eastern Rite]] [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] being also a significant Church among the Ukrainians. \n \n == Early history ==\n [[Image:PerovVG PervHristianKievGRM.jpg|350px|right|thumb|''First Christians in Kiev'' by [[Vasily Perov]] ]]\n Christianity was most likely first introduced into the lands of present-day Ukraine by the [[Goths]], who established the [[Chernyakhov culture]] in the [[2nd century]]. Although not a Christian people as a whole, the incoming [[Ostrogoths]] certainly had relations with Christian centers such as [[Rome]] and had come across [[missionary|missionaries]] in the lands they had previously inhabited; it is therefore believed that some of the Gothic inhabitants of [[Oium]] were Christian, as they had established churches in other lands occupied by the Goths. However, the the Gothic control over the area proved to be short-lived, as the [[Hunnic Empire]] swept into the area in the [[4th century]], making any lasting impression by the Goths unlikely. \n \n-===Saint Andriy===\n-[[Saint Andrew|Saint Andriy]] (Andrew) the [[apostle]] is believed to have traveled up the western shores of the [[Black Sea]], to the area of present-day southern Ukraine, while preaching in the lands of [[Scythia]]. Legend has it that he traveled further still, up the [[Dnieper River]], until he came to the location of present-day [[Kiev|Kyiv]] in 55 AD, where he erected a [[cross]] and prophesied the foundation of a great Christian city. Although the [[Primary Chronicle]] refers to the apostle continuing his journey as far north as [[Novgorod]], St. Andriy's visit to the later [[Ruthenia]]n lands has not been proven, and in fact may have been a later invention designed to boost the [[Autocephaly|autocephalic]] aspirations of Ukrainian churches. <ref>{{uk icon}} Panas, Kost' (1992). ''History of the Ukrainian Church (Історія української церкви)'', Transintekh; p. 12.</ref> Belief in the [[missionary]] visit of St. Andriy became widespread by the [[Middle Ages]], and by [[1621]], a Kyivan [[synod]] had declared him the \"Rus'-apostle\".<ref>[[Andrew Wilson (historian)|Wilson, Andrew]] (2000). ''The Ukrainians: Unexpected Nation'', Yale University Press, ISBN 0-300-09309-8; pg.33.</ref> The [[18th century]] [[St Andrew's Church of Kiev|Church of St. Andriy]] in Kyiv replaced an earlier structure from [[1086]], both of which were purportedly built on the very location of the apostle's cross, planted on a hill overlooking the city.\n+===Saint Andrew===\n+[[Saint Andrew]] the [[apostle]] is believed to have traveled up the western shores of the [[Black Sea]], to the area of present-day southern Ukraine, while preaching in the lands of [[Scythia]]. Legend has it that he traveled further still, up the [[Dnieper River]], until he came to the location of present-day [[Kiev]] in 55 AD, where he erected a [[cross]] and prophesied the foundation of a great Christian city. Although the [[Primary Chronicle]] refers to the apostle continuing his journey as far north as [[Novgorod]], St. Andriy's visit to the later [[Ruthenia]]n lands has not been proven, and in fact may have been a later invention designed to boost the [[Autocephaly|autocephalic]] aspirations of Ukrainian churches. <ref>{{uk icon}} Panas, Kost' (1992). ''History of the Ukrainian Church (Історія української церкви)'', Transintekh; p. 12.</ref> Belief in the [[missionary]] visit of St. Andrew became widespread by the [[Middle Ages]], and by [[1621]], a [[Kievan synod|Synod of Kiev (1621)]] had declared him the \"Rus'-apostle\".<ref>[[Andrew Wilson (historian)|Wilson, Andrew]] (2000). ''The Ukrainians: Unexpected Nation'', Yale University Press, ISBN 0-300-09309-8; pg.33.</ref> The [[18th century]] [[St Andrew's Church of Kiev]] replaced an earlier structure from [[1086]], both of which were purportedly built on the very location of the apostle's cross, planted on a hill overlooking the city.\n \n ===Crimean roots===\n-According to a [[9th-century]] tradition, [[Pope Clement I]] (ruled [[88]]-[[98]]) was exiled to [[Chersonesos]] on the [[Crimea|Crimean peninsula]] in [[102]], as was [[Pope Martin I]] in [[655]]. Furthermore, it has been definitively recorded that a representative from the Black Sea area, the \"head of the Scythian bishopric,\" was present at the [[First Council of Nicaea]] in [[325]], as well as the [[First Council of Constantinople]] in [[381]]; it has been surmised that this representative would have to have been Bishop Cadmus of the [[Bosporan Kingdom]]. [[Ostrogoths]], who remained on present-day Ukrainian lands after the [[Hunnic Empire|invasion of the Huns]], established a [[Ecclesiastical province|metropolinate]] under the [[Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople|Bishop of Constantinople]] at [[Dorus (Crimea)|Dorus]] in northern Crimea around the year [[400]]. A [[Diocese|bishop's seat]] had also existed since [[868]] across the [[Strait of Kerch]], in the ancient city of [[Tmutarakan|Tmutorokan]]. The [[Polans (eastern)|Polans]] and the [[Antes culture]]s, located so close to the Crimea, surely became familiarized with Christianity by this time.\n-\n-===Saints Kyrylo and Metodiy===\n-The relics of Pope St. Martin were allegedly retrieved by the \"[[Equal-to-apostles|apostle]]\" brothers [[Saints Cyril and Methodius|Kyrylo and Metodiy]] (Saints Cyril and Methodius), who passed through present-day Ukraine on their way to preach to the [[Khazars]]. Sent from Constantinople at the request of the ruler of [[Great Moravia]], these brothers would add to foundation of Christianity in Ukraine by creating the [[Glagolitic alphabet]], a precursor to the [[eponym|eponymous]] \"[[Early Cyrillic alphabet|Cyrillic script]]\", which enabled the local population to worship in [[Old Church Slavonic]], a language closer to the [[vernacular]] [[Old East Slavic language]] than the [[Greek language|Greek]] used to worship in Constantinople, or [[Latin]] in the west.\n-\n-In response to local disputes with clerics of the Latin Church, Kyrylo and Metodiy appealed in person to the [[Pope|Bishop of Rome]] in [[867]], bringing with them the relics of Pope St. Martin from Chersonesos.  Their labors and request were met with approval, and their continued efforts planted the Christian faith into Ukraine. By [[906]], they had founded a diocese in [[Przemyśl]], now in present-day [[Poland]], at the  western edge of Ukraine.  Their efforts, and those of their apostles, led to the translation of [[Bible|Christian Scriptures and service (liturgies) from Greek to Slavonic, and the eventual development of the modern [[Cyrillic alphabet]].\n-\n-==Kyivan Rus'==\n+According to a [[9th-century]] tradition, [[Pope Clement I]] (ruled [[88]]-[[98]]) was exiled to [[Chersonesos]] on the [[Crimea|Crimean peninsula]] in [[102]], as was [[Pope Martin I]] in [[655]]. Furthermore, it has been definitively recorded that a representative from the Black Sea area, the \"head of the Scythian bishopric,\" was present at the [[First Council of Nicaea]] in [[325]], as well as the [[First Council of Constantinople]] in [[381]]; it has been surmised that this representative would have to have been Bishop Cadmus of the [[Bosporan Kingdom]]. [[Ostrogoths]], who remained on present-day Ukrainian lands after the [[Hunnic Empire|invasion of the Huns]], established a [[Ecclesiastical province|metropolinate]] under the [[Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople|Bishop of Constantinople]] at [[Dorus (Crimea)|Dorus]] in northern Crimea around the year [[400]]. A [[Diocese|bishop's seat]] had also existed since [[868]] across the [[Strait of Kerch]], in the ancient city of [[Tmutarakan]]. The [[Polans (eastern)|Polans]] and the [[Antes culture]]s, located so close to the Crimea, surely became familiarized with Christianity by this time.\n+\n+===Saints Cyril and Methodius===\n+The relics of Pope St. Martin were allegedly retrieved by the \"[[Equal-to-apostles|apostle]]\" brothers [[Saints Cyril and Methodius]], who passed through present-day Ukraine on their way to preach to the [[Khazars]]. Sent from Constantinople at the request of the ruler of [[Great Moravia]], these brothers would add to foundation of Christianity in Ukraine by creating the [[Glagolitic alphabet]], a precursor to the [[eponym|eponymous]] \"[[Early Cyrillic alphabet|Cyrillic script]]\", which enabled the local population to worship God in [[Old Church Slavonic]], a language closer to the [[vernacular]] [[Old East Slavic language]] than the [[Greek language|Greek]] used to worship in Constantinople, or [[Latin]] in the west.\n+\n+In response to local disputes with clerics of the Latin Church, Kyrylo and Metodiy appealed in person to the [[Pope|Bishop of Rome]] in [[867]], bringing with them the relics of Pope St. Martin from Chersonesos. Their labors and request were met with approval, and their continued efforts planted the Christian faith into Ukraine. By [[906]], they had founded a diocese in [[Przemyśl|Peremyshl]], now Przemyśl in present-day [[Poland]], at the western edge of Ukraine. Their efforts, and those of their apostles, led to the translation of [[Bible|Christian Scriptures and service (liturgies) from Greek to Slavonic, and the eventual development of the modern [[Cyrillic alphabet]].\n+ \n+\n+==Kievan Rus'==\n [[Image:Baptizm_of_Olga_Kirillov.jpg|300x|thumb|left|''Baptism of [[Princess Olga]]'' by S. Kirillov.]]\n By the the [[9th century]], it is known that the [[Slavic peoples|Slavic]] population of western Ukraine (likely the [[White Croats]]) had accepted Christianity while under the rule of [[Great Moravia]]. However, it was the [[East Slavs]] who came to dominate the territory of present-day Ukraine, beginning with the rule of the [[Rus' (people)|Rus']], whose [[Slavic_mythology#Pantheon|pantheon of gods]] had held a considerable following for over 600 years. \n-Following the [[Rus'-Byzantine War (860)|assault on Constantinople]] by Rus' forces under the command of [[Askold and Dir]], the two princes were baptized in that holy city. Returning to Kyiv, the two actively championed Christianity for a period of 20 years, until they were murdered by the [[pagan]] [[Oleg of Novgorod|Prince Oleh]] (Oleg). [[Ecumenical Patriarch Photios I of Constantinople|Patriarch Photios]] purportedly provided a bishop and priests from [[Constantinople]] to help in the [[christianization]] of the Slavs.<ref>Chirovsky, Nicholas (1981). ''Ancient and Kievan-Galician Ukraine-Rus'', Philisophical Library; page 216.</ref> By [[900]], a [[church]] was already established in Kyiv, St. Elijah's, modeled on a church of the same name in Constantinople. This gradual acceptance of Christianity is most notable in the [[Rus'-Byzantine Treaty (945)|Rus'-Byzantine Treaty]] of [[945]], which was signed by both \"baptized\" and unbaptized Rus'\", according to the text included in the [[Primary Chronicle]].\n-Christianity acceptance among the Rus' nobility gained a vital proponent when [[Princess Olga|Princess Olha]] (St. Olga), ruler of [[Kievan Rus'|Kyivan Rus']], became baptized, taking the \"[[Given name|Christian name]]\" ''Helen''. Her baptism in [[955]] (or [[957]]) in either Kyiv or Constantinople (accounts differ) was a turning point in religious life of Rus' but it was left to her grandson, [[Vladimir the Great|Prince Volodymyr]], to make Kyivan Rus' a Christian state.\n+\n+Following the [[Rus'-Byzantine War (860)|assault on Constantinople]] by Rus' forces under the command of [[Askold and Dir]], the two princes were baptized in that holy city. Returning to Kiev, the two actively championed Christianity for a period of 20 years, until they were murdered by the [[pagan]] [[Oleg of Novgorod|Prince Oleg]]. [[Ecumenical Patriarch Photios I of Constantinople|Patriarch Photios]] purportedly provided a bishop and priests from [[Constantinople]] to help in the [[christianization]] of the Slavs.<ref>Chirovsky, Nicholas (1981). ''Ancient and Kievan-Galician Ukraine-Rus'', Philisophical Library; page 216.</ref> By [[900]], a [[church]] was already established in Kiev, St. Elijah's, modeled on a church of the same name in Constantinople. This gradual acceptance of Christianity is most notable in the [[Rus'-Byzantine Treaty (945)|Rus'-Byzantine Treaty]] of [[945]], which was signed by both \"baptized\" and unbaptized Rus'\", according to the text included in the [[Primary Chronicle]].\n+\n+Christianity acceptance among the Rus' nobility gained a vital proponent when [[Princess Olga]] (St. Olga), the ruler of [[Kiev]], became baptized, taking the \"[[Given name|Christian name]]\" ''Helen''. Her baptism in [[955]] (or [[957]]) in either Kiev or Constantinople (accounts differ) was a turning point in religious life of Rus' but it was left to her grandson, [[Vladimir the Great]] , to make Kievan Rus' a Christian state.\n \n ===Baptism of Kyiv===\n Christianity became dominant in the territory with the mass [[Baptism of Kiev]] in the [[Dnieper River]] in [[988]] ordered by Vladimir. Following the [[East-West Schism|Great Schism]] in [[1054]], the [[Kievan Rus']] that incorporated most of modern Ukraine ended up on the [[Eastern Orthodox]] side of the divided Christian world.  \n@@ -37,7 +42,7 @@\n Early on, the Orthodox Christian [[metropolitan bishop|metropolitan]]s had their seat in [[Pereyaslav]], and later in Kiev. The people of Kiev lost their Metropolitan to [[Vladimir-Suzdal]] in [[1299]], but regained a Ukrainian Metropolitan in [[Halych]] in [[1303]]. The religious affairs were also ruled in part by a Metropolitan in [[Navahradak]], (present-day [[Belarus]]).\n \n ==After the Breakup of the Kievan Rus==\n-In the [[1400s]], the primacy over the Ukrainian church was restored to Kiev, under the title \"[[Metropolitan of Kiev and Halicia]]\". One clause of the [[Union of Krevo]] stipulated that [[Jagiello]] would disseminate [[Roman Catholicism]] among Orthodox subjects of the [[Grand Duchy of Lithuania]], of which Ukraine was a part. The opposition from the [[Ostrogski]]s and other Orthodox [[magnate]]s led to this policy being suspended in the early 16th century.\n+In the [[1400s]], the primacy over the Ukrainian church was restored to Kiev, under the title \"[[Metropolitan of Kiev and Halych]]\". One clause of the [[Union of Krevo]] stipulated that [[Jagiello]] would disseminate [[Roman Catholicism]] among Orthodox subjects of the [[Grand Duchy of Lithuania]], of which Ukraine was a part. The opposition from the [[Ostrogski]]s and other Orthodox [[magnate]]s led to this policy being suspended in the early 16th century.\n \n Following the [[Union of Lublin]], the [[polonization]] of the Ukrainian church was accelerated. Unlike the Roman Catholic church, the Orthodox church in Ukraine was liable to various taxes and legal obligations. The building of new Orthodox churches was strongly discouraged. The Roman Catholics were strictly forbidden to convert to Orthodoxy, and the marriages between Catholics and Orthodox were frowned upon. Orthodox subjects had been increasingly barred from high offices of state.<ref name=KostOstr>{{Ru icon}} [[Nikolay Kostomarov]], ''\"Russian History in Biographies of its main figures\"'', Chapter ''[http://www.kulichki.com/inkwell/text/special/history/kostom/kostom22.htm Knyaz Kostantin Konstantinovich Ostrozhsky]''\" ([[Konstanty Wasyl Ostrogski]])</ref> \n ===Union of Brest and its aftermath==="
}

The acceptance of  [[Byzantine]] [[Christianity]] as a dominant [[religion]] in the area, as well as a [[state religion]], was marked by [[988]] mass [[Baptism of Kiev]] by [[Grand Prince]] [[Vladimir I of Kiev|Vladimir the Great]] of [[Kiev]] (St. Vladimir, Volodymyr in Ukrainian), a ruler of [[Kievan Rus]]. After the great [[East-West Schism]] that soon followed, the territory of [[Kievan Rus]] remained with the [[Byzantine Patriarch]]'s [[Eastern Orthodoxy]]. While most of the christians in [[Ukraine]] were and still are orthodox, since [[1598]] an [[Eastern Rite]] [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] (UGKC), which claimed varying with time but always a significant membership in western Ukraine, is in [[full communion]] with the [[Catholic see]]. Still, Eastern Orthodoxy was a traditional religion in Ukraine and at some points in history was inseparable from most Ukrainians' national self-identity.\n "

Analysis:
Record 644 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision made by the user "Mzajac" involves a subtle but significant change in the translation of the phrase "Together we are many! We can be defeated!" to "Together we are many! We can’t be defeated!" This shift from a statement of vulnerability ("can be defeated") to one of resilience and strength ("can’t be defeated") alters the tone and implications of the phrase. 

This change can be interpreted as a reinforcement of a defiant narrative, which is often weaponized in cultural contexts to promote unity and resistance against perceived oppression or threats. The original phrase could imply a call for solidarity in the face of adversity, while the revised version emphasizes an unyielding spirit, which can serve to galvanize support and foster a sense of invincibility among Ukrainians. 

Such linguistic shifts can be strategically used to frame cultural identity and heritage in a way that aligns with nationalistic sentiments, particularly in the context of ongoing conflicts. The context of the comment, which indicates a translation, further suggests an intention to present a more empowering narrative, potentially weaponizing the cultural heritage associated with the phrase.

Judgment: Weaponised

  "Diff": "--- \n+++ \n@@ -61,11 +61,7 @@\n It is now believed that the only real event which enabled to contain the schism in the former-uniate territory was the ROC's reaction of raising its Ukrainian Exarchate to the status of an [[Autonomy|autonomous church]], which took place in 1990, and up until the break up of the USSR (late 1991) there was an uneasy peace in western Ukraine. However after the nation became independent, the question of an independent and autocephalous Orthodox Church arose once again and another schism was approaching.\n \n ===Post-independence===\n-What historians now see as the reason for the following events was the decision of the head of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church Metropolitan of Kiev and all Ukraine Filaret to achieve total autocephalocy of his [[metropolitan see]] with or without the approval of the [[motherchurch]] required by the [[canon law]]. These events followed Filaret's own unsuccesful attempt to gain a seat of the [[Moscow Patriarch]] to himself (1990) and the Ukrainian independence following the [[collapse of the Soviet Union]] (August, 1991). To achieve that, with active support of the then president Leonid Kravchuk, he covertely organised a communion with the Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church in case Moscow refused. \n-\n-The skeptical hierarchy of the Russian Orthodox Church called for a full council where this issue would have been discussed, upon arrival most of the clergy of the UOC who initially supported Filaret, openely criticised this move and immediately the votes turned against him. In the end the council voted for Filaret to retire from his position which was confirmed by a swore. U\n-\n-pon returning to Kiev however Filaret carried out his reserve option, and Police aided by nationalist Paramilitaries supported him in retaining his rank. The UOC synod was quick to respond and in the eastern city of Kharkov elected a new leader, the Metropolitan Vladimir (Slobodan). From there most of the fate of control of church buildings was decided by the church parishes, but when most refused to follow Filaret, paramilitaries, especially in [[Volyn Oblast|Volyn]] and [[Rivne Oblast|Rivne]] Oblasts where there was strong nationalist sympathy amongst the new regional authorities, carried out raids bringing property under their control.\n+What historians now see as the reason for the following events was the decision of the head of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church Metropolitan of Kiev and all Ukraine [[Filaret]] to achieve total [[autocephalocy]] (independence) from the Russian Orthodox Church. After the fall of the USSR he led a movement for «full canonical independence, namely, autocephaly» for his Church. In November 1991 he headed a working council which requested the hierarchy of the Russian Orthodox Church to grant the Ukrainian Orthodox Church-Moscow Patriarchate autocephalous status. President of Ukraine (then, [[Leonid Kravchuk]]) supported Filaret's request but the Moscow Patriarchate strongly opposed it. Immediately a number of articles in the press accused Filaret of severe violation of his monastic vows and abuse of his ecclesiastical authority. The Hierarchical Council of the Russian Orthodox Church, that took place from March to April 1992, demanded that he resigns his position. Filaret, who attended the Council, promised that he would step down, but upon his return from Moscow, he disclosed that the promise was given under pressure and he is not leaving. Subsequently, in May 1992 at a Hierarchical Council held in [[Kharkhiv]] the majority of the bishops of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church of Moscow Patriarchate voted to depose Metropolitan Filaret from his office and suspend his clerical functioning. Despite, supported by three other bishops and political authorities in Ukraine, Filaret united with the Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church. In June of 1992 they created a new Church, the Ukrainian Orthodox Church of Kievan Patriarchate (UOC-KP) with 94-year-old [[Patriarch Mstyslav]] as a leader. Though only chosen as assistant, Filaret was in fact controlling the Church affairs. Opposing this situation, some of the Autocephalous [[bishop]]s and clergy refused to join the Ukrainian Orthodox Church-Kyivan Patriarchate.\n \n ==Modern Times==\n "
}

Analysis:
Record 177 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision introduces a more detailed narrative regarding the actions of Metropolitan Filaret and the Ukrainian Orthodox Church's quest for autocephaly. The language shifts from a neutral recounting of events to a more charged description that emphasizes the conflict between the Ukrainian Orthodox Church and the Russian Orthodox Church. 

Key indicators of weaponization include:
- The phrase "total autocephalocy (independence) from the Russian Orthodox Church" suggests a strong desire for separation and independence, framing the Ukrainian church's actions in a context of resistance against Russian influence.
- The mention of "support from political authorities in Ukraine" and "nationalist Paramilitaries" implies a connection between religious and national identity, which can be used to justify actions taken by these groups as part of a broader struggle for Ukrainian sovereignty.
- The revision highlights accusations against Filaret, framing them as politically motivated ("accused Filaret of severe violation of his monastic vows"), which can serve to delegitimize opposing narratives and reinforce a sense of victimhood among supporters of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church.

Overall, the revision's tone and content reflect a narrative that could be weaponized to frame the conflict in terms of cultural and religious identity, emphasizing the struggle against perceived oppression from the Russian Orthodox Church.

Judgment: Weaponised

I suggest a vote before we make any changes, in order to have some sort of consensus.[[User:Faustian|Faustian]] ([[User talk:Faustian|talk]]) 18:26, 31 January 2009 (UTC)\n+\n ==Article improvment==\n \n I think that this article can be good or featured just with more references. --[[user:vojvodaen|Vojvodae]][http://istorijska-biblioteka.wikidot.com/start ist] 14:23, 31 January 2009 (UTC)"
}

Analysis:
Record 375 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision contains a discussion about the Ukrainian Orthodox Church (UOC) and its relationship with the Moscow Patriarchate (UOC-MP). The user "Faustian" presents arguments that favor the UOC over the UOC-MP, highlighting points such as the number of parishioners and the perceived subservience of the UOC-MP to a foreign patriarch. This framing can be seen as an attempt to delegitimize the UOC-MP by emphasizing its historical ties to Russia and its recent name change, which is presented in a way that suggests a loss of authenticity or autonomy.

The use of terms like "subservient to a foreign patriarch" and the historical context provided about the UOC-MP being known as the "Russian Orthodox Church" indicates a narrative that seeks to undermine the legitimacy of the UOC-MP while promoting the UOC as a more authentic representation of Ukrainian identity. This aligns with the weaponization of cultural heritage, as it leverages religious identity and historical narratives to assert cultural dominance and justify a preference for one church over another.

Additionally, the suggestion to hold a vote for consensus implies a strategic approach to decision-making that could further entrench divisions based on these cultural and religious identities. Overall, the language and arguments presented in the revision reflect a subtle but clear attempt to weaponize cultural heritage in the context of the ongoing tensions between Ukrainian and Russian identities.

Judgment: Weaponised
=============================================

Analysis:
Record 276 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision introduces a critical perspective on the relationship between the Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate) and Moscow, highlighting the lack of autonomy of the UOC(MP) and its "weird and absolutely non-canonical status." The use of terms like "Muscovite Church in Ukraine" and the assertion that the church is neither autocephalous nor autonomous suggest a deliberate framing that undermines the legitimacy of the UOC(MP). 

The phrase "clumsy euphemisms" indicates a dismissive tone towards the language used by the Moscow Patriarchate, which can be interpreted as an attempt to delegitimize their claims. Additionally, the reference to the Orthodox media and the explicit mention of the church's status serve to reinforce a narrative that positions the UOC(MP) as an extension of Russian influence rather than a legitimate religious entity. This aligns with the broader context of cultural and territorial disputes, where language is used to assert control and influence over cultural heritage. 

Overall, the revision reflects a shift in tone that could be seen as weaponizing cultural heritage by framing the UOC(MP) in a negative light, thus contributing to the ongoing narrative of cultural oppression and influence in the region.

Judgment: Weaponised

Thw demographic info in the CIA Worldfactbook is used throughout wikipedia, in newspaper articles, etc.  It is also used as a basis for nationmaster.com's figures on Ukrainian religion [http://www.nationmaster.com/graph/rel_rel-religion-religions].  Even if you disagree about the credibility, it is an important fact that this is the US government's estimate.  There is no legitimate reason to exclude their estimate from this article.\n+\n+With all respect, tt seems you are pushing a non-nuetral point of view regarding the UOC-MP's popularity in Ukraine.  This is, unfortunately, a pattern with you.  I remember you have earlier claimed that almost all of the churches in Transcarpathia reverted to Orthodoxy in the 1920's-1930's, before I found the reference that stated that only 1/3 of them did.  Please, let's be objective.  [[User:Faustian|Faustian]] 14:16, 8 February 2007 (UTC)\n \n == More to do ==\n "
}

Analysis:
Record 745 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision includes a significant update regarding the jurisdiction and control of the Dormition Cathedral and the Refectory Church, which were previously under the Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate) and have now been returned to state control. The phrase "returned to direct state control" implies a reclaiming of cultural heritage, which can be interpreted as a political statement about sovereignty and authority over cultural sites.

Additionally, the comment "Christmas service went ahead" suggests a celebration of a religious event that has political implications, especially in the context of the ongoing conflict between Ukraine and Russia. The mention of the Orthodox Church of Ukraine being granted permission to celebrate a Christmas service in the Dormition Cathedral can be seen as a symbolic act of asserting Ukrainian identity and religious independence from Russian influence.

The language used in the revision, particularly the emphasis on the "Ukrainian government" and the "Orthodox Church of Ukraine," reflects a narrative that seeks to frame the situation in terms of cultural reclamation and national identity, which aligns with the weaponization of cultural heritage in the context of the Ukraine-Russia conflict. This framing can serve to justify actions taken by the Ukrainian government and reinforce a narrative of cultural sovereignty against perceived Russian oppression.

Judgment: Weaponised

The legality of this step is occasionally questioned to this day along with the fact that the transfer was accompanied by graft and bribery, which in church affairs amounts to an ecclesiastical crime. The transfer itself, however, led to the significant Ukrainian domination of the [[Russian Orthodox Church]], which continued well into the 18th century, [[Feofan Prokopovich]], [[Epifany Slavinetsky]], [[Stephen Yavorsky]] and [[Demetrius of Rostov]] being among the most notable representatives of this trend.<ref name=Kargamanov>\"As a result, the Kievans practically controlled the Russian church obtaining key posts there (and holding them to almost the end of the 18th century)\"<br>Yuri Kagramanov, \"[http://magazines.russ.ru/novyi_mi/2006/8/ka10.html The war of languages in Ukraine]\", [[Novy Mir]], 2006, № 8</ref>\n \n-===Daria Sitkus===\n-\n-The second comming of Jesus Christ came in the form of Daria Sitkus. She states that then end will come in the year 2012, when the great sneakers [[Neil Sedaka]] will return and join with Smokey [[Shepard Smith]].\n \n ===Territories gained from Crimean Khanate===\n "

The UOC (MP) actively supported the former Prime minister [[Viktor Yanukovych]] while members of the UOC-KP, UAOC, and UGCC supported the opposition candidate [[Viktor Yushchenko]], who was running against him. Analysis:
Record 1057 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Not Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision primarily focuses on the historical and political context surrounding the establishment of the Orthodox Church of Ukraine and the events leading up to the granting of the tomos of autocephaly. The language used in the "Diff" does not exhibit any overtly weaponized terms or narratives that would suggest an attempt to manipulate cultural heritage for political ends. 

Key indicators include:
- The text discusses the political dynamics between different Orthodox churches in Ukraine without using charged language or framing that could incite division or conflict.
- The mention of surveys regarding public sentiment towards church unification is presented in a neutral manner, reflecting a range of opinions without bias.
- The revision maintains a factual tone, focusing on events and their implications rather than employing emotionally charged or politically divisive language.

Overall, the changes made in this revision do not reflect an intention to weaponize cultural heritage but rather aim to provide a comprehensive account of the ecclesiastical developments in Ukraine.

Judgment: Not Weaponised
=============================================

Ukrainians make up nearly 75% of the population, with [[Russia|Russian]]s comprising 22% of the overall population. The rest of the population is a collection of varying peoples: [[Poland|Polish]], [[Belarus|Belarussian]], [[Romania|Romanian]], and [[Hungary|Hungarian]]. [[Religion]] is also practiced throughout the country - [[Orthodox Christianity]] and [[Catholicism]] are the two most widely practised religions. The [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church]] is the largest church in the country. The second largest church is the [[Ukrainian Catholic Church]], which is united with the Roman Catholic Church.\n \n Ukraine has seven [[university|universities]] throughout the country.\n "
}

Analysis:
Record 7 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Not Weaponised**

**Explanation:** The revision made in the "Diff" field involves a minor change in the ethnic group representation, specifically replacing "Moldova|Moldovan" with "Romania|Romanian." This change does not introduce any weaponized language or narratives that could be used to frame cultural or territorial control in a specific light. The overall tone and context of the text remain neutral and factual, focusing on demographic information without invoking any contentious or politically charged terms. There are no indicators of cultural heritage being weaponized in this revision.

Judgment: Not Weaponised
