Sent from Constantinople at the request of the ruler of [[Great Moravia]], these brothers would add to foundation of Christianity in Ukraine by creating the [[Glagolitic alphabet]], a precursor to the [[eponym]]ous \"[[Early Cyrillic alphabet|Cyrillic script]]\", which enabled the local population to worship God in [[Old Church Slavonic]], a language closer to the [[vernacular]] [[Old East Slavic language]] than the [[Greek language|Greek]] used to worship in Constantinople, or [[Latin]] in the west.\n \n In response to local disputes with clerics of the Latin Church, Cyril and Methodius appealed in person to the [[Pope|Bishop of Rome]] in 867, bringing with them the relics of Pope St. Martin from Chersonesos. Their labors and request were met with approval, and their continued efforts planted the Christian faith into Ukraine. By 906, they had founded a diocese in [[Przemyśl|Peremyshl]], now Przemyśl in present-day [[Poland]], at the western edge of Ukraine. Their efforts, and those of their apostles, led to the translation of [[Bible|Christian Scriptures]] and service (liturgies) from Greek to Slavonic, and the eventual development of the modern [[Cyrillic alphabet]].\n+Been their pimped that! [sgp]\n \n ==Early Rus' period==\n "

  "Diff": "--- \n+++ \n@@ -2,10 +2,6 @@\n [[Ukraine]] is a country with a well-defined national identity, but also an assortment of strong culturally-identified [[ethnic]] groups. [[Ukrainians]] make up nearly three quarters of the population, and [[Russians]] comprise twenty-two percent. Also represented are [[Belarusians]], [[Moldovans]], [[Crimean Tatars]], [[Bulgarians]], [[Hungarians]], [[Romanians]], [[Poles]], [[Jews]], [[Greeks]] and others. \n \n [[Religion]] is also practiced throughout the country—[[Orthodox Christianity]] and [[Uniat(e)]] are the two most widely practised religions; [[Protestantism]] and [[Judaism]] are also well represented. The [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church]] is the largest in the country. Faithful of the [[Ukrainian Catholic Church]], the second largest, practice Orthodox rites but are united with the [[Roman Catholic Church]]. \n-\n-Ukraine has seven [[university|universities]] throughout the country.\n-\n-Ukrainian traditions are also practised outside of Ukraine's borders by the people of the [[diaspora]].\n \n Ukrainians generally carry themselves in a very civilized manner. Men always hold the door open for a woman when she enters a building, stand up when a woman enters the room, and, if there is a shortage of seats, will give up their seats to the women. In rural areas men will sometimes kiss a woman's hand, but this is starting to go out of fashion.\n \n@@ -19,34 +15,5 @@\n - When eating dinner as a guest in someone's home, try not to leave early\n \n ==Food==\n-{{main |Ukrainian cuisine}}\n \n Cultural [[food]] is an important part to the Ukrainian culture.  Special foods are used at [[Easter]] as well as [[Christmas]], that are not made at any other time of the year. The most well known foods are: [[borshch]] (a vegetable soup, usually with beets), [[holobtsi]] (cabbage rolls), [[varenyky]] (often called [[perogies]]), and pyrohy (a fried, dessert version of verenyky).\n-\n-==Christmas Traditions==\n-{{main|Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper}}\n-At Christmas time there is a custom on the night of [[Christmas Eve]] to have a twelve-course meal, symbolic of the twelve [[Twelve Apostles|apostles]].  This meal is both meatless and [[dairy]]less. It usually consists of a few fish dishes (baked fish, pickled [[herring]]), verenyky, holobtsi, [[kolach]] (round braided [[bread]]), kutya (cooked wheat with [[poppy]] seeds, and [[honey]] or [[sugar]], only made in the Christmas season), some [[mushroom]] dishes, and [[garlic]], as well as a few other ingredients.\n-There are also [[symbolism|symbolic]] accompaniments to the meal.  The meal starts in the evening, as soon as the first evening [[star]] is seen, representing the star that the [[Magi|wise men]] followed to reach [[Jesus]]. There is also a [[candle]] in the window to show that anyone wandering the street that doesn't have a place to go is welcome to join the family for the evening and celebrate. As the meal is supposed to be just a family affair, for the night the guest is considered an honorary family member. The use of wheat is also important.  There is usually a sheaf of wheat placed in the corner near the table, to remind the family of the ancestors that have passed on, and to symbolise their presence at the table. Also wheat is placed under the tablecloth and under the table. Also, an extra plate is set at the table for Jesus.\n-\n-[[Carols]] are also an important part of the Christmas tradition. Some carols reach back into pre-Christian times. The most widely recognised Ukrainian carol is the [[New Year]]'s carol \"Shchedryk\", adopted in the west as the [[Carol of the Bells]]. Christmas carols are a tradition that the entire family participates in. In addition, one is only allowed to sing these carols during the Christmas season, and never at any other time.\n-\n-== See also ==\n-\n-* [[Ivan Kupala]]\n-* [[Koleda]]\n-* [[Ukrainian dance]]\n-\n-== References ==\n-\n-* The History of Ukrainian Culture, Kiev, 2001. Available online (in Ukrainian)\n-** [http://litopys.org.ua/istkult/ikult.htm Vol. 1, Kievan Rus']\n-** [http://litopys.org.ua/istkult2/ikult2.htm Vol. 2 Ukrainian Culture of the thirteenth to eighteenth centuries]\n-* Ivan Kryp'yakevych, \"History of Ukrainian Culture\", Kiev, 2002, available [http://litopys.org.ua/krypcult/krcult.htm online] (in Ukrainian)\n-* \"Ukrainian culture\", lectures edited by Dmytro Antonovych, Kiev, 1993, available [http://litopys.org.ua/cultur/cult.htm online] (in Ukrainian)\n-\n-[[Category:Ukrainian culture| ]]\n-\n-\n-{{ukraine-stub}}\n-\n-[[es:Cultura de Ucrania]]"
}

  "Diff": "--- \n+++ \n@@ -90,9 +90,9 @@\n \n Nevertheless the first [[Russophilia|Russophile]] tendencies began to surface, and came in face of the Uniate Bishop [[Joseph Semashko]]. Believing that the Uniate Church's role as an interim bridge between [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodoxy]] and their eventual path to [[Catholicism]] is over, now that the ruler of the lands is no longer a Catholic, but an Orthodox Monarch, he began to push for an eventual reversion of all Uniates. Although the idea was shared by growing number of the lower priests, the ruling Uniate [[synod]], controlled by the strong Polish influence, rejected all Semashko's suggestions. <ref> [http://www.pravoslavie.ru/arhiv/050513111111.htm#rel1 Воссоединение униатов и исторические судьбы белорусского народа] </ref> In addition many of the Latin Catholic authorities responded to this by actively converting the Uniates to [[Latin Rite]] Catholicism.\n \n-In 1831, the general discontent of the Poles with the Russian rule erupted into a revolt, now known as the [[November Uprising]], which the Uniate Church officially supported. However, the uprising failed, and the Russian authorities were quick to respond to its organisers and areas of strongest support. The outcome was that the Uniate synod's members were removed along with most of the Polish magnates privileges' and authority being taken away. With the Polish influence in the Ruthenian lands significantly reduced and in some cases eliminated, the Uniate Church began to disintegrate. In [[Volhynia]] the famous [[Pochayiv Lavra]] was returned to Russian Orthodox clergy in 1833. The final blow came from the [[Synod of Polotsk]] in 1839 headed by the ex-Uniate Bishop Semashko, where it was agreed to terminate the accords of [[Union of Brest]] and all of the remaining Uniate property on the territory of the Belarus and Right Bank Ukraine within the [[Russian Empire]] was incorporated into the [[Russian Orthodox Church]]. Those Uniate clergy who refused to join the Russian Orthodox Church (593 out of a total of 1,898 in Ukraine and Belarus) were exiled to the Russian interior or Siberia <ref> Magocsi, R.P. (1996).  ''A History of Ukraine''.  Toronto: University of Toronto Press. ISBN 0-8020-7820-6 Pg. 375 </ref> \n-\n-Within the Russian Empire, the Uniate Church continued to function until 1875, when the Eparchy of [[Chełm|Chelm]] was [[Conversion of Chelm Eparchy|abolished]].  The greater longevity of the Uniate Church in this region was attributed to the fact that it came under Russian control later than did the other territories (1809) and that, unlike other Ukrainian regions within the Russian Empire, it had been part of the [[Congress Kingdom of Poland|Congress Poland]], which had some autonomy until 1865. Within Chelm, the conversion to Orthodoxy met with strong resistance from the local ethnic Ukrainian priests and parishioners, and was accomplished largely through the efforts of Russian police, Cossacks, and immigrating [[Ukrainian Russophiles|Russophile]] [[Pope (disambiguation)|priests]] from [[Galicia (Central Europe)|eastern Galicia]].  The resistance was strong enough that when, a generation later in 1905, the formally Orthodox population of Chelm was allowed to return to Catholicism (Russian authorities only allowing conversion to the [[Latin Rite]]), 170,000 out of 450,000 did so by [[1908]].<ref> Himka, John Paul.  (1999). ''Religion and Nationality in Western Ukraine.'' McGill-Queen's University Press: Montreal and Kingston.  Pg. 32 and pp. 58-60. </ref>\n+In 1831, the general discontent of the Poles with the Russian rule erupted into a revolt, now known as the [[November Uprising]], which the Uniate Church officially supported. However, the uprising failed, and the Russian authorities were quick to respond to its organisers and areas of strongest support. The outcome was that the Uniate synod's members were removed along with most of the Polish magnates privileges' and authority being taken away. With the Polish influence in the Ruthenian lands significantly reduced and in some cases eliminated, the Uniate Church began to disintegrate. In [[Volhynia]] the famous [[Pochayiv Lavra]] was returned to Russian Orthodox clergy in 1833. The final blow came from the [[Synod of Polotsk]] in 1839 headed by the ex-Uniate Bishop Semashko, where it was agreed to terminate the accords of [[Union of Brest]] and all of the remaining Uniate property on the territory of the Belarus and Right Bank Ukraine within the [[Russian Empire]] was incorporated into the [[Russian Orthodox Church]]. Those Uniate clergy who refused to join the Russian Orthodox Church (593 out of a total of 1,898 in Ukraine and Belarus) were exiled to the Russian interior or Siberia <ref> Magocsi, R.P. (1996).  ''A History of Ukraine''.  Toronto: University of Toronto Press. ISBN 0-8020-7820-6 Pg. 375 </ref>  \n+\n+Within the Russian Empire, the Uniate Church - despite mass deportations, persecutions and discrimination - continued to function until 1875, when the Eparchy of [[Chełm|Chelm]] was [[Conversion of Chelm Eparchy|abolished]].<ref name=\"autogenerated3\" /> The greater longevity of the Uniate Church in this region was attributed to the fact that it came under Russian control later than did the other territories (1809) and that, unlike other Ukrainian regions within the Russian Empire, it had been part of the [[Congress Kingdom of Poland|Congress Poland]], which had some autonomy until 1865. Within Chelm, the conversion to Orthodoxy met with strong resistance from the local ethnic Ukrainian priests and parishioners, and was accomplished largely through the efforts of Russian police, Cossacks, and immigrating [[Ukrainian Russophiles|Russophile]] [[Pope (disambiguation)|priests]] from [[Galicia (Central Europe)|eastern Galicia]].  The resistance was strong enough that when, a generation later in 1905, the formally Orthodox population of Chelm was allowed to return to Catholicism (Russian authorities only allowing conversion to the [[Latin Rite]]), 170,000 out of 450,000 did so by [[1908]].<ref> Himka, John Paul.  (1999). ''Religion and Nationality in Western Ukraine.'' McGill-Queen's University Press: Montreal and Kingston.  Pg. 32 and pp. 58-60. </ref>\n \n [[Image:PochaevInside.jpg|thumb|left|250px|[[Pochayiv Lavra]], located right next to the border of the [[Russian Empire]] and [[Austro-Hungary]] after its return to Orthdoxy in 1833 became a major bastion against the Catholic-ruled [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]].]]\n "
}

Analysis:
Record 689 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision introduces a significant linguistic shift by adding the phrase "despite mass deportations, persecutions and discrimination" in the context of the Uniate Church's functioning within the Russian Empire. This addition emphasizes the negative experiences faced by the Uniate Church and its followers, framing the historical narrative in a way that highlights oppression and suffering. 

The use of terms like "mass deportations," "persecutions," and "discrimination" serves to evoke a strong emotional response and aligns with narratives that can be weaponized to justify contemporary grievances or actions. This framing can be seen as an attempt to underscore the historical injustices faced by a specific cultural group, potentially reinforcing a victim narrative that could be used to support current political or cultural claims.

Additionally, the context provided by the user comment referencing an academic source suggests an attempt to lend credibility to this narrative, which can further amplify its impact. Overall, the revision's language shifts towards a more charged and emotionally resonant portrayal of historical events, indicative of a weaponized approach to cultural heritage.

Judgment: Weaponised
=============================================

Analysis:
Record 5 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

The revision reflects a significant shift in tone and content regarding the naming of the city "Kyiv" versus "Kiev." The user Mzajac argues for the use of the Ukrainian name "Kyiv," framing it as a matter of combating "systemic bias" and challenging the "status quo." - The phrase "systematic censorship" suggests an active suppression of Ukrainian identity, which aligns with narratives of cultural oppression.
- The assertion that "Kyiv" is used in several English-language publications positions it as a legitimate alternative, countering the dominance of the Russian transliteration "Kiev."
- The reference to "restoring the use of 'Kyiv'" implies a reclamation of cultural identity, which can be seen as a response to historical narratives that have marginalized Ukrainian perspectives.

Overall, the language used in this revision indicates an attempt to assert Ukrainian cultural heritage in the face of competing narratives, thus weaponizing the discussion around the city's name in a politically charged context.

Judgment: Weaponised

МИД Украины|date=2019-07-09|website=gordonua.com|language=ru-UA|access-date=2019-07-26}}</ref> or '''Kyivo-Pechers’ka Lavra'''<ref>[http://www.rada.gov.ua/ukraine.htm Verkhovna Rada Portal] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727035555/http://www.rada.gov.ua/ukraine.htm |date=27 July 2011 }} This is the official English spelling used by the Ukrainian government</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/city/detail/69789/  Parliament votes down law on preservation of Kyiv Pechersk Lavra complex] Interfax-Ukraine, 16 June 2010 at 10:42</ref> ({{lang-uk|Києво-Печерська лавра}}: ''Kyievo-Pechers'ka lavra''; {{lang-ru|Киeво-Печерская лавра}}: ''Kiyevo-Pecherskaya lavra''), also known as the '''Kyiv Monastery of the Caves''', is a historic [[Monastery#Orthodox Christian monasteries|Orthodox Christian monastery]] which gave its name to [[Pechers’ky Raion|one of the city districts]] where it is located in [[Kiev|Kyiv]].\n+'''Kiev Pechersk Lavra, Kyiv Pechersk Lavra'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://whc.unesco.org/en/list/527/|title=Kyiv: Saint-Sophia Cathedral and Related Monastic Buildings, Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|language=en|access-date=2019-07-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gordonua.com/news/worldnews/pravilnoe-napisanie-stolicy-ukrainy-na-angliyskom-yazyke-zakrepleno-v-dokumente-yunesko-mid-ukrainy-1102775.html|title=Правильное написание столицы Украины на английском языке закреплено в документе ЮНЕСКО - МИД Украины|date=2019-07-09|website=gordonua.com|language=ru-UA|access-date=2019-07-26}}</ref> or '''Kyivo-Pechers’ka Lavra'''<ref>[http://www.rada.gov.ua/ukraine.htm Verkhovna Rada Portal] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727035555/http://www.rada.gov.ua/ukraine.htm |date=27 July 2011 }} This is the official English spelling used by the Ukrainian government</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/city/detail/69789/  Parliament votes down law on preservation of Kyiv Pechersk Lavra complex] Interfax-Ukraine, 16 June 2010 at 10:42</ref> ({{lang-uk|Києво-Печерська лавра}}: ''Kyievo-Pechers'ka lavra''; {{lang-ru|Киeво-Печерская лавра}}: ''Kiyevo-Pecherskaya lavra''), also known as the '''Kiev Monastery of the Caves''', is a historic [[Monastery#Orthodox Christian monasteries|Orthodox Christian monastery]] which gave its name to [[Pechers’ky Raion|one of the city districts]] where it is located in [[Kiev]].\n \n Since its foundation as the [[cave monastery]] in 1051,<ref>Magocsi P.R. A History of Ukraine. University of Toronto Press: Toronto, 1996. p 98.</ref> the Lavra has been a preeminent center of [[Eastern Orthodox Christianity]] in Eastern Europe. Together with the [[Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kyiv|Saint Sophia Cathedral]], it is inscribed as a [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]].<ref name=\"Kyiv Pechersk Lavra, St. Sophia Cathedral remain on UNESCO’s World Heritage List\">[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/kyiv-pechersk-lavra-st-sophia-cathedral-remain-on-unescos-world-heritage-list/ Kyiv Pechersk Lavra, St. Sophia Cathedral remain on UNESCO’s World Heritage List], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (20 June 2013)</ref>{{#tag:ref|Late 2010 a monitoring mission of [[UNESCO]] was visiting the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra to check on situation of the site. At the time the [[Ministry of Culture (Ukraine)|Minister of Culture]] [[Mykhailo Kulynyak]] stated the historic site along with the [[Saint Sophia's Cathedral, Kyiv|Saint Sophia Cathedral]] was not threatened by the \"black list\" of the organization.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mincult.kmu.gov.ua/mincult/uk/publish/article/238820|title=\"Софії Київській та Києво-Печерській лаврі \"чорний список\" ЮНЕСКО не загрожує\" – Міністр культури Михайло Кулиняк|accessdate=23 June 2017|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150711080914/http://mincult.kmu.gov.ua/mincult/uk/publish/article/238820|archivedate=11 July 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The [[World Heritage Committee]] of UNESCO decided in June 2013 that Kyiv Pechersk Lavra, and St. Sofia Cathedral and related monastery buildings would remain on the [[World Heritage List]].<ref name=\"Kyiv Pechersk Lavra, St. Sophia Cathedral remain on UNESCO’s World Heritage List\"/>|group=nb}} The monastery complex is considered a separate national historic-cultural preserve (sanctuary), the national status to which was granted on 13 March 1996.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/cgi-bin/laws/main.cgi?nreg=181/96&p=1260343170231885|title=Про надання статусу національного Києво-Печерському держав... -  від 13.03.1996 № 181/96|website=zakon1.rada.gov.ua|accessdate=23 June 2017}}</ref> The Lavra is not only located in another part of the city, but is part of a different national sanctuary than Saint Sophia Cathedral. While being a cultural attraction, the monastery is once again active, with over 100 monks in residence.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} It was named one of the [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine]] on 21 August 2007, based on voting by experts and the internet community.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}\n \n-Currently, the jurisdiction over the site is divided between the state museum, National Kyiv-Pechersk Historic-Cultural Preserve,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kplavra.kiev.ua/#|title=Сайт Національного Києво-Печерського історико-культурного заповідника|website=www.kplavra.kiev.ua|accessdate=23 June 2017}}</ref> and the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church]] as the site of the chief monastery of that Church and the residence of its leader, [[Onufriy (Berezovsky)|Onufrius, Metropolitan of Kyiv and All Ukraine]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://lavra.ua/en/general-information/ |title=General information — Kyiv Holy Dormition Caves Lavra |accessdate=9 December 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://lavra.ua/en/head-of-uoc-led-solemnities-on-synaxis-of-near-caves-venerable-fathers/ |title=Head of UOC led solemnities on Synaxis of Near Caves’ Venerable Fathers |agency=Kyiv Holy Dormition Caves Lavra|date=11 October 2019|accessdate=12 December 2019}}</ref>\n+Currently, the jurisdiction over the site is divided between the state museum, National Kyiv-Pechersk Historic-Cultural Preserve,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kplavra.kiev.ua/#|title=Сайт Національного Києво-Печерського історико-культурного заповідника|website=www.kplavra.kiev.ua|accessdate=23 June 2017}}</ref> and the [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)|Ukrainian Orthodox Church]] as the site of the chief monastery of that Church and the residence of its leader, [[Onufriy (Berezovsky)|Onufrius, Metropolitan of Kiev and All Ukraine]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://lavra.ua/en/general-information/ |title=General information [[File:Lavra Kyiv.JPG|thumb|Panorama of the monastery (southward view)]]\n [[File:Uspensky Sobor.jpg|thumb|right|225px|The reconstructed Cathedral of the Dormition, as seen in 2005.]]\n-The word ''pechera'' means ''cave''. The word ''[[lavra]]'' is used to describe high-ranking male monasteries for monks of the Eastern Orthodox Church. Therefore, the name of the monastery is also translated as Kyiv Cave Monastery, Kyiv Caves Monastery or the Kyiv Monastery of the Caves (''на печерах'').\n+The word ''pechera'' means ''cave''. The word ''[[lavra]]'' is used to describe high-ranking male monasteries for monks of the Eastern Orthodox Church. Therefore, the name of the monastery is also translated as Kiev Cave Monastery, Kiev Caves Monastery or the Kiev Monastery of the Caves (''на печерах'').\n \n ==Foundation and early history==\n-According to the [[Primary Chronicle]], in the early 11th century, [[Anthony of Kiev|Anthony]], an [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox]] [[monk]] from [[Esphigmenou Monastery|Esphigmenon monastery]] on [[Mount Athos]], originally from [[Liubech]] of the [[Principality of Chernigov|Principality of Chernihiv]], returned to [[Kievan Rus'|Rus']] and settled in Kyiv as a [[missionary]] of monastic tradition to Kyivan Rus'. He chose a cave at the Berestov Mount that overlooked the [[Dnieper River]] and a community of disciples soon grew. [[Knyaz|Prince]] [[Iziaslav I of Kiev|Iziaslav I of Kyiv]] ceded the whole mount to the Anthonite monks who founded a monastery built by architects from [[Constantinople]].\n+According to the [[Primary Chronicle]], in the early 11th century, [[Anthony of Kiev|Anthony]], an [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox]] [[monk]] from [[Esphigmenou Monastery|Esphigmenon monastery]] on [[Mount Athos]], originally from [[Liubech]] of the [[Principality of Chernigov|Principality of Chernihiv]], returned to [[Kievan Rus'|Rus']] and settled in Kiev as a [[missionary]] of monastic tradition to Kievan Rus'. He chose a cave at the Berestov Mount that overlooked the [[Dnieper River]] and a community of disciples soon grew. It is a [[Classical architecture|Classical style]] construction and consists of [[storey|tier]]s, surmounted by a [[gilding|gilded]] [[dome]].\n+The Great Lavra Belltower is one of the most notable features of the Kiev skyline and among the main attractions of the Lavra. 96.5 meters in height, it was the tallest free-standing belltower at the time of its construction in 1731–1745, and was designed by the architect Johann Gottfried Schädel. It is a [[Classical architecture|Classical style]] construction and consists of [[storey|tier]]s, surmounted by a [[gilding|gilded]] [[dome]].\n \n ===Dormition Cathedral===\n [[File:Успенський собор - Catedral de la ASuncion 2.jpg|thumb|Restored Dormition Church]]\n-Built in the 11th century, the main church of the monastery was destroyed during the [[World War II]], a couple of months after the Nazi Germany troops occupied the city of [[Kiev|Kyiv]] and the controversial [[1941 Khreshchatyk explosions]] that destroyed the city's main street. According to the Soviet authorities, the church was destroyed by the advancing German troops, while at the same time German authorities put the blame on the withdrawing Soviet troops who practiced the tactics of [[scorched earth]] and blew up all the Kyiv bridges over [[Dnieper]] as well as being accused in the 1941 Khreshchatyk explosions.\n+Built in the 11th century, the main church of the monastery was destroyed during the [[World War II]], a couple of months after the Nazi Germany troops occupied the city of [[Kiev]] and the controversial [[1941 Khreshchatyk explosions]] that destroyed the city's main street. According to the Soviet authorities, the church was destroyed by the advancing German troops, while at the same time German authorities put the blame on the withdrawing Soviet troops who practiced the tactics of [[scorched earth]] and blew up all the Kiev bridges over [[Dnieper]] as well as being accused in the 1941 Khreshchatyk explosions.\n \n Since 1928, the monastery was converted into a museum park by the Soviet authorities and after its return no efforts were provided to restore the church. The temple was finally restored in 1995 after Ukraine obtained its independence and the construction was accomplished in two years. The new Dormition Church was consecrated in 2000.\n \n@@ -212,7 +212,7 @@\n ===Refectory chambers with Church of the Saints Anthony and Theodosius===\n {{main|Refectory Church (Pechersk Lavra)}}\n [[File:Trapezna lavra.jpg|thumb|Refectory Church|right]]\n-The refectory chambers with the Church of the Saints Anthony and Theodosius is the third in a series of temples. The original temple was built in the 12th century and no drawings or visual depictions of it remain. Characteristic of the church facades are rich architectural embellishments. In 1905, students of the Lavra art school painted the interior walls of the church. The carved wooden iconostasis is multi-tiered and was made for the All Saints church in the early 18th century.\n@@ -221,14 +221,14 @@\n {{main|Church of the Saviour at Berestove}}\n [[File:Church of the Saviour at Berestove (Side view).jpg|thumb|left|225px|Side view of the [[Church of the Saviour at Berestove]] seen with its [[campanile]], designed by architect Andrei Melenskyi in the [[Classical architecture|Classical style]].]]\n \n-The Church of the Saviour at Berestove is located to the North of the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra. It was constructed in the village of Berestove around the start of the 11th century during the reign of Prince [[Vladimir II Monomakh|Volodymyr Monomakh]]. It later served as the mausoleum of the Monomakh dynasty, also including [[Yuri Dolgoruki]], the founder of Moscow. Despite being outside the Lavra fortifications, the Church of the Saviour at Berestove is part of the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra complex.\n+The Church of the Saviour at Berestove is located to the North of the Kiev Pechersk Lavra. In 1051, the monk [[Anthony of Kiev|Anthony]] settled in an old cave in a hill near the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra. This cave received additions including corridors and a church, and is now the [[Far Caves]]. In 1057, Anthony moved to a cave near the Upper Lavra, now called the [[Near Caves]].\n-\n-Foreign travellers in the 16th–17th centuries wrote that the catacombs of the Lavra stretched for hundreds of kilometres, reaching as far as Moscow and [[Velikiy Novgorod|Novgorod]],<ref name=\"Touring Kyiv\">{{cite book | first=Ruta | last=Malikenaite | year=2003 | title=Guidebook: Touring Kyiv | publisher=Baltia Druk | location=Kiev | isbn=966-96041-3-3}}</ref> spreading awareness of the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra.\n+[[File:Iliya Muromets Kiev.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Imperishable relic of saint [[Ilya Muromets]] in Kiev Pechersk Lavra]] \n+The Kiev Pechersk Lavra caverns are a system of narrow underground corridors (about 1-1½ metres wide and 2-2½ metres high), along with numerous living quarters and underground chapels. In 1051, the monk [[Anthony of Kiev|Anthony]] settled in an old cave in a hill near the Kiev Pechersk Lavra. This cave received additions including corridors and a church, and is now the [[Far Caves]]. The exposition is the actual ensemble of the Upper ([[Near Caves]]) and Lower ([[Far Caves]]) Lavra territories, which house many architectural relics of the past. The collection within the churches and caves includes articles of precious metal, prints, higher clergy portraits and rare church hierarchy photographs. The main exposition contains articles from 16th to early 20th centuries, which include [[chalice (cup)|chalice]]s, [[crucifix]]es, and textiles from 16th–19th centuries, with needlework and [[embroidery]] of Ukrainian masters. The remainder of the collection consists of pieces from the Lavra's Printing House and the Lavra's Icon Painting Workshop.<ref name=\"Kyiv Sightseeing Guide\">{{cite book | year=2001 | title=Kyiv Sightseeing Guide | publisher=Centre d'Europe | location=Kiev/Lviv | isbn=966-7022-29-3}}</ref>\n+[[File:Orthodox pilgrim.jpg|thumb|200px|Orthodox pilgrim in Kiev Pechersk Lavra – women must cover their head when entering Lavra.]]\n+The Kiev Pechersk Lavra is one of the largest museums in Kiev. The main exposition contains articles from 16th to early 20th centuries, which include [[chalice (cup)|chalice]]s, [[crucifix]]es, and textiles from 16th–19th centuries, with needlework and [[embroidery]] of Ukrainian masters. The remainder of the collection consists of pieces from the Lavra's Printing House and the Lavra's Icon Painting Workshop.<ref name=\"Kyiv Sightseeing Guide\">{{cite book | year=2001 | title=Kyiv Sightseeing Guide | publisher=Centre d'Europe | location=Kiev/Lviv | isbn=966-7022-29-3}}</ref>\n The museum provides tours of the [[catacombs]], which contain remains of Orthodox saints or their relics. The Caves are of geological interest because they are excavated into [[loess]] ground. Analysis:
Record 641 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision made by the user "Denisarona" reflects a significant shift in the naming convention of the Kyiv Pechersk Lavra to "Kiev Pechersk Lavra." This change in spelling is not merely a stylistic choice; it aligns with a broader narrative that has been used in geopolitical contexts, particularly by Russian sources, to assert a claim over Ukrainian cultural heritage. The term "Kiev" is often associated with Russian narratives that downplay Ukrainian sovereignty and identity, while "Kyiv" is the Ukrainian spelling that emphasizes the city's cultural and national significance.

The comment by the user indicates an undoing of a previous revision, which suggests a contentious editing history surrounding the naming of this important cultural site. The use of "Kiev" instead of "Kyiv" can be seen as an attempt to align with Russian perspectives that frame the narrative of cultural oppression and territorial claims, thus weaponizing the cultural heritage associated with the site.

Additionally, the overall tone of the changes, which include the removal of Ukrainian spellings and references, contributes to a narrative that could be interpreted as an effort to diminish Ukrainian identity in favor of a Russian-centric view. This aligns with the examples of weaponization terms provided, particularly in the context of cultural heritage and the ongoing conflict between Ukraine and Russia.

Judgment: Weaponised
=============================================

  "Diff": "--- \n+++ \n@@ -1,66 +0,0 @@\n-[[Image:Virsky First Dance.JPG|thumb|300px|right|A performance of a traditional Ukrainian dance by [[Virsky]] dance ensemble]]\n-{{Ukrainians}}\n-\n-The '''Culture of [[Ukraine]]''' is a result of influence over millennia from the West and East, with an assortment of strong culturally-identified [[ethnic]] groups. Like most [[Western world|Western]] countries, Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by [[Christianity]]. [[Russia]]n and other Eastern European cultures also have had a more or less significant impact on the Ukrainian culture.\n-\n-==Religion==\n-\n-[[Religion]] is practiced throughout the country—[[Eastern Orthodox Church|Orthodox Christianity]] and [[Eastern Catholic Churches|Eastern Catholicism]] are the two most widely practiced religions; [[Protestantism]] and [[Judaism]] are also well represented. The [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church]] is the largest in the country. Faithful of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]], the second largest, practice Byzantine rites but are united with the [[Roman Catholic Church]].\n-\n-==Social customs==\n-{{Cleanup-section|date=December 2007}}\n-Ukrainians generally carry themselves in a very polite, civilized manner. Men often hold the door open for a woman when she enters a building, stand up when a woman enters the room, and, if there is a shortage of seats, men will give up their seats to the women. In rural areas, men will sometimes kiss a woman's hand, but this is starting to go out of fashion.\n- \n-According to convention, when standing at a threshold (doorsill), do not shake hands or offer anything to be taken by the person on the other side. A young unmarried man or woman should not be seated at a table's corner.  Always buy an odd number of flowers as a gift, unless it is a funeral.  In that case, it is appropriate to buy an even number. When passing through the aisles in a theater or elsewhere, it is polite to face the people sitting down.\n-\n-==Cuisine==\n-{{main|Ukrainian cuisine|Ukrainian wine}}\n-\n-[[Food]] is an important part to the Ukrainian culture.  Special foods are used at [[Easter]] as well as [[Christmas]], that are not made at any other time of the year. At Christmas time, for example, ''[[kutia]]'' - a mixture of cooked buckwheat groats, poppy seeds, and honey, and special sweet breads - is prepared.\n-\n-An average Ukrainian diet consists of fish, cheeses and a variety of sausages. [[Head cheese]] is also quite popular in Ukraine as well as Kovbasa, a type of sausage. Typically bread is a core part of every meal, and must be included for the meal to be \"complete.\"  At Christmas time, for example, it is tradition to have a [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-course meal]]. Included at Easter are the famous [[pysanky]] (coloured and patterned eggs). Making these eggs is a long process, and they are not actually eaten, but displayed in the centre of the table (usually around the bread).\n-\n-Ukrainians often toast to good health, linger over their meal, and engage in lively conversation with family and friends. Often they will drink tea (''[[chai]]''), wine, or coffee afterwards with a simple dessert, such as a fruit pastry.\n-\n-===Best-known foods===\n-* [[Salo (food)|Salo]] (salted pork fat with garlic)\n-* [[Borshch]] (a vegetable based soup, usually with beets and beef or pork meat)\n-* [[Holubtsi]] (cabbage rolls stuffed with rice and meat usually)\n-* [[Varenyky]] (stuffed dumplings, also known as [[perogies]] or pyrohy)\n-* [[Pampushky]] (a fried, dessert version of varenyky, filled with fruit instead of meat or cheese)\n-\n-==Dance==\n-{{main|Ukrainian dance}}\n-\n-A Ukrainian style of dancing is called [[Kalyna]]. Both men and women participate in this type of dancing. \n-\n-* The women wear colourful costumes, sometimes featuring a solid-coloured (usually blue, green, red, or black) tunic and matching apron, and under that an open skirt, and below that a white skirt with an embroidered hem that should reach an inch or so below the knee. If they wear a tunic, then under that they wear a long-sleeved richly [[Ukrainian embroidery|embroidered]] white shirt. Traditionally, women wear a type of red leather boots to dance in. They also wear a beautiful flower head piece ([[vinok]]), that is a headband covered with flowers and has long flowing ribbons down the back that flow when they dance, and plain red coral necklaces.\n-* The men wear baggy pants (usually blue, white, black or red) and a shirt (usually white, but sometimes black) embroidered at the neck and down the stomach. Over the shirt they sometimes will wear a richly embroidered vest. Around their waist they wear a thick sash with fringed ends. Like the women, they wear boots, but these can be black or white in addition to red.\n-* Kalyna dancing involves partner dancing. One dance, called the [[previtanya]], is a greeting dance. It is slow and respectful, the women bow to the audience and present bread with salt on a cloth and flowers. Another, called the [[hopak]] is much more lively, and involves many fast-paced movements. Hence hopak as a dance is derived from hopak martial art of [[Cossacks]].\n-\n-==Weddings==\n-{{main|Ukrainian wedding traditions}}\n-Weddings traditionally take place in churches, the bride in white and the groom in black. Wedding celebrations are known to continue for days, even a week. They are accompanied by lively music and dancing, drinking and eating, and fellowship. \n-Some particular wedding customs include:\n-\n-* Before the wedding, the groom goes with his friends to the bride's house and bargains with \"money' to get a bride from her family. \n-* When leaving the church, the bride carries a basket of candies or sweets to throw to children and the crowd\n-* The groom carries her down any stairs\n-* At the reception, the bride dances with each of the unmarried women present, and places a special veil on each of them. This veil symbolises that they are still pure, but that the bride hopes they will get married soon. She also throws a bunch of flowers and the girl who catches it first will likely be the next to marry.\n-\n-==See also==\n-* [[Architecture of Ukraine]]\n-\n-==External links==\n-* [http://libraries.theeuropeanlibrary.org/Ukraine/treasures_en.xml Treasures of the national library of Ukraine] displayed via [[The European Library]]\n-\n-{{Ukraine topics}}\n-{{Culture of Europe}}\n-\n-[[Category:Ukrainian culture|*]]\n-\n-[[es:Cultura de Ucrania]]\n-[[fr:Culture de l'Ukraine]]\n-[[ro:Cultura Ucrainei]]\n-[[ru:Украинский фольклор]]\n-[[uk:Українська культура]]"
}

Analysis:
Record 222 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision indicates a complete removal of a substantial section of content related to Ukrainian culture, including details about religion, social customs, cuisine, dance, and weddings. The comment "[[WP:AES|←]]Blanked the page" suggests an intent to erase the cultural narrative presented in the article. This act of blanking can be interpreted as an attempt to undermine or erase the cultural identity of Ukraine, which aligns with the weaponization of cultural heritage.

The absence of any explanation or justification for this removal in the comment further implies a disregard for the significance of the content that was deleted. By erasing these cultural elements, the revision could contribute to a narrative that diminishes the recognition of Ukrainian culture, potentially aligning with broader geopolitical narratives that seek to delegitimize or suppress Ukrainian identity in favor of a dominant perspective. This aligns with the weaponization terms associated with narratives of cultural oppression and the legitimacy of territorial claims.

Judgment: Weaponised

Special foods are used at [[Easter]] as well as [[Christmas]], that are not made at any other time of the year. At Christmas time, for example, ''[[kutia]]'' - a mixture of cooked buckwheat groats, poppy seeds, and honey, and special sweet breads - is prepared.\n \n-An average Ukrainian diet consists of fish, cheeses and a variety of sausages. [[Head cheese]] is also quite popular in Ukraine as well as Kovbasa, a type of sausage. Typically bread is a core part of every meal, and must be included for the meal to be \"complete.\"  At Christmas time, for example, it is tradition to have a [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-course meal]]. Included at Easter are the famous [[pysanky]] (coloured and patterned eggs). Making these eggs is a long process, and they are not actually eaten, but displayed in the centre of the table (usually around the bread).\n+An average Ukrainian diet consists of fish, cheeses and a variety of sausages. [[Head cheese]] is also quite popular in Ukraine as well as Kilbasa, a type of sausage. Typically bread is a core part of every meal, and must be included for the meal to be \"complete.\"  At Christmas time, for example, it is tradition to have a [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-course meal]]. Included at Easter are the famous [[pysanky]] (coloured and patterned eggs). Making these eggs is a long process, and they are not actually eaten, but displayed in the centre of the table (usually around the bread).\n \n Ukrainians often toast to good health, linger over their meal, and engage in lively conversation with family and friends. Often they will drink tea (''[[chai]]''), wine, or coffee afterwards with a simple dessert, such as a fruit pastry.\n "
}

In the wake of the break up of the [[Russian Empire]], Russian Orthodox church was seen as counterrevolutionary and pro-White by the Communists, and a [[Ukrainian Autonomous Orthodox Church]] was  founded  with their encouragement in order to reduce the influence of patriarch [[Tikhon of Moscow]] whose position towards the revolution was strongly critical. The [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] government later changed its religious policy and started to persecuted UAOC along with the Russian Orthodox church.  \n \n-On [[October 8]], [[1942]] Archbishop Nikanor and Bishop Mstyslav (later a Patriarch) of the UAOC and Metropolitan Oleksiy (Hromadsky) of the Ukrainian Autonomous Orthodox Church concluded an [[Act of Union]], uniting the two national churches at the [[Pochaev]] [[Lavra]] (monastery). Metropolitan Oleksiy was executed in [[Volhynia]] on [[May 7]], [[1943]].   \n+On [[October 8]], [[1942]] Archbishop Nikanor and Bishop Mstyslav (later a Patriarch) of the UAOC and Metropolitan Oleksiy (Hromadsky) of the Ukrainian Autonomous Orthodox Church concluded an [[Act of Union]], uniting the two national churches at the [[Pochaev]] [[Lavra]] (monastery). Later [[German]] occupation authorities and pro-Russian hierarchs of the Autonomous Church allegedly forced Metropolitan Oleksiy to remove his signature. Metropolitan Oleksiy was executed in [[Volhynia]] on [[May 7]], [[1943]].   \n \n The Russian Orthodox Church regained its general monopoly in the [[Ukrainian SSR]] after [[World War II]] following another shift in the official Soviet attitude towards Christian churches.  As a result many started to accuse it of being a [[puppet]] of the [[Communist Party]].  After the suspicious death of Patriarch Tikhon these autocephalic churches sought to remain independent; something that Moscow tolerated until after World War II when many Ukrainian Orthodox clergy not affiliated with Moscow fled to [[Germany]], the [[United States]], or [[Canada]]. The UAOC and UGCC and their church property in Ukraine were liquidated by the Soviet authorities who transfered some of their property to the Patriarchate of Moscow, which could legally lay claim to any Orthodox church property that was within the territory of its uncontested jurisdiction.  Any UAOC hierarchs or clergy who remained in Ukraine and refused to join the Russian Church were persecuted and many sent to [[gulag|concentration camps]]. In the next several years, similar actions were taken against the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]] in Western Ukraine and [[Transcarpathia]].\n "
}

Record 68 (Version: diff):

The original text refers to "Nazi occupation authorities," which is a clear and direct reference to the German forces during World War II. The revision changes this to "Later German occupation authorities," which, while still accurate, introduces the term "allegedly" in the context of the actions taken against Metropolitan Oleksiy. This shift can imply doubt about the actions of the German authorities, potentially downplaying their culpability in the historical narrative.

Additionally, the phrase "pro-Russian hierarchs" remains unchanged, which continues to frame the narrative in a way that suggests a conflict between Ukrainian and Russian interests. The use of "allegedly" can serve to create ambiguity around the actions of the German authorities, which may be interpreted as an attempt to shift blame or mitigate the historical accountability of those involved.

Overall, the changes in the language reflect a nuanced attempt to reshape the narrative surrounding the historical events, which can be seen as a form of weaponization of cultural heritage by altering perceptions of responsibility and agency in a sensitive historical context.

================= EDIT #184 =================

JSON Record:
{
  "version": "diff",
  "Timestamp": "2006-06-02T20:54:00Z",
  "User": "Faustian",
  "Comment": "/* Second Polish Republic */ removed info not concerning Ukraine (Warsaw, Polish Orthodox), added other info",
  "Diff": "--- \n+++ \n@@ -72,7 +72,9 @@\n ===Second Polish Republic===\n The treaty [[Peace of Riga]] in [[1921]] following the [[Polish-Soviet War]] gave the newly created [[Second Polish Republic]] significant areas of the ethnically Ukrainian (and Belarusian) territories. This included [[Polessie]] and [[Volhynia]], areas with almost exclussively Orthodox population amongst the rural peasents. As well as the former Austrian province of [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]] with its [[Uniate]] population. \n \n-Many of the Polish authorities saw the Orthodox Church as a strong reminder of Russian rule and [[Russification]]. Many parishes in ethnically Polish places shared the same fate (although under a different motive) with those in Bolshevik Russia. (Particularly the [[Alexander Nevsky Cathedral, Warsaw|Alexander Nevsky Cathedral in Warsaw)]]. However with respect to Eastern Poland, the [[Polish government]] initially issued a decree defending the rights of the Orthodox minorities. In practice, this often failed, as the [[Catholics]], also eager to strengthen their position, had official representation in the [[Sejm]] and the courts. Any accusation was strong enough for a particular church to be confiscated and handed over to Roman Catholic church.  During the Polish occupation, 190 Orthodox churches were destroyed and 150 were forcibly transformed into Roman Catholic (not Ukrainian Catholic) churches <ref name=Subtelny>{{cite book| author=Subtelny, O. | title=Ukraine: A History| location= Toronto | publisher= University of Toronto Press | year = 1988| }}</ref>.  Such actions were condemned by the head of the Ukrainian Catholic Church, metropolitan Andrei Sheptytsky, who claimed that these acts would \"destroy in the souls of our non-united Orthodox brothers the very thought of any possibility of reunion.\" <ref name=Magosci>{{cite book| author=Magosci, P. | title=Morality and Reality: the Life and Times of Andrei Sheptytsky| location= Edmonton, Alberta | publisher= Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies, University of Alberta | year = 1989| }}</ref> \n+Because of the Ukrainian national character of the Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church, the Polish authorities sought to weaken it in various ways.  In 1924, following a visit with the Ukrainian Catholic believers in North America and western Europe, the head of the UGCC was initially denied reentry to Lviv until after a considerable delay.  Polish priests led by their bishops began to undertake missionary work among Eastern Rite faithful, and the administrative restrictions were placed on the Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church <ref name=Magosci>{{cite book| author=Magosci, P. | title=Morality and Reality: the Life and Times of Andrei Sheptytsky| location= Edmonton, Alberta | publisher= Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies, University of Alberta | year = 1989| }}</ref>.\n+\n+With respect to the Orthodox Ukrainian population in eastern Poland, the [[Polish government]] initially issued a decree defending the rights of the Orthodox minorities. In practice, this often failed, as the [[Catholics]], also eager to strengthen their position, had official representation in the [[Sejm]] and the courts. Any accusation was strong enough for a particular church to be confiscated and handed over to the Roman Catholic church.  During the Polish occupation, 190 Orthodox churches were destroyed and 150 were forcibly transformed into Roman Catholic (not Ukrainian Catholic) churches <ref name=Subtelny>{{cite book| author=Subtelny, O. | title=Ukraine: A History| location= Toronto | publisher= University of Toronto Press | year = 1988| }}</ref>.  Such actions were condemned by the head of the Ukrainian Catholic Church, metropolitan Andrei Sheptytsky, who claimed that these acts would \"destroy in the souls of our non-united Orthodox brothers the very thought of any possibility of reunion.\" <ref name=Magosci>{{cite book| author=Magosci, P. | title=Morality and Reality: the Life and Times of Andrei Sheptytsky| location= Edmonton, Alberta | publisher= Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies, University of Alberta | year = 1989| }}</ref> \n  \n In addition to persecution from the new authorities, the Orthodox clergy found itself with no ecclestical link to submit to. Like most ex-[[Russian Orthodox]] communities that ended up outside the USSR, and thus with no possible contact with the persecuted mother church, the [[Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople]] agreed to take over [[Moscow Patriarchy]]'s role and in [[1923]] the [[Polish Orthodox Church]] was formed out of the parishes that were on the territory of the Polish republic although 90% of its clergy and believers were non-Polish people.\n "
}

Analysis:
Record 269 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision introduces a narrative that emphasizes the oppression of the Orthodox Ukrainian population under Polish rule, particularly highlighting the destruction of Orthodox churches and the forced transformation of these churches into Roman Catholic ones. The phrase "During the Polish occupation, 190 Orthodox churches were destroyed and 150 were forcibly transformed into Roman Catholic (not Ukrainian Catholic) churches" serves as a strong indicator of cultural erasure and oppression, which aligns with weaponization narratives that frame historical events in a way that justifies current grievances or actions.

Additionally, the comment by the user "Faustian" suggests a selective removal of information that does not pertain to Ukraine, which could imply an intent to focus the narrative on Ukrainian suffering and oppression while downplaying other aspects of the historical context. This selective emphasis can be seen as an attempt to shape public perception in a way that aligns with a specific political or cultural agenda, further indicating the potential weaponization of cultural heritage. 

The overall tone of the added content, which underscores the struggles of the Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church and the Orthodox population, contributes to a narrative that could be used to rally support or justify actions against perceived historical injustices, thus fitting the criteria for weaponization.

Judgment: Weaponised

Record 179 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision by the user "Kuban kazak" contains several linguistic indicators that suggest an attempt to weaponize cultural heritage narratives, particularly in the context of Ukrainian and Russian Orthodox Church relations. 

1. **Terminology and Framing**: The user refers to the "UOC-MP" (Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate) and contrasts it with the "UAOC" (Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church) in a way that emphasizes the perceived oppression and control by the Moscow Patriarchate. Phrases like "mass arrests of UAOC's hierarchy and clergy" and "handing over all churches to the Russian Orthodox Church" frame the narrative in a way that highlights victimization and loss of cultural autonomy.

2. **Historical Context**: The user invokes historical events, such as the "Russification" policies of the Soviet Union, to argue against the legitimacy of the UOC-MP's claims. This use of historical context is a common tactic in weaponizing cultural narratives, as it seeks to establish a moral high ground based on past injustices.

3. **Confrontational Tone**: The language used is confrontational, with phrases like "I do not need to tell you with what happened to [User:Vernyhora] or the like of other POV-pushers," which implies a threat or warning against opposing viewpoints. This kind of rhetoric can serve

JSON Record:
{
  "version": "diff",
  "Timestamp": "2019-02-28T12:43:32Z",

  "Diff": "--- \n+++ \n@@ -1,11 +1,18 @@\n {{Culture of Ukraine}}\n '''Ukrainian culture''' is a composition of material and spiritual values of [[Ukrainian people]] that has formed throughout its history ([[Ukrainian history]]). It is closely intertwined with [[ethnic studies]] about ethnic Ukrainians and Ukrainian [[historiography]] which is focused on [[history of Kiev]] and region around it.\n \n-The modern Ukrainian culture is believed to be formed as a descendent of the Old Russian (Ruthenian) state centered in [[Kiev]] and known as [[Kievan Rus']]. Therefore it has a shared culture and history with neighboring nations, such as [[Belarusians]] and [[Russians]]. Ukrainian historian and Imperial Russian subject [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] referred to Ukraine as ''Ukraine-Rus''.\n+Whilst the country has often struggled to preserve its independence its people have managed to retain their cultural possessions and are proud of the considerable cultural legacy they have created. Numerous writers have contributed to the country's rich literary history such as [[Taras Shevchenko]] and [[Ivan Franko]]. The Ukrainian culture has experienced a significant resurgence since the establishment of independence in 1991.\n \n-Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]]. The [[Soviet era]] unified the cultures of many unrelated nations with a common language.\n+The modern Ukrainian culture is believed to be formed as a descendent of the ancient state of [[Kievan Rus']] centered in [[Kiev]] as well the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]], both of which Ukrainians claim as their historical ancestors. Therefore it has a shared culture and history with neighboring nations, such as [[Belarusians]] and [[Russians]]. Ukrainian historian, academic and politician of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic|Ukrainian Peoples Republic,]] [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] referred to Ukraine as ''Ukraine-Rus,'' emphasising Ukraines historical claim to the ancient state of Kievan Rus. \n \n-The idea of Ukrainian culture and ethnic studies has its controversies. According to modern Russian ethnic studies and historiography Ukrainian culture and Ukrainian nation is part of bigger [[triune Russian nation]], where Russians are dominant ethnic group and Ukrainians are simply its regional branch. At the same time Ukrainian culture has a lot of commonalities with [[Polish culture]] and [[Belarusian culture]], lesser extent [[Yiddish culture]], due to being related for many centuries to the former [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]]. In addition Ukrainian culture has special relations with Moldavian culture which is part of bigger [[Vlach nation]] today politically realized as country of [[Romania]].\n+Traditional peasant folk art, embroidery and vernacular architecture are critiacl to Ukrainian culture, and its elements have often been determined by the resources available at the time. The countries strong tradition of folk art and embroidery continues to this day, with [[Ukrainian embroidery]] often considered an art form in itself. \n+\n+Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]]. The [[Soviet era]] unified the cultures of many unrelated nations with a common language and led to the appropriation of many of the socialist republics culture and identity. Because of the countries unique positions its culture has been influenced by both Western Europe, Russia and Asia.\n+\n+Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past have often implemented policies aimed at integrating the endemic population into their occupiers own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture for example the policy of [[Russification of Ukraine|Russification]] posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture. \n+\n+Whilst progressing into modernity, Ukraine remains a highly traditional country, where the observance of certain customs and practices play a central role in its culture. Many significant Ukrainian holidays and events are based on the old Julian Calendar and so differ to their Gregorian counterparts, these include Christmas and New Years Eve, both of which are highly important in Ukrainian culture. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theculturetrip.com/europe/ukraine/articles/11-things-you-should-know-about-ukrainian-culture/|title=11 Things You Should Know About Ukrainian Culture|last=Sibirtseva|first=Maria|website=Culture Trip|access-date=2019-02-28}}</ref>\n+\n \n ==Customs==\n ===Holidays and celebrations ==="
}

Analysis:
Record 706 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision introduces several linguistic indicators that suggest a weaponization of cultural heritage. Notably, the phrases "foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past have often implemented policies aimed at integrating the endemic population into their occupiers own population" and "the policy of Russification posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture" highlight a narrative of oppression and cultural survival. This framing positions Ukrainian culture as a victim of external forces, which can be used to justify contemporary political stances and actions against perceived aggressors.

Additionally, the emphasis on "retaining its originality" and the "considerable cultural legacy" creates a narrative of resilience against cultural erasure, which can be a rallying point for national identity. The mention of "significant obstacles" and the historical context of "Russification" further reinforces a narrative of struggle against cultural domination, aligning with the broader themes of cultural preservation and resistance against external influences. 

Overall, the language shifts towards a more emotive and politically charged narrative, which can be interpreted as an attempt to frame Ukrainian cultural heritage in a way that supports current geopolitical narratives.

Judgment: Weaponised

Analysis:
Record 182 (Version: diff):
**Judgment: Weaponised**

**Explanation:**
The revision contains several linguistic indicators that suggest an attempt to weaponize cultural heritage, particularly in the context of Ukrainian and Russian Orthodox Church history. 

1. **Terminology and Framing**: The user Qe2 emphasizes the term "Russification" in relation to the Soviet government's policies, which is a loaded term that implies a systematic effort to impose Russian culture and suppress Ukrainian identity. This framing can be seen as an attempt to highlight cultural oppression, aligning with narratives that resonate with Ukrainian perspectives on historical injustices.

2. **Cultural Sensitivity**: The user replaces "peasantry" with "population" to avoid the derogatory connotations associated with the term "peasant" in Russian discourse. This sensitivity to language reflects an awareness of cultural identity and the historical context of Ukrainian oppression, which can be weaponized to rally support against perceived cultural aggressions.

3. **Historical Context**: The mention of the "transfer of the Ukrainian Church to Moscow control" and the subsequent "virtual destruction of the rural church" invokes a narrative of loss and victimization that can be used to justify contemporary political stances. This aligns with the weaponization of cultural heritage by framing historical events in a way that emphasizes suffering and oppression.

4. **Ad Hominem and Disruption Claims**: The user references disruptive behavior and vandalism in the context of editing Wikipedia, which can be interpreted as an attempt to delegitimize opposing

Judgment: Weaponised
